div.p: THE GVIDE VNTO TRVE BLESSEDNESSE.
OR, A BODY OF THE DOctrine of the Scriptures, directing man to the ſauing knowledge of GOD.
Collected By SAM. CROOKE.

q.p: Thou haſt knowne the holy Scriptures of a Child, which are able to make thee wiſe vnto ſaluation, through the faith which is in Chriſt Ieſus.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by Iohn Pindley, for Nathaniel Butter, and are to be ſold at his ſhop neere S. Auſtins gate, at the ſigne of the Pyed Bull. 1613.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT WORSHIPFVLL SIR ARTHVR CAPELL Knight, his ſingular good Patrone, the Author wiſheth, what the worke deſcribeth.
div.p:
TO whome, vnder Chriſt, ſhould I render this account of my poore labours in my charge, but vnto your ſelfe, Right worſhipfull; by whoſe meanes the Lord vouchſafed mee ſo free and comfortable an entrance therein to? Jt is the Lord Ieſus, the doore of the ſheepe, of whom you haue obtayned
this mercie, rather to be, among few, a faithfull dorekeeper in his houſe; then to dwell, with manie, in the Simoniacall tabernacles of wickedneſſe. Neither ſhall it euer repent you, that you haue not drunke of thoſe ſtollen waters, or rather of that blood of ſoules; wherewith too manie, in theſe gold-thirſtie daies, doe purchaſe Aceldama vnto them and theirs. Let others enrich themſelues with the wages of vnrighteouſneſſe; let them make their boaſt of their couetous deſire, and bleſſe themſelues in their contempt of the Lord: but let the Lord keep this for euer in the purpoſe of the hearts of his ſeruants, to deale faithfully and vprightlie in ſo honourable and weightie a truſt. And let ſuch as haue found
this bleſſing, in theſe corrupt daies, to haue a free acceſſe to the worke and charge of the miniſterie, thankfullie acknowledge the ſame both to God and man. Amongſt whome I gladlie profeſſe my ſelfe to be one; and therefore, to the honour of God, and the iuſt acknowledgement of your Chriſtian integritie, I commend this worke to your worthy name and Patronage: your example to the memorie and imitation of poſteritie: & your ſelfe with all your Worſhipfull familie, to the holie direction and ſafe tuition of Almightie God.

closer.signed: Your worſhips in Chriſt euer bounden, SAM. CROOKE.

div.head: TO THE CHRISTIAN READERS, eſpecially thoſe of my charge the inhabitants of Wrington in Somerſetſhire.
div.p:
BLeſſedneſſe is the Alpha and Omega of Man, the beginning of nature, and the end of Grace. The naturall Philoſopher in his inqueſt of Happineſſe laieth this ground,Ariſt. Ethi • . lib. 1. cap. 1 that, All things deſire that which either in trueth or in opinion is good for them; and that onely is good, which tendeth vnto the onely good, the vttermoſt end and perfection of their ſeuerall natures. But where Philoſophie ends Religion begins: or rather, where Reaſon failes Grace ſupplies, proclaiming all that nature (in the blindneſſe of Corruption) accounts excellent to be vanitie of vanities; Eccl. 1.2. and the end of all
and whole of man, Eccl. 12.13, 14. to be the feare of God, and the keeping of his Commandements. And that with reſpect to the laſt Iudgement, wherein all workes of men, whether good or euill, though neuer ſo ſecret, ſhall come to light and triall, and receiue their due reward. Yea ſo farre was nature in ſtaken in the matter of Bleſſedneſſe, that it could not truely define ſo much as the happineſſe and perfection of the brute creature; which the Scripture ſheweth to be the Reuelation and glorious Redemption of the Sonnes of God. Rom. 8.19, 21. Wherefore as it is euident in nature that all men ſeeke bleſſedneſſe: ſo it is apparant in experience, that there is no man that can attaine thereto without a ſupernaturall guide; without which, wee ſee that touching Bleſſedneſſe, there are as many mindes as men, and as many waies as wits; euery one croſſing another, and ſo all prouing that all are inſufficient.

For this cauſe I haue framed this Treatiſe, for a direction to that, which all men ſeeke, and ſo few finde. Wherein from the ground of nature,Ioh. 1.9. as of that light which enlightneth euery man that commeth into the world, I endeuor to raiſe the building of ſauing knowledge.

Although (to ſpeake properly) the light of nature ſheweth rather the neceſſitie
then the way to ſauing knowledge, and is a ground rather of enquirie, then of attaining thereto. For all that nature can truely determine, and articulatelie pronounce concerning this matter, is, that Bleſſedneſſe is to bee ſought, and ſuch a bleſſedneſſe, as may ſort with the nature of man the ſeeker; eſpecially in regard of his better part, which is his ſoule. The reſt well may ſhee ſtammer at; as that the ſoule is not onely a reaſonable, but alſo a religious and immortall ſpirit, and therefore cannot be bleſſed without the euerlaſting fellowſhip and fauour of God, to whom ſhee is by band of conſcience obliged: But plainelie to vtter theſe (more then metaphyſicall) trueths, is of ſuch onely, whoſe tongue-ſtring is looſed, and to whom the Lord hath ſaid, Ephphata, be opened. Mar. 7.34 35. And with this helpe, Reaſon it ſelfe will yet goe further, and ſay, that the meanes of acquaintance and fellowſhip with God, can be no other, then thoſe which himſelfe affordeth, and namely his Word, the onely infallible Index of the minde of the ſpeaker; and therefore it cannot but reiect, as vncertain and vnſafe, whatſoeuer the preſumptuous boldneſſe of fleſh and blood obtrudeth againſt, or beſides this rule.

And yet further touching the triall of this touchſtone, whether it be the word of God or no, Reaſon it ſelfe will acknowledge, that (whatſoeuer inducements may bee from the authoritie of thoſe whom we credit and reſpect) none but God himſelfe can thoroughly reſolue vs of it: and that either by the apparant traces of diuine maieſtie in the letter of the Scripture; or by the ſecret teſtimonie of the ſame Spirit that inſpired it, inclining the heart of the reader or hearer to embrace and ſubſcribe vnto the authoritie of it. So that now the true beleeuer may ſay vnto the Church as thoſe Conuerts to the woman of Samaria, Now wee beleeue not becauſe of thy ſaying, Ioh. 4.42. for wee haue heard him our ſelues.

Vnto reaſon thus enlightened or willing thus to be enlightened, I hope my manner of proceeding in this Treatiſe will ſeeme reaſonable; wherein I haue with the vttermoſt of my poore abilitie faithfully endeuoured to compriſe the whole bodie of the heauenly doctrine of the Scriptures: and that in ſuch a methode, as vpon long and ſerious penſitation, I haue iudged moſt meete, to bring light to the matter, and eaſe, both for vnderſtanding and memorie, to the Reader.

A ſubiect, I grant, not of ſo pleaſing a ſtraine either to the writer or to the reader, as ſome other treatiſes which afford more libertie of inuention and diſcourſe. But I haue learned of the bleſſed Apoſtle of the Gentiles,Phil. 3.1. not to be greeued to write theſe ſame (ſeeming triuiall) things vnto you; knowing that euen from theſe things is the experience beſt taken of Chriſt ſpeaking in the Miniſter (and therefore euen from theſe points doth the ſame Apoſtle auouch his vnderſtanding in the myſterie of Chriſt) and withall being aſſured, that for you it is a ſure courſe, 2. Cor. 13.3. Eph. 3.4. to be alwaies put in remembrance of theſe things, 2. Pet. 1.12 though yee haue knowledge, and bee eſtabliſhed in the preſent trueth.

The experience of eleuen yeeres hath taught me, that it is not enough to teach in publike, vnleſſe the auditors haue care to inſtruct themſelues, and one another priuately at home. For which purpoſe, I haue framed this Treatiſe by way of Queſtion and anſwere, a waye moſt familiar for inſtruction, and whereby the ſpirit both of the anſwerer, and of all that attend, is ſtirred vp to bethinke themſelues, what might bee moſt aptly anſwered, to the Queſtion propounded. Neither haue I done this onely in the larger Treatiſe; but alſo extracted
an Abridgement of the ſubſtance thereof, in a farre briefer draught, for the priuate vſe of Chriſtian families, and help of the weaker ſort; that becomming all things to all men, 1. Cor. 9.22. I might by all meanes ſaue ſome.

Wherefore as I haue out of my penurie caſt in all that I had, Luc. 21.4. euen theſe two mites, into the treaſurie of the Church; So I earneſtly deſire thee, Chriſtian Reader (eſpecially you that are of my charge, beloued in our Lord Ieſus, to whom as my labours are principally due, and moſt familiar, ſo from you aboue others, I expect this Retaliation) to employ this our Lords talent, now in thy hands, for thine owne beſt aduantage, and of thoſe that are committed vnto thee by the Lord.

So ſhalt thou ſettle thy ſelfe, and them, vpon the ground of ſauing truth. So ſhalt thou be prepared to giue anſwere to euery man, 1. Pet. 3.15. that ſhall aske of thee a reaſon of the hope that is in thee. So ſhalt thou be able, to make farre greater & ſweeter benefite of whatſoeuer thou ſhalt heare out of the word preached; which vnto thoſe that are ignorant of the grounds of Religion,Eſa. 8.6. or deſpiſe theſe waters of Shiloah, becauſe they runne ſoftly, is many times vnprofitable and vnſauourie. So ſhalt thou
not be plucked away with the errour of the wicked (whoſe itching eares, 2. Pet. 3.17, 18. 2. Tim. 4.3. 2. Theſ. 2.10. 2. Cor. 11.3. and harts not louing the truth, are eaſily corrupted from the ſimplicitie that is in Chriſt) and ſo fall from thine owne ſtedfaſtneſſe: but grow in grace, and in the knowledge of our Lord and Sauiour Ieſus Chriſt. Finally,Gal. 6.16. walking according to this rule, peace ſhall be vpon thee, and mercie, as vpon the Iſrael of God.

closer.signed: Thine in the common faith, and ſeruice of our Lord Ieſus, SAM. CROOKE.

div.head: THE GVIDE VNTO TRVE BLESSEDNES.
SECTION I. Of mans happineſſe, in acquaintance with God, making himſelfe known to vs in his word, written.
div.p: Queſtion. WHat is it that all men doe, and ought chiefly to deſire?
Anſwer. That, being to liue a while in this world, and for euer in another, they may be, both here & hereafter,Num. 23.10 Pſal. 106 4, 5 truly bleſſed.

p.hi: Q. Wherein conſiſteth this true bleſſedneſſe of man?

div.p: A. Not inEccle. 1.2. himſelfe, nor in any other created thing, but onely in Pſal. 37.4 & 73.25. God his Creator, who alone, being infinite, is able to fill the heart of man.

p.hi: Q. How may man find happines in God?

div.p: A. ByIob. 22.21 acquaintance, and fellowſhip with him, who is the fountaine of bleſſedneſſe:Joh. 17.3 Gal. 4.9. ſo knowing him, or rather being knowne of him, that hee mayEccl 12.13. ſerue him, and be2 Cor 5 9 accepted of1. Sam. 2.30 him, honour him, and be honoured by him.

p.hi: Q. God being inuiſible, how may wee come to know him?

div.p: A. The inuiſible things of God are reuealed vnto mankinde, partly by hisPſ 19 1 &c Rom. 1.20 workes, to leaue all without excuſe, but chiefly by his Pſa. 19.7. &c. Iob 22.22 Ioh. 6 68 word to guide vs to ſaluation.

p.hi: Q. Where is that ſauing word of God to be had?

div.p: A. In the writings of the holy Prophets & Apoſtles, commonly called the Joh. 5.39 2. Tim. 3.15 Scriptures of the old & new Teſtament.

p.hi: Q. Is there not alſo an vnwritten word of God?

div.p: A. No For howſoeuerHeb. 1.1 Num. 12.6. at the firſt the whole word of God was deliuered without writing, by immediate reuelation or tradition, yet ſince thatExo. 34.27 God commanded the Scriptures to be written, the Church hath beeneEſay 8.20 Luc. 16.29, 31 directed vnto the Scriptures onely for the ſauing knowledge of God.

p.hi: Q. By whom was this word written?
A.

list.item: 1 The old Teſtament by Moſes, and the Rom. 3.2 Prophets, who deliuered the ſame vnto the Church of the Iewes.
2 The new Teſtament by the Apoſtles & Euangeliſt, Rom. 1.16 Reu. 1.11. by whom it was deliuered to the Church of the Gentiles.

p.hi: Q. In what language did they write?

div.p: A. In the language beſt knowne vnto the Church: the Prophets in Hebrew, the Apoſtlos in Greeke. In which tongues onely they are, for the letter, to be held authenticall.

p.hi: Q. What ſhall we thinke of the bookes called Apocrypha?

div.p: A. That they are bookes, of good vſe and eſteeme in the Church, for direction of manners; but not to be acknowledged as rules of faith; ſince they were neither written in Hebrew, the language of the Church before Chriſt, nor euer receiued into the Canon of Scripture by them,Rom 3.2. to whom alone, in thoſe times, the Oracles of God were committed.

p.hi: Q. Seeing the Apoſtles and Prophets were men, how can their writings be accounted the word of God?

div.p: A. Becauſe they proceeded2. Pet. 1.20 21. not from the will or minde of man, but holy men of God ſpake and wrote as they were moued by the holy Ghoſt: in which regard the 2. Tim. 3.16 whole Scripture is ſaid to be by diuine inſpiration.

p.hi: Q. How may it appeare that the Scriptures were inſpired by God?
A.

list.item: 1 By the teſtimonie of the Church, both before Chriſt and ſince.
2 By arguments vn-anſwerable, taken from the antiquitie, the maieſtie of the ſtile, the truth of prophecies &c.
3 And moſt effectually, by the teſtimonie of the ſame holy ſpirit, that inſpired them,1. Cor. 2 10 & 14.37 1. Ioh 2, 20. who inclineth our hearts to beleeue what is reuealed in them.

p.hi: Q. Are the Scriptures plaine, and eaſie to be vnderſtood?
A.

list.item: 1 Vnto thoſe2. Cor. 3.4 whoſe eyes the God of this world hath blinded,2. Pet. 3.5. Ioh. 8.43. all things in Scripture, belonging to the ſauing knowledge of God, are darke and difficult.

2 But vnto ſuch as are by gracePſ. 119.18 enlightened, and made willing to vnderſtand, howſoeuer2. Pet. 3.16 ſome things remaine obſcure to exerciſe their diligence, yet the fundamentall doctrines of faith and precepts of life, are allPro. 8.9. plaine and perſpicuous.

p.hi: Q. What need is there then of an interpreter?
A.

list.item: 1 ToActs 8.31 vnfold obſcure places.
2 To2 Pet. 1.12 1. Cor. 14.3. inculcate & apply plaine texts.

p.hi: Q. How are the Scriptures to bee interpreted?

div.p: A. By theNehem. 8.8 Scriptures themſelues, according to the Analogie of faith, and the ſcope and circumſtances of the preſent place.

p.hi: Q. What is the vſe of Scripture?

div.p:
A. It ſerueth, and is2. Tim. 3.16 profitable
To teach truth,
To conuince errour,
For correction of vice,
For direction to good life,
ForRom. 15.4. comfort in affliction, &c.

div.head: SECT. II. Of the Doctrine of the Scriptures, touching God himſelfe.

p.hi: Q. HOw do the Scriptures guide vs to the ſauing knowledge of God?

div.p:
A. By reuealing vnto vs all neceſſarie truthes, concerning
1 God himſelfe.
2 His workes.

p.hi: Q. What doe the Scriptures teach vs concerning God himſelfe?

div.p: A. Foure things; and firſt thatHeb. 11.6. there is a God.

p.hi: Q. What proofes are there of this truth, beſides the teſtimonie of Scriptures?

div.p:
A. Diuers, taken from
1 Gods workes ofZech. 12.1. creation, eſpecially the ſoule of man.
2 His works of prouidence, chiefly hisPſal. 9.16. & 58.10, 11. apparent iudgements on the wicked.
3 The common conſent of all Nations, who rather worſhip any god, or gods, then none at all.
4 TheEſa. 31.14. terrors of conſcience, which make the moſt vngodly miſcreants, will they, nill they, to acknowledge, andPſal. 53 5. & 14.5. tremble at him, &c.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſecond thing that the Scripture teacheth concerning God?

div.p: A. What God is, viz. Joh. 4.24. a Spirit.

list.item: 1 Moſt1. Joh. 1.5. ſimple, without mixture, or compoſition.
21. Tim 1. • 17. Eternall, without beginning, or end.

31 Kings 8 2 •
Infinite, without comprehenſion
of place, or thought.
4Iam. 1.17. Conſtant, without ſhadowe of change.
5Gen 17 1. Abſolute, in power, holines, and glorie.

p.hi: Q. How then can he be knowne of vs, being incomprehenſible?

div.p: A. We onely ſee hisExod. 33.23. & 34.5 backe parts, not his face, and conceiue of him by his names, expreſſing what an one hee is to vs; not in hisIud. 13.18. glorious nature, onely knowne vnto himſelfe.

p.hi: Q. What is the third thing which is taught vs concerning God?

div.p: A. That there is onelyDeut. 6.4. Eſa. 46.9. one God and no more; as alſo both nature teacheth, guiding all things to one principle; and reaſon acknowledgeth, admitting but one that is infinite, and independant.

p.hi: Q. How is it then that many in Scripture are called Gods?

div.p:
A. The name Elohim, or God, is ſometimes improperly giuen to other things, either as theyPſal. 82.6. Exod. 7.1. participate of God his communicable attributes, or as they are1. Cor. 8.5. Phil. 3.19. abuſiuely ſet vp by man in
the place of God; but1. Cor. 8.6. vnto vs there is but one God and Lord, vnto whom therefore the name Iehouah is in ſcripture incommunicably appropriated.

p.hi: Q. What is the fourth thing that we are taught concerning God?

div.p: A. That in this one ſimple and indiuided Godhead, we muſt acknowledge and adore,Mat. 3.16, 17. & 28.19. 1. Ioh. 5.7. three diſtinct perſons, coeſſentiall, and coequall, to wit, the Father, the Sonne, and the holy Ghoſt.

p.hi: Q. What is the Father?

div.p: A. The firſt perſon in the Trinitie,Ioh. 5.26. hauing foundation of perſonall ſubſiſtence from none other.

p.hi: Q. What is the Sonne?

div.p: A. The ſecond perſon, Ioh. 5.26. hauing foundation of perſonall ſubſiſtence from the Father,Pſal. 2.7. Pro. 8.22. &c of whom he is eternally begotten.

p.hi: Q. What is the holy Ghoſt?

div.p: A The third perſon, hauing foundation of perſonall ſubſiſtence from the Father and the Sonne,Ioh. 14.26. & 15.26. from both whom he eternally proceedeth.

p.hi:
Q How may the diſtinction of theſe
perſons he conceiued?
A.

list.item: 1 In relation and order of ſubſiſtence betwixt themſelues, as hath beene ſhewed.

2 In order and manner of working in the creatures, wherein
1 TheIoh. 5.17, 19 original of the action is aſcribed to the Father.
2 TheIoh. 1.3. Heb. 1.2. wiſedome, and manner of working to the Sonne.
3 TheGen. 1.2. 1. Cor. 12.11. efficacie of operation to the holy Ghoſt.

div.p: In a word, God the Father, in the Sonne, by the holy Ghoſt, worketh all things.

div.head: SECT. III. Of the doctrine of the Scriptures, touching the workes of God: and firſt touching his eternall decree.

p.hi: Q. VVHat are wee taught in Scripture concerning the workes of God?

div.p:
A. That God,Pſal 135.6. Eph. 1.11. as from eternitie he
decreed, ſo in time, and euerlaſtingly hee accompliſheth, all things, vnto the full execution of that his decree.

p.hi: Q. How may we take a view of the workes of God?
A.

list.item: 1 Generally, in all his creatures:

2 Specially, in the chiefe of his creatures, Viz.
Angels, and
Men.

p.hi: Q. What is the decree of God concerning all creatures?

div.p: A. It is his eternall and vnchangeable counſell and purpoſe,Prou 6.4 Rom. 11.36 fore-ordaining all things vnto his own glory.

p.hi: Q. What is the decree of God touching Angels and men?

div.p: A. It is his free appointment,1. Theſ. 5.9 foreordaining them to a certaine, and euerlaſting eſtate, for his owne glory.

p.hi: Q. What is that euerlaſting eſtate?

div.p:
A. It is two fold, according to theIbid. parts of this his decree, which are
1. Election, that is,1. Tim. 5.21 appointment of ſome Angels, and men, vntoRom. 9.23. euerlaſting glorie and bleſſedneſſe,
for theEpheſ. 1.6. praiſe of his goodnes.
2 Reprobation, that is,Mat. 25.41 Rom 9.21. 2. Tim. 2.20 appointment of ſome Angels, and men, vnto euerlaſting diſhonour, for the glorie of his iuſtice.

div.head: SECT. IIII. Of the execution of Gods decree: and firſt of Creation.

p.hi: Q. HOw doth God execute this his decree?

div.p:
A. By 2. actions, viz.
Creation, and
Prouidence.

p.hi: Q. What is Creation?

div.p: A. TheGen. 1. Heb. 11.3. making of all things of nothing, very good, in the firſt ſixe daies of the world.

p.hi: Q. How did God create Angels?

div.p: A. He made them all at the firſtCol. 1.16 very good, and glorious ſpirits; yetIob 4.18. mutable.

p.hi: Q. When did God create man?

div.p: A. In theGen. 1.25 ſixt & laſt day of creation.

p.hi: Q. How, and whereof did God make man?
A.

list.item: 1 Hee formed hisGen. 2.7. bodie of the duſt of the earth:
2 HeIbid. breathed in his face the breath of life; ſo making him a liuing ſoule.

p.hi: Q. How many of mankinde did God create at the firſt?
A.

list.item: 1 OnelyGen • .7. one man Adam:
2 Out of him, and for him,Oc. 2.5, •• Mal. 2.15 one woman Eue; ſo made he them Male, and Female.

div.head: SECT. V. Of Prouidence, ſuſtaining, diſpoſing and employing all creatures, eſpecially Angels.

p.hi: Q. THus farre of Creation, what is Prouidence?

div.p: A. The continual care, which God exerciſeth vpon his creatures, once made,Pſal. 119.91 for the ſuſtaining, and diſpoſing of them.

p.hi: Q. How doth God ſuſtaine all creatures?

div.p:
A. He vpholdeth them all in their being Heb. 1.3 by his mighty word: and that
Partly by the continuation of particulars, either for the whole time of this world, as2. Pet. 3.4 heauen, and heauenly bodies, earth and other elements, &c. or for the time of life allotted, as allPſal. 36.6 & 104.27. &c liuing creatures.
Partly, by propagation of kinde, wherbyGen. 7.3. & 8.21, 22 creatures, euen of ſhorteſt continuance, doo ſucceſsiuely abide vnto the end of the world.

p.hi: Q. How are Angels vpheld in their being?

div.p: A. They are all ſuſtained by the power of God, ſo that they ſhallLuk. 20.36 neuer dye, or returne to nothing.

p.hi: Q. How are men vpheld?

div.p: A. Two waies: and firſt, as all other bodily creatures, partly by maintenance of Act 17.28 Pſal. 36.6 1 Tim. 4 10 euery mans life here on earth, for the time allotted by God himſelfe: partly byGen. 1.28 Eccl. 1.4. propagation of kinde, vnto the end of the world, through the bleſſing of procreation.

p.hi: Q. How ſecondly?

div.p: A. As Angels, after a ſort: God ſo prouiding, that when theEccl. 12.7. bodie of man returneth to the earth, from whence it was taken, yet the ſoule periſheth not, but returneth to God that gaue it: yea that theIob. 19 26, 27. ſame body alſo, and euery part thereof, is preſerued in the graue, and ſhall bee ioyned entire to the ſoule at the laſt day, ſo to continue for euer; as ſhall be ſhewed.

p.hi: Q. How doth God diſpoſe of his creatures?

div.p: A. He guideth, and employeth them, to thoſe ſeuerall ends, and vſes, whereby they may beſtPſal. 119 91 ſerue vnto his glorie, and the good of themſelues, and of their follow creatures;Pſal. 8. eſpecially of man.

p.hi: Q. How doth God diſpoſe of Angels?

div.p: A. Two wayes: the firſt reſpecting their euerlaſting condition: the ſecond their emploiment.

p.hi: Q. How did God diſpoſe of Angels, in regard of their euerlaſting condition?

div.p:
A. Diuerſly; according to the parts of his fore-mentioned decree: for firſt, he ſuffered the Reprobate Angels
2. Pet. 2 4 voluntarily and maliciouſly, without any temptation, to fall into that impardonable ſinne ofJude 6. Apoſtaſio, and ſo into damnation irrecouerably; who are called Diuels, reſerued in euerlaſting chaines vnder darkneſſe, vnto the Iudgement of the great day.

p.hi: Q. How did God diſpoſe of elect Angels?

div.p: A. He confirmed them in their well-being, that they mightMat. 18.10 neuer fall by ſinne from their firſt bleſſed eſtate; which are called2. Cor. 11.19 Angels of light,Iob 1.6. ſonnes of God,Luk. 2.13 heauenly ſouldiours, &c.

p.hi: Q. How doth God employ Angels?

div.p: A. He vſeth them all,Iob. 1.6. both good, and euill Angels, as his ſeruants, and miniſters, for the accompliſhment of his will and worke.

p.hi: Q. How are good Angels employed?
A.

list.item: 1. To be as aHeb. 1.14 Pſal. 34.7. & • 1.11. guard and garriſon vnto the Elect of mankinde, for their comfort and protection.
2. To2. Kin. 19.35. reſiſt and puniſh the wicked.

p.hi: Q. How are euil Angels employed?
A

list.item: 1. In2. Sam. 24.1 with 1. Chro. 21.1. Epheſ 6.12 trying and exerciſing the godly.
2. In1. Kin. 22.21.22, 2. Cor. 4.4. ſeducing andLuk. 12.20. tormenting the wicked.

div.head: SECT. VI. Of the Prouidence of God, diſpoſing of man in this world, and of the ſtate of Innocencie.

p.hi: Q. HOw doth God diſpoſe of man?

div.p: A. As of that creature, Pro. 8.31. in whom,Pſal. 8.3. &c. • . Cor. 9.9 10 aboue all other he intendeth to let forth the glory of his wiſedome, power, and goodneſſe: and therefore the Scriptures doe moſt plentifully declare the dealing of God with man, both in the time of this world, and for euer hereafter.

p.hi: Q. How doe the Scriptures ſet forth the dealing of God with man, in the time of this world?

div.p:
A. In a threefold eſtate, (viz.)
1. The ſtate of Innocencie.
2. The ſtate of corruption and miſerie, and
3. The ſtate of Redemption.

TheEccl. 7.31 firſt commonly had and loſt of all mankinde, both Elect and reprobate, without difference:Rom 3.13 the ſecond ſeizing on all men naturally, but abiding without recouerie onely on the reprobate: the third1. Pet. 3.9. Pſal. 130.8. proper to the Elect. All which doe make way vnto that finall and euerlaſting eſtate of honour, or diſhonour, fore-appointed vnto all men; beginning at the ende of this life, perfected at the day of Iudgement, and continuing for euer in the world to come.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſtate of Innocencie?

div.p: A. The holy and happy condition of mankinde,Gen. • .27. created by God after his owne image, and& 2.8. placed by him in Paradiſe.

p.hi: Q. Wherein did that Image of God chiefly conſiſt?

div.p: A. In foure ſingular excellencies: viz.

list.item: 1 AJob 10.12 reaſonable & immortal ſoule.
2 True wiſedome and holineſſe, adorning the ſoule,Pſal. 51 6 Epheſ 4.24. wherein eſpecially he reſembled his maker.
3. A1. Cor. 11.7 body endued with beautie, ſtrength, and immortalitie, anſwerable to the ſoule.
4Gen. 1.28 Dominion ouer the creatures.

p.hi: Q. What happineſſe had man, thus created and placed?

div.p: A. The image of God, in wiſedome, and true holineſſe, ſhining in himMat. 5.8. without teinture or blemiſh, he enioyed full fruition and aſſurance of thePſal. 17.15 fauourable and bliſſefull preſence of this Creatour, together with abſoluteGen. 2.25 contentment in himſelfe, and ſeruice from all the creatures Ge. 2.10.20 to whom as their Lord, hee gaue their originall names.

p.hi: Q. What emploiment had man in this ſtate?

div.p: A. A twofold emploiment, viz.

list.item: 1 Outward,Gen. 2.15. to till and dreſſe the Garden:

2 Spirituall, toIbid. v. 16. 17 worſhip & ſerue God his Creator, and procure his
owne euerlaſting bleſſednes, whereto hee was fitted with freedome of will, & abilitie for perfect obedience vnto God, according to the tenor of the couenant of workes.

p.hi: Q. What was the tenour of the couenant of workes?

div.p: A. The ſubſtance of the Morall law, written in the hearts of our firſt parents, with the promiſes of bleſſednes to them, if they ſhould continue in obedience, and threatnings of death and damnation, if they ſhould tranſgreſſe.

p.hi: Q. How doth it appeare that the law was written in their hearts?
A

list.item: 1 By the effect of it in them both, who immediately after their fall, were forced by the onelyGen. 3.8. guilt of conſcience, (not yet otherwiſe charged) to hide themſelues from Gods preſence.
2 By theGen. 4.6 Ro. 2.14.15 remainders thereof in all mankinde, who euen without the law, are by light of nature a law vnto themſelues.

p.hi: Q. How was the Couenant of workes ſealed?

div.p: A. By the two ſacramentall trees, planted for that purpoſe in the middeſt of the garden. Viz.

list.item: The one,Gen. 2.9. the tree of life, aſſuring life and glorie, vpon condition of obedience.
The other, the & ver. 17. tree of knowledge of good and euill, ſealing death & damnation in caſe of diſobedience.

div.head: SECT. VII. Of the ſtate of Corruption and miſerie: and firſt of the Fall of man.

p.hi: Q. THus farre of the ſtate of Innocencie: what is the ſtate of Corruption and miſerie?

div.p: A. The fearefull condition whereinto in Adam Eccl. 7.31. all mankinde fell, by tranſgreſsing and violating the couenant of workes.

p.hi: Q. What are we to conſider h • rein?

div.p:
A. Two things, to wit,
1 The cauſes,
2 The effect, of the fall of man.

p.hi: Q. To whom doth the conſideration of the cauſes direct vs?

div.p:
A. To three parties, differently concurring to the fall of man, viz.
1. God permitting.
2 Satan tempting.
3 Man yeelding, & falling.

p.hi: Q. How did God permit the fall of man?

div.p:
A. Not byIam. 1.13. 1. Ioh. 2.26. inſtilling into him any euill, or taking from him any abilitie vnto good; but
12. Sa. 24.1. with 1. Chro. 21.1. Suffering Satan to tempt him:
22. Chron. 32, 31. Leauing man to the libertie, and mutabilitie of his owne will, not hindering his fall by ſupply of grace.

p.hi: Q. Why did God permit mans fall?

div.p: A. He did it in great wiſedome, to Rom. 11.32 make way for the glorie both of his mercie in thoſe that ſhall be ſaued by Chriſt, and of his iuſtice in thoſe that ſhall periſh for their ſinnes; yet without wrong to any, Ro. 11.35. being not bound to his creature to vphold him from falling by his grace.

p.hi: Q. How did Satan tempt man?

div.p: A. Being himſelfe fallen, in enuie of Gods glorie, and mans happineſſe, heGe. 3.1. &c ſubtilly addreſſed himſelfe, in the ſerpent, 2 Cor. 11.3. 1. Tim. 2.14 firſt to the woman, the weaker ſexe, and after by her vnto the man, Gen. 3.5. pretending greater loue, and care of their wel-doing, then was in God.

p.hi: Q. Whereto did he tempt them?

div.p: A. To infidelitie, vnthankefulnes, ambition, and ſo to ſlat diſobedience, in eating the forbidden fruit, as the meanes to attaine to an higher degree of bleſſedneſſe.

p.hi: Q. How did they yeeld to the temptation, being created good?

div.p: A. Being left by God to theGen. 3.6. mutabilitie of their owne will, theyEccl. 7.31 voluntarily enclined vnto that euill, whervnto they were tempted; therby not onelyGen. 4.7. looſing for themſelues the image and fauour of God, but withallRom. 3.23. depriuing their poſterity of that bleſſed eſtate, andRom. 5, 12. plunging them into the contrarie.

p.hi: Q. How could all their poſteritie fall with them?

div.p:
A. Being in their loines, who were
by Gods appointment to ſtand or fall in that triall, not as ſingular perſons onely, but alſo as heads of mankinde, Rom. 5.19 • . Cor. 15.22. wee all tooke part with them, both in this fall, and in the wofull effect thereof.

div.head: SECT. VIII. Of the Conſequents of the Fall: and firſt of Sinne.

p.hi: Q. WHat is the effect of this fall?

div.p: A. That which in Scripture is called theGen. 5.3. & 6.3 image of Adam, theEpheſ 4.22 old man, the Joh. 3.6 fleſh. &c.

Viz. theRom. 5.12. ſtate
1. Of ſinne:
2 By, & for ſinne of death.

p.hi: Q. What is Sinne?

div.p: A. A1. Ioh. 3.4 ſweruing from the law of God, making the ſinnerGen. 4.7 guiltie before God, and liable to the curſe of the law.

p.hi:
Q. How is mankinde in the ſtate of
ſinne, ſince the fall?

div.p:
A. Euery one, naturally deſcending from Adam, beſides the guilt of that firſt ſinne committed in Paradiſe,
1. IsPſal. 51.5 conceiued and borne in originall corruption:
2. Liuing in this world, ſinneth alſoGen. 6.5 Eſa. 48.8. actually; yea of himſelfeJer 13.23 Mat. 7.18. can doe nothing but ſinne;Tit. 1.15 neither is any thing pure vnto him.

p.hi: Q. What is originall corruption?

div.p:
A. It is the defacing of Gods image, conſiſting chiefely in wiſedome and holineſſe, and the impreſsion of the contrarie Ioh. 8.41. &c. image of Satan, calledRom. 7.7 Jam. 1.14 Concupiſcence, conſiſting
1. In an vtterRom. 7.18 diſabilitie, and& 8.7. enmitie vnto that which is good:
2. InRom. 7.14 proneneſſe vnto all manner euill.

p.hi: Q. In what part of our nature doth it abide?

div.p: A. In the whole man and euery part.

list.item: 1.Eph. 4.17 18, 19. Darkening orEſay 44.20 miſleading the vnderſtanding:
2Tit 1 15 Epheſ. 4.19 Benumming orMar. 10.20 1. Cor. 8.7 abuſing the conſcience:
3Rom. 7.23 Rom 6.10 Enthralling andEpheſ 4.18 hardening the will:
4.Iam. 4.1 Gal. 5.17 Iob 15.16. Diſturbing and diſordering the affections:

5. Finally making the bodily ſences and members, Either
1. AsMat 5.29, 30 Porters to let in ſinne, or
2. AsRo. 6.12, 13 & 3.13. &c. Inſtruments to execute it.

p.hi: Q. Is the image of God then wholly defaced in man?

div.p: A. No. For heIam. 3.9 remaineth ſtill a creature reaſonable and capable of grace, hauing the ſame parts, and faculties he had before, and in them ſome reliques of Gods image: as in the vnderſtandingJoh. 1.9. ſome light; in the conſcience ſometimesRom 2.15. right iudgement; in the will,Rom. 2.14 ſome libertie to good and euill, in naturall and ciuill actions, and freedome in all things from compulſion &c.

p.hi: Q. What is actuall ſinne?

div.p:
A. It is ſinne committedRom. 5.14 after the manner of Adams tranſgreſsion, to wit, a particular breach of Gods law,
leauing aIer. 13.23 ſtaine in the ſoule, which polluteth the ſinner, and diſpoſeth him to further euill.

p.hi: Q. How is ſuch ſinne committed?

div.p:
A. Two wayes, Viz. by
1. Omiſsion of duety required:
2. Commiſsion of euill forbidden. whether it be
1. Inwardly, in theGen. 6.5. Mat. 15.19 vnderſtanding, will, or affections, or
2. Outwardly, inEſay 3 8. word or deed.

p.hi: Q. By what degrees doe men proceed in the committing of actuall ſinne?

div.p: A. 2. Sam. 11.2 Temptation offered,Pſal. 7.14 Jam. 1.14.15 concupiſcence taking liking conceiueth, wherevpon enſueth the committing, or birth of ſinne: by cuſtome and continuance wherein, the heart finally isHeb. 3 13 hardened.

p.hi: Q. What are the different kindes of actuall ſinne?

div.p: A. They are many, but wee may reduce them to theſe fiue. Viz.

list.item: 1.Eſay 6.5 Partaking with others ſinnes:
2.Pſal 19.12 Sinnes of ignorance, or of an1. Cor. 8.7 erring conſcience.
3.Rom. 7.19. Sinnes of knowledge, through infirmitie:
4.Pſal. 19.13 & 50.21. Eccle. 8.11. Sinnes of Preſumption and obſtinacie:
5.Heb. 6.4.5, 6 & 10.29 Mar. 3.29, 30. The impardonable ſinne againſt the holy Ghoſt.

p.hi: Q. Doe all naturall men alike commit all theſe kindes of ſinne?

div.p: A. No; for thoughRom. 7.14. all are alike diſpoſed vnto all manner euill, hauing in their corrupt nature the ſeedes of euery ſinne, yet doth God, for the good of humane ſocietie, reſtraine many from notorious crimes, byRo. 13.3.4.5 feare of ſhame and puniſhment, deſire of honour and reward. &c.

p.hi: Q. How doth God employ men in this ſtate of ſinne?
A.

list.item: 1. Hee guideth them, partly by theRo 2.14.13 Joh. 1.9. light of nature, and partly, byEſay. 44.28. common graces of the Spirit, vnto many actions, profitable for humane ſocietie, and for the outward ſeruice of God.

2. HeeAct. 3.18 & 4 27.28 ouer-ruleth their euill and ſinfull actions, ſo that thereby they bring to paſſe nothing, but
what his hand and counſell had before determined for his owne glorie.

div.head: SECT. IX. Of the ſecond Conſequent of the Fall, viz. Death: and of the Leauing of Reprobates in this fearefull ſtate.

p.hi: Q. HOw is man by ſinne in the ſtate of death?

div.p: A. By the iuſt ſentence of God, deliuering himRom. 5.12 for ſinne, into the power both of corporall and eternall death; ſignified byGe. 3.22. &c expelling our parents out of Paradiſe, and debarring them of the Sacramentall tree of Life.

p.hi: Q. What are we to vnderſtand by corporall death?

div.p:
A. TheGen. 3.19 Eccl. 12.7 ſeparation of the ſoule, and bodie, with all euils that attend thereon, or make way thereto, asDeut. 28.15. &c. ſorrow ſickneſſe, ſhame, ſeruitude, penurie, &c. yea euenMal. 3.2 Pſal. 69.22 bleſsings are curſed,
andPſal. 69.22 proſperitie cauſeth ruine.

p.hi: Q. What is eternall death?

div.p: A. It is the finall2. Theſ 1.9. ſeparation of the whole man in hell for euer, from Gods fauourable preſence and fellowſhip; together with preſent2. Tim. 2.26 Epheſ. 2.2. bondage vnder Satan,Heb. 10 27 Eſay 33.14 helliſh horrors, and ſuch like fore-runners of damnation.

p.hi: Q. By what law doth God proceede in this puniſhment?

div.p: A. By the law of workes, firſt written in the heart of Adam, and vttered to his eare, in Paradiſe, and ſince more ſolemnely publiſhed, and fully expreſſed by Moſes and the Prophets, Deu. 29. • 6 Rom. 1.31. & 3 20. for the diſcouerie of ſinne, and the puniſhment due thereto.

p.hi: Q. How commeth it to paſſe, that the reprobate abide; without recouerie in this ſtate of ſinne and death?

div.p: A. BecauſeAct. 17.30 & 14.16. the Lord doth not grant vnto them the benefite of Redemption, and grace of faith and repentance vnto life, but ſuffereth them to runne on in ſinne deſeruedly vnto condemnation.

p.hi:
Q. How doth God ſuffer them ſo to
runne into condemnation?

div.p:
A. In a diuers manner:
Some reprobates dying infants;
Others of riper yeares: of which later ſort,
1. Some are not called,
2. Others called.

p.hi: Q. How doth God deale with reprobates dying infants?

div.p: A. Being once conceiued, they are in theRom. 5.14 ſtate of death, by reaſon of the ſinne of Adam imputed, and of originall corruption cleauing to their nature, wherein alſo dying, they periſh; as (for inſtance) the children of Heathen parents; for touching the2. Cor. 7.14 children of Chriſtians, we are taught to account them holy.

p.hi: Q. How doth God deale with thoſe of riper yeeres vncalled?

div.p: A. Being naturally poſſeſſedEpheſ. 4.18.19. with ignorance and vanitie, heRo. 1.26.28 giueth them vp to their owne luſts, to commit ſin without remorſe, with greedineſſe, in a reprobate mind, vntill theGen. 15.16. Pſal. 69.27. meaſure of ſinne being fulfilled, they are cut off.

p.hi:
Q. How doth God deale with ſuch reprobates
as are called?

div.p: A. He vouchſafeth them the outward Heb. 4.1, 2 2. Cor. 10.1, 2, &c. meanes of ſaluation, giuing farther to ſome of them YomoHeb. 6.4, 5. illumination, aAct. 8.13. temporarie faith, ſome outward holineſſe, & taſt of heauen; whom yet he ſuffereth to fall away, and the meanes of grace to become a2. Cor. 2.16 ſauour of death vnto them; yea ſome of thoſe doeHeb. 6.6. fall, euen to the ſinne vnpardonable.

div.head: SECT. X. Of the ſtate of Redemption by the Couenant of Grace: and of the foundation thereof, viz. the Mediator.

p.hi: Q. TO come to the ſtate of Redemption, how doth God recouer his Elect out of the ſtate of ſinne and death?

div.p: A. ByRom. 3.23, 24. the new Couenant of Grace.

p.hi: Q. What is the Couenant of Grace?

div.p: A. GodsGal. 3.21, 22. ſecond contract with mankind, after the fall, for the reſtoring of him into his fauour, & to the ſtate of happineſſe, by the meanes of a Mediator.

p.hi: Q. How doth this couenant differ from that of workes?

div.p: A. In this chiefly, that the Couenant of workes requireth of euery man, in his owne perſon, Deut. 27.26 perfect obedience, & in default, forEzek. 18, 14 Gal, 3.10.11. ſatisfaction, euerlaſting puniſhment: but the Couenant of grace Ibid. ver. 13, 14. admitteth paiment, and performance, by another, in behalfe of ſo many as receiue it. Thus this CouenantRom. 3.31 & 10.4 aboliſheth not, but is the accompliſhment, and eſtabliſhment of the former.

p.hi: Q. When was this Couenant of grace firſt plighted betweene God and man?

div.p:
A. Immediately after the fall, in Paradiſe, in thatGen. 3.15 promiſe giuen concerning the womans ſeede; God in vnſpeakeable mercy propounding the remedy, before he pronounced ſentence
of iudgement.

p.hi: Q. What are wee to conſider in this couenant of grace?

div.p:
A. Two things, to wit,
1. The foundation, which is the Mediator:
2. The application thereof, for ſaluation, vnto the Elect.

p.hi: Q. What need was there of a Mediator?

div.p: A. Betweene parties ſo diſagreeing, the one of finite nature offending, the other of infinite nature offended, the one vtterly diſabled to2. Cor. 3.5 doe any the leaſt good, orJob 9.3 ſatisfie for the leaſt ſinne, the other requiring perfect Deut. 27.26 obedience andMat. 18.34. ſatisfaction, 1. Sam. 2.25 what agreement could there be without a Mediator?

p.hi: Q. In this caſe, what was the Mediator then to doe?
A

list.item: 1. ToEſay 53.5.6 Job 33.24 pay all our debt, and ſatisfie Gods iuſtice, by a1. Tim. 2.6 price of infinite valew:
2. To purchaſe, and merit for vs GodsEpheſ. 1.6. fauour, and kingdome, by a moſtRom. 5.19 abſolute and perfect obedience.

p.hi:
Q. What an one muſt he be, that ſhould
vndertake this mediation?

div.p:
A. He muſt be
1. Man, of kinne to our nature offending, thatRom. 8.3. 1. Cor. 15.21 Heb. 2.14, 15, 16. in the ſame, he might ſatisfie; and withall,1. Joh. 3.5. perfectly iuſt without exception.
2.Act. 20.28 God, that hee might giue worth and efficacie to his ſatisfaction and obedience; and withallHeb. 2.10 the Sonne to make vs children vnto his heauenly Father.

p.hi: Q. How many Mediators are there?

div.p: A. Onely1. Tim. 2.5 one: for thoughDeut. 5.31 Gal. 4 19 other are ſo called, yet are they onely2. Cor. 5.19 Iob 33.23. Miniſters of the word, not Authors of the worke of reconciliation.

p.hi: Q. When was the Mediator giuen?
A.

list.item: 2. If the vertue and efficacie of his mediation, as ſoone as need was euenReu. 13.8 from the beginning of the world.
3. If his manifeſtation in the fleſh, in theGal. 4.4. 1. Tim. 2.6 fulneſſe of time; from whence we now reckon more then 1600. yeeares.

p.hi: Q. Who is this Mediator betweene God and man?

div.p: A. Luk. 2.11 1. Tim. 2.5 Ieſus, the ſonne of the Virgin Mary, the promiſed Meſsiah or Chriſt, whom theIoh. 1.45 & 8.56. Fathers expected, the Prophets foretold, whoſe1. Joh. 1.1 Act. 1.1 life, death, reſurrection and aſcenſion, the Euangeliſts deſcribe, whoſe1. Tim. 3.16 2. Cor. 10.4.5 word preached, vnto this day, ſubdueth the world; finally whom weeAct. 10.45 looke for from heauen to be the Iudge of quick and dead.

p.hi: Q. Is there no need of any other Mediator for vs vnto Chriſt?

div.p: A. No. For hee isIob 19.25 next of kinne, moſtHeb. 2.17. mercifull, moſt faithfull, and& 7.25 able perfectly to ſaue all thoſe that come to God through him.

div.head: SECT. XI. Of Ieſus Chriſt, his Perſon, Offices, and twofold eſtate, of Humiliation, and Exaltation.

p.hi: Q. VVHat doe the Scriptures teach vs touching Chriſt?
Q. What are wee taught touching the perſon of Chriſt?
A.

list.item:
1. His two natures Viz
The Godhead,
And manhood:
2. The hypoſtaticall, or perſoſonall vnion of both, into one Immanuel.

p.hi: Q. How How is the Godhead of Chriſt proued?

div.p:
A. Not onely by aboundantEſay 7.14 & 9.6. &c. teſtimonies of ſcripture, but alſo by his miracles, eſpecially theRom. 1.4 raiſing of himſelfe from death, together with theAct 5.39 continuance and conqueſt of the Goſpell, and thatZech. 4 ••
not by carnall power or policie, but onely by the power of his ſpirit, andReu. 12.11 patient ſuffering of his Saints.

p.hi: Q. How doth it appeare that Chriſt was man?

div.p: A. Beſides manifoldGen. 3 15 1. Tim. 2.5. &c. predictions, and cleare teſtimonies, it is aboundantly proued by plentifull experiments, eſpecially by his1. Pet. 3.18 Heb. 2.14 partaking of humane infirmities, and ſuffering of death.

p.hi: Q. Being very man, how could hee be without ſinne?

div.p: A. Becauſe he was not begotten, after the ordinarie courſe, by man, butLu. 1.34.35 formed of the onely ſubſtance of the Virgin, and that ſubſtance, in the conception, ſanctified by the holy Ghoſt.

p.hi: Q. What is the perſonall vnion of theſe two natures?

div.p: A. TheIoh. 1.14 Heb. 2.16 aſſuming of the humane nature (hauing no ſubſiſtence in it ſelfe) into the perſon of the Sonne of God, and in that perſon vniting it to the Godhead; ſo making one Chriſt,Mat. 1.2 3 God and man.

p.hi: Q. What is the office of Chriſt?

div.p:
A. The1. Tim. 2.5 Mediator-ſhip, which being one, hath yet three denominations from three ſeuerall functions: Viz.
Propheticall
Prieſtly
Kingly.

p.hi: Q. What is his Prophetical Office?

div.p: A. The office ofEſay 61.1 Mat. 23.8.10. inſtructing his Church: which hee did and doth performe two waies viz.

list.item:
1. Outwardly, asMath. 23.37 1. Pet. 3.19. before his incarnation
by the Prophets, Prieſts, and Scribes of the Old Teſtament, and in the dayes of his fleſh in hisHeb. 2.3 owne perſon, as aRom. 15.8 Miniſter of the Circumciſion, (but with theMat 7.29 authoritie of the Law-giuer) ſo ſince vnto the worlds end2. Cor. 4.6 & 5.19, 20 by his Apoſtles, and Miniſters, Epheſ. 4.11 called and fitted by him for that purpoſe:
2. Inwardly by theLuk. 24.49. Act. 16 14 ioynt operation of his holy ſpirit.

p.hi: Q. What is the Prieſtly function of Chriſt?

div.p: A. It is that whereby heeHeb. 5.1, 5. &c. appeaſeth and reconcileth God to his Elect.

list.item: 1. Performing for them abſoluteRom. 5.19 obediēce to the whole law of God.
2. Offering himſelfe vnto his Father,2. Cor. 5.21 a ſacrifice propitiatorie for all their ſinnes.
3.Heb 9.24 1. Ioh. 2.1, 2 Rom. 8.34 Heb. 12.24 Appearing euer at the right hand of God to make interceſsion for them.

p.hi: Q. What is the kingly office of Chriſt?

div.p:
A. It is the exerciſe of thatPſal. 110.1 power giuen him by God ouer all, andMat. 28. • 8 Pſal. 2.8. &c. poſſeſsion of all, for theEſay 9 7. ſpirituall gouernement,
and ſaluation of his Elect, and for theEſay 9.7. deſtruction of his & their enemies.

p.hi: Q. In what ſtate did Chriſt God and man performe this threefold office?

div.p:
A. In a two-fold eſtate. Viz. of
1. Humiliation and
2. Exaltation.

p.hi: Q. What was his ſtate of humiliation?

div.p: A. It was thePſal. 45.5 baſe condition of a ſeruant whereto hee humbled himſelfe from his conception to his croſſe, and ſo vntill the time of his reſurrection.

p.hi: Q. What is his eſtate of Exaltation?

div.p: A. HisPhil. 2.7.8 glorious condition, beginning at the inſtant of hisPhil 2.9 Heb. 2.9 reſurrection, and comprehending hisAct. 2.24 Aſcenſion, Epheſ. 4.8 ſitting at the right hand of God, and1. Pet. 3.22 ſecond comming in glorie to iudge the world.Ma. 15.31

div.head: SECT. XII. Of the Application of the Couenant of Grace, and firſt of our vnion with the perſon of Chriſt.
div.p: Q. HItherto of the Foundation of the Couenant of Grace, viz. the Mediator: what is the Application of it?
A. The communicating thereof for ſaluation to euery one of Gods Elect, giuing himHeb 3.14 part in Chriſt the Mediator, and all his benefits.
Q. What part hath euery Elect in Chriſt hereby?

p.hi: A.

list.item: 1. Vniō with Chriſts perſon.
2. Communion.

div.p: Q. How are the Elect vnited to Chriſt his perſon?

A. They are incorporated, & madeEph. 5.30 members of the myſtical body whereof Chriſt is head; which the Scripture figureth, as by other reſemblances,
ſo eſpecially vnder the Epheſ. 5.2. Item Cautic. the whole ho • ke. ſimilitude of mariage.

p.hi: Q. How may we conceiue of this our mariage with Chriſt?

div.p:
A. We are to conceiue therein as in outward mariage,
1. The conſent of parents and parties.
2. The maner of coniunction.

p.hi: Q. What conſent of parents is there in this mariage?

div.p:
A. Only Gods donation, who being the alone parent of both parties (as in theGen. 2.22. mariage of the firſt Adam) giueth,
1.Iohn 3 16. Iohn 17.6. Chriſt to vs, as a Sauiour.
2.Heb. 2.13. Vs to Chriſt, as a people to be ſaued.

p.hi: Q. What conſent of parties is there?
A.

list.item: 1. Chriſt conſenteth to take vs as his own ſpouſe, which he witneſſed eſpecially by takingHeb. 2.14. our fleſh vpon him, that he might be ourMatt. 1.23. Immanuel, or God with vs.

2. We beingIohn 6.44. drawne of God, and2. Cor. 11.2 prepared by the friends
of the Bridegroome, doCant. 7.10. conſent to take Chriſt as our Lord and Husband, as wee profeſſe by taking hisEſay 44.5. name andMat. 11.29. yoke vpon vs.

p.hi: Q. What is the maner of this our coniunction?

div.p:
A. Mysticall, that is to ſay:
Real, in reſpect of the things conioined, our very nature, body and ſoule, being coupled to the body and ſoule of Chriſt, (ſo that we areEphe. 5.30 members of his body, of his fleſh and of his bones) and therby alſo to the1. Cor. 1.30 diuine nature: yet not corporall, but
Spirituall, in regard of the means, whereby this coniunction is wrought.

p.hi: Q. What are the meanes of this ſpirituall coniunction?

div.p:
A. On Chriſts part, his holy1. Ioh. 4.15. Rom. 8.9. Spirit, Gal. 4.6. 1. Iohn 3.24. & 4.13. giuen by him vnto euerie member of his body, in the very moment of regeneration, as theGal 5.25. 1. Cor. 15 45. ſoule of ſpirituall life, and fountaine of ſupernaturall grace; in which reſpect,1. Cor. 6.17 he that is ioyned
to the Lord, is ſaid to be one ſpirit.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſpirit of Chriſt?

div.p: A. The holy1 Cor. 3.16 Ghoſt, truly reſiding, and powerfullyRom. 5.5. working in all thoſe that are Chriſts,Rom. 8.2. deriued vnto them from him, and1. Cor. 12.13 Eph 2.18. & 4.4. knitting them inſeparably vnto him.

p.hi: Q. Is the Holy Ghoſt giuen to none, but ſuch as are thus ioined vnto Chriſt?

div.p:
A. The Holy Ghoſt is conſidered three waies;
1. As the Author of all excellencie, euen in common gifts of nature and reaſon, asJud. 14.6. ſtrength and courage,Exod. 31.3 Arts and Sciences,1. Sam. 11.6 Policie and Gouernement, &c. In which ſenſe he is giuen to many that neuer heard of Chriſt.
2. As the Author of1. Cor. 12.1.4. ſpirituall gifts, ſo called, becauſe being ſanctified, they are meanes of edification, as the power of working miracles, healing, languages, &c. yea aHeb. 6.4 5. taſte of the heauenly gift, and of the good word of God, and of the powers of the world to come. In which ſence, he is giuen to ſundry reprobates, that are
called, as hath been ſhewed.
3. As the Author of the perpetuall, effectuall, andIoh. 6.63. vitall influence of ſauing grace from Chriſt the head, to euery true member of his body. In which ſence,Ioh. 14.17 the world cannot receiue or know him, but he is beſtowed on the1. Pet. 1.2. Elect only, and thoſe truly regenerated, and conuerted vnto the Lord.

p.hi: Q. But on our parts, what meanes is there of this coniunction?

div.p:
A. Only faith; which yet isEph. 2.8. not of our ſelues, but the gift of God, and of all other the firſt, and moſt generall effect and inſtrument of the2. Cor. 4.13. Gal. 5 5. ſpirit of Chriſt,Eph. 3.16.17 diſpoſing and inabling vs, ſo to imbrace and cleaue vnto him, as
1. ToRom. 5.2. receiue from God by him, whatſoeuer benefits and graces.
2. ToCol 2.7. Gal. 5.6 returne to God in him, all holy and thankful obedience.

div.head: SECT. XIII. Of our Communion with Chriſt, in regard of his Propheticall office, by the Reuelation of the Couenant of Grace; and of the firſt outward meanes of Reuelation; viz. the Goſpell preached.

p.hi: Q. VVHat is our communion with Chriſt?

div.p: A. It is our participation with him in the benefits, flowing from his ſeueral offices. For being made one with him, we are therebyReu. 2.28. Col. 2.10. poſſeſſed of all things that are his, as the wife of the wealth of her husband, theJohn 15.5. branch of the ſap of the roote, and theEph. 4.15, 16. members of ſenſe and motion from the head. In which regard the whole Church is called alſo1. Co. 12.12. Galat. 3.16. Chriſt, and the ſeuerall membersActs 11.26. Chriſtians.

p.hi:
Q. What are the benefits which wee
partake with Chriſt flowing from his offices?

div.p: A. They are the fruits of his Propheticall, Prieſtly, & Kingly functions, whereby, as he is1. Cor. 1.30 made to vs of God, wiſdome, righteouſneſſe, ſanctification, and redemption, ſo we alſo by him after a ſort, becomeAct. 2.17.18 Prophets, 1. Pet. 2.9. Reuel. 5.10, Prieſts and Kings.

p.hi: Q. What fruit receiue we by the Propheticall function of Chriſt, to make vs Prophets?

div.p: A. TheMat. 11.27. & 16.17. John 14.21. Pſal. 25 14. Reuelation of Gods couenant of grace, whereby Chriſt is made vnto vs of God, wiſdome, and we2. Tim. 3.15 1. Iohn 5.20 wiſe for our owne and others ſaluation.

p.hi: Q. Touching this reuelation, what are we to conſider?

div.p:
A. Three things, viz. the
Meanes whereby, it is imparted.
Maner how, it is imparted.
Subiects to whom, it is imparted.

p.hi: Q. What are the meanes whereby God reuealeth his couenant?

div.p:
A. They are of two ſorts:
1. outward, viz.
1. the Word, and
2. the Sacraments.
2. inward.

p.hi: Q. What is here meant by the Word, the firſt outward meanes?

div.p: A. The Goſpell preached, called theRom. 10.8. word of faith, and of Act. 20.32 grace; containing (Pro. 3.18 as a ſecond tree of life) the promiſe of Ioh. 6.68. 2. Tim. 1.10. life and ſaluation, by Chriſt the Mediator, which is the ſubſtance of the Couenant of grace.

p.hi: Q. In what part of the Scripture is the Goſpell contained?

div.p: A. Heb. 13 8. Rom. 10.6 Both in the old and the new Teſtament: in the former, more ſparingly and darkly, vnderGen. 3.15. & 49 10 obſcure promiſes andHeb. 10 1. ſhadowes of legall ceremonies, proper to the Iewes; but in the latter, moſtRom. 16.25 26 plainly and plentifully, in the cleere declaration both of the truth and fruit of Chriſt, already exhibited to all nations. In which regard eſpecially, it is termed aHeb. 9.15. & 8.8. &c. new Couenant or Teſtament.

p.hi: Q. To what part of Gods word is the Goſpell oppoſed?

div.p:
A. To the LaW, which containing theGal. 3.10 tenor of the fore-mentioned Couenant of works, is notwithſtanding this latter Couenant of grace, often
vrged in theRom. 1.18. Deut. 27.26. Ez. 18 4, 5. &c Leuit. 18.5. Scriptures, eſpecially of the old Teſtament.

p.hi: Q. What vſe is there of the Law, the Goſpell being publiſhed?

div.p:
A. Not as of aGal. 1.12. cauſe, properly working faith and grace, (for that belongeth only to theAct. 20.24. Epheſ. 1.13. Goſpell) but yet as of a needfull preparatiue thereunto, that beingRom. 8.15. humbled by the Law, ſeeing our ſelues notGal. 3.11. capable of ſaluation by the couenant of works, we may be forced toMatt. 11.28.
• lie to the remedy; offered vnto vs in the grace of the Goſpell.

p.hi: Q. What need is there of the preaching of the Goſpell, ſeeing we may reade it?

div.p: A. Becauſe, though1 Cor. 1.21 fooliſhneſſe to the world, it is theDeu. 18.17, &c. ordinance of God, and hisRom. 1.16. power to ſaluation: and wee haue need to haue the word not only propounded in groſſe, but alſoRom. 10.14 Gal. 3.2. Act. 8.30.31. 2 Tim. 2.15. expounded, diuided, and applied by the miniſtry, for that end by Chriſt ordained.

div.head: SECT. XIIII. Of the ſecond outward meanes, viz. the Sacraments.

p.hi: Q. TO proceed to the other outward meanes: What are Sacraments?

div.p: A. Rom. 4.11. Seales annexed1. Cor. 21.23 by God, to the word of the Couenant of Grace, to inſtruct, aſſure, &Gal. 3.27. poſſeſſe vs of our part in Chriſt, and his benefits, & to binde vs in all thankfull obedience vnto God in him.

p.hi: Q. How doth God by the Sacraments aſſure vs of his mercies in Chriſt?

div.p: A. By exhibiting to the worthy receiuer, by ſuch outward ſignes, whether elements, or actions, as himſelfe for reliefe of our weaknes hath preſcribed, whole 1. Cor. 10.4 Chriſt, God and man, with all his benefits; in 2. Cor. 1.20. whom all the promiſes of God are, Yea and Amen.

p.hi: Q. How do they binde vs vnto God?

div.p:
A. We receiuing them as pledges
of his infinite loue in Chriſt, doe thereby profeſſe our ſeluesCol. 2.6, 7. bound to expreſſe our thankfulnes, by all duties to his Maieſtie; and for his ſakeEph. 4.3, 4, 5 one to another.

p.hi: Q. What Sacraments be there of the Couenant of Grace?

div.p:
A. They be of two ſorts: viz.
1. Some of the old Teſtament, before Chriſts comming.
2. Other of the new, vnder Chriſt.

p.hi: Q. What Sacraments were there of the old Testament?

div.p: A. Beſides diuers1. Pet. 3.20, 21. 1. Cor. 10 1, 2, 3, 4. extraordinarily giuen, & ſeruing but for a ſeaſon, there were two of ordinary and perpetuall vſe, from their inſtitution vntill the comming of Chriſt, (to which thoſe other may be referred) viz.

list.item: 1.Gen. 17.10, &c. Deut. 30.6. Circumciſion, for entrance into the Couenant.
2.Exod. 12.3, &c. 1. Cor. 5.7. The Paſſeouer, for continuance and confirmation therein.

p.hi: Q. What Sacraments be there of the new Testament?

div.p:
A. Onely two: to wit,
1. Baptiſme, ſucceeding in the place of Circumciſion.
2. The Supper of the Lord, anſwering to the Paſſeouer.

p.hi: Q. How doe theſe Sacraments of the new Testament differ from thoſe of the old?

div.p:
A. In reſpect,
Rom. 4.11. 1. Cor. 10.2.3, 4.Not of the Author, God, the ſubſtance, Chriſt, or the receiuers, the people of God, which are in both the ſame:
But ofMat. 28.19, 20. continuance, 1. Cor. 11.26 euidence, eaſie performance, and efficacie: in all which,2. Cor. 3.9. theſe of the new Teſtament haue great preeminence.

div.head: SECT. XV. Of Baptiſme.

p.hi: Q. VVHat is Baptiſme?

div.p:
A. The former Sacrament of the new Teſtament, by theEph 5.26 waſhing of water, repreſenting the powerfull1 Cor 6.11. Heb. 10.22. waſhing of the bloud, and
ſpirit of Chriſt; and ſo ſealing ourJohn 3.5. Tit. 3.5. new birth, and entrance into the Couenant of grace.

p.hi: Q. How was this Sacrament ordained and brought into the Church, in the place of Circumciſion?

div.p: A. At theIohn 1.33. commandement of God, by the miniſtery firſt ofMatth. 3.1. Iohn, therefore called the Baptiſt: after, ſanctified and confirmed by our Sauiour Chriſt himſelfe, beingMatt. 3.13. baptized by Iohn, and giuingMat. 28.18. commiſsion to his Apostles and Ministers, to continue the ſame in his Church vnto the end.

p.hi: Q. What are the neceſſary and eſſentiall parts of this Sacrament?

div.p: A. Two: viz.

list.item: 1. The outward element ofIohn 1.31. water, together with the actiō ofEph. 5.26. Act. 8.36, &c. & 2.41. waſhing, that is, dipping or ſprinkling the party baptized,Mat. 28.19. In the name of the Father, the Sonne, and the holy Ghoſt.
2. The ſpiritual thing ſignified, viz. theHeb. • .14. bloud &1. Cor 6.11. ſpirit of Chriſt, waſhing away both theAct. 2.38. guilt andEze. 36.25 filthineſſe of ſinne.

p.hi: Q. Doth this ſpiritual waſhing alwaies accompany the outward action?

div.p: A. No: for howſoeuer God for his part, doe euerEzek. 24.13 offer it at the preſent vnto all, yet doe the1. Pet. 1.2 Elect onely effectually partake the ſpirituall benefit; and thatGal. 3.27. then firſt, when by the ſpirit and faith they are vnited vnto Chriſt: from which time, baptiſme once receiued, remaineth aZech. 13.1. fountain alwaies open for ſinne and for vncleanneſſe.

p.hi: Q. How farre forth doth Baptiſme cleanſe the elect from ſinne?

div.p: A. From1. Cor. 6.9.10, 11. 1. John 1.7. Pſal. 51 7. all ſins, as well actuall as originall, as wel committed after Baptiſme, as before: and thatEſay 1.18. perfectly, in reſpect of the guilt, althoughIoh. 13.10 Pſal. 51.2. imperfectly, & by degrees, in reſpect of the pollution and power of ſinne.

p.hi: Q. Who are to be admitted to this Sacrament?

div.p:
A. Whoſoeuer are outwardly comprehended in the Couenant: whether th y be,
1. of riper yearesActs 8.37. cōuerted to the profeſsion of the faith: or,
2.1 Cor. 7.14 children borne of Chriſtian parents.

div.head: SECT. XVI. Of the Lords Supper.

p.hi: Q. VVHat is the Lords Supper?

div.p: A It is the other Sacrament of the new Teſtament, wherein God by the ſignes of bread and wine, ſignifieth, ſealeth, and exhibiteth to euery faithfull receiuer, the body and bloud of Chriſt for his ſpirituall nouriſhment and growth in Chriſt, & ſo confirmeth him in the Couenant of Grace.

p.hi: Q. How was this Sacrament inſtituted in ſtead of the Paſſeouer?

div.p: A. Our Lord Ieſus Chriſt1. Cor. 11.23 in the night that he was betraied, Matth. 26.26, &c. immediatly after hee had eaten the Paſſeouer with his Diſciples, did both himſelfe with them celebrate this holy Sacrament, and withall1. Cor. 11.24, 25, 26. giue charge for continuance of the ſame in the Church vntill his ſecond comming: in which regard it is called the 1. Cor. 11.20. Lords Supper.

p.hi: Q. What are the eſſentiall parts of this Sacrament?

div.p:
A. As of all other Sacraments, two: to wit,
1. The outward ſignes, viz. theMat. 26.26, 27. elemēts of bread & wine, together with the actions of bleſsing & diſtributing, taking & communicating, according to our Sauiours firſt inſtitution.
2. The ſpiritualIbid. things ſignified, viz. the body & bloud of Chriſt, ſanctified andIoh. 6.50, 51 giuen vs by God, and by faith receiued of vs, for the nouriſhing and preſeruing of our ſoules and bodies vnto eternall life.

p.hi: Q. Is Chriſts body and bloud, together with the outward elements, receiued of all Communicants?

div.p: A. No: for howſoeuer they beMat. 26.26. offred by God to all, yet are they receiued by ſuch alone, as haue the hand of faith to lay hold on Chriſt. As for thoſe that come without faith, they receiue1. Cor. 11.27. onely the outward elements, and that vntoVerſ. 29. condemnation.

p.hi: Q. Who are to be partakers of this Sacrament?

div.p:
A. All baptized, who are of yeeres & ſound iudgement to diſcerne the Lords body, ought to repaire to this Sacrament: but thoſe onely come worthily,
who profeſsing the true faith, haue duly1. Cor. 11.28 examined & prepared thēſelues.

p.hi: Q. How ought euery Chriſtian comming to this Sacramēt, to examin & prepare himſelfe that he may come worthily?

div.p: A. By due ſearch & triall of himſelf, whether he haue in him the conditions, by God required in worthy Communicants, viz.

list.item: 2. Cor. 13.5. 1. Tim. 1.15. Faith, groūded vpō knowledge both of Gods will in generall, & this holy Sacrament in particular.
Heb. 10.22. Iames 48. Repentāce of ſins paſt, attēded with trueZech. 12.10. l • ue of God, & of his 1. Cor. 16.14. brethren.

p.hi: Q. How ought euery Chriſtian thus prepared, to demeane himſelfe in receiuing, and after?
A.

list.item: 1. In the preſent actiō, with reuerēce, intention & thankſgiuing, 1. Cor. 11.26. cōmemorating the Lords death, for the cō fort & refreſhing of his ſoul, &Rom. 12.1. ofring vp himſelfe ſoule & body as a ſacrifice of thanks: in which regard it is called the Euchariſt.

2. Afterward, cōtinually indeuoring to finde anCol. 2.6, 7. increaſe of his faith in Chriſt, loue to God & all his ſaints,
power to ſubdue ſinne, and practiſe obedience, with all other2. Pet. 3.18 ſauing and ſanctifying graces.

div.head: SECT. XVII. Of the inward meanes of reuealing the Couenant of Grace, viz. the Spirit, and Faith.

p.hi: Q. VVHat are the inward meanes whereby God reuealeth his Couenant of Grace?

div.p:
A. They are 2. Viz.
1. The Spirit.
2. Faith.

p.hi: Q. What is here meant by the Spirit?

div.p: A. A ſpeciall effect of the Spirit of Chriſt before-mentioned, dwelling in our hearts, teſtifying, on Gods part, his free loue, and gracious purpoſe touching our ſaluation inPſal. 35.3 particular, bearing Rom. 8.16 witneſſe with our ſpirits that we are, in Chriſt, his Children, and hee our Father, & withall guiding vs to thePſal. 16.7 Ioh. 14.26 knowledge of the whole will of God, reuealed in his word; called therefore theEpheſ. 1.17 ſpirit of wiſedome or Reuelation.

p.hi:
Q. Doth the Spirit alwaies witneſſe
the loue of God vnto vs?

div.p: A. The witneſſe of the ſpirit isRom. 5.5. Epheſ. 2.13.14. continuall, yet it isPſal. 51.10 & ver. 7.8 not alwaies with like feeling and comfort apprehended, becauſe neither are our hearts alwaies alike purged, humbled and enlarged to receiue it, nor the ſweet promiſes of the Goſpell (Eſay 59.21. whereon the ſpirit groundeth this teſtimonie) with like care attended on, and meditated.

p.hi: Q. How may wee diſcerne betweene the perſwaſion of Gods Spirit, and the preſumption of our owne hearts?

div.p:
A. Among other, by theſe three differences. Viz. that
1. Preſumption giuethDeu. 29.19 libertie to continue in ſinne, but Gods ſpiritIoh. 16.8 rebuketh vs for euery ſinne.
2. PreſumptionJer 3.4, 5 relyeth on Gods loue; not louing him, but Gods ſpirit maketh vsCant. 8.6. 1. Ioh. 4.19 loue him becauſe hee hath loued vs firſt.
3. Proſumptiō is ioined with ſelf-loue, but Gods ſpirit, reuealing his mercy to vs, maketh vsIob 42.5, 6. Ezek. 16.63. & 36.31 abhor our ſelues.

p.hi: Q. What meane you here by Faith?

div.p:
A. That ſpeciall act of faith, whereby
we1. Ioh. 5.10. giue credit to the report of the word and ſpirit of Chriſt, touching our ſaluation in particular, and ſoIoh. 3.33 ſet to our ſeale that God is true.

p.hi: Q. How are we brought to giue credit to the word and ſpirit?

div.p: A. By theRom. 10.17. ministerie of the ſame word, with the Sacraments annexed, and the power of the ſame ſpirit; by which onely meanes God worketh, and ſetteth on worke, this grace of faith, in the hearts of his Children, from the generall promiſes of the Goſpell,1. Tim. 1.15. Ioh. 20.28 particularly, andIob 19.25 1. Pet. 1.13. vndoubtedly to conclude their owne ſaluation.

p.hi: Q. Can all that haue faith, particularly, and vndoubtedly reſolue of their ſaluation?
A.

list.item: 1. Many for a time reſt ſecure in a flirting perſwaſion, which may appeare not to be true faith, in that itAct. 15.9 purgeth not the heart.

2. The Elect hauing true faith, Luk. 22.32 Rom. 11.29 neuer failing, and working in them ſound aſſurance, muſt yet ordinarily Mar 9.24 Luc. 17.5 ſtriue againſt doubting, and mayPſal. 51.12 & 31 22. & 42.5. at times, (falling into ſin, or ſome
ſpirituall affliction) looſe for a ſeaſon, the ioy and feeling of this aſſurance.

div.head: SECT. XVIII. Of the manner of reuealing the Couenant of Grace, viz. Vocation.

p.hi: Q. THus much of the meanes: now what is the manner of reuealing the Couenant of Grace?

div.p: A. It isRom. 8.30 Heb. 3.1. Vocation, or Calling; when God by the meanes aforeſaid, acquainting men with his gracious purpoſe of ſaluation by Chriſt,Hoſ. 2.14 inuiteth them to come vnto him.

p.hi: Q. Are there not different kindes of Calling?

div.p: A. Yes: there is two fold calling.

list.item:
1. Effectuall, peculiar to thoſe few that are Elect, whereby God (become in Chriſt their Father) doth not onely outwardly by his word inuite, butGen. 9.27 Pſal. 65.4 & 25.14 Ioel. 2.32 Acts 2.39 inwardly alſo & powerfully, by his ſpirit, allure and winne
their hearts to cleaue to him inſeparably vnto ſaluation.
2.Eſay 48.12 Outward onely; and ineffectuall, wherebyMat. 22.14 many are called, who are not choſen; as hath been ſhewed.

p.hi: Q. How doth this latter differ from the former calling?

div.p: A. Howſoeuer wee are to1. Cor. 1.2 iudge charitably of all outwardly called, becauſe who among them are alſo inwardly called is onely2. Tim. 2.19 knowne to God; yet doth this outward calling differ from the former.

list.item: 1. In that it is wrought onely byHeb. 4.2. outward meanes and common illumination without theIud. v. 19. ſpirit of regeneration, or any portion ofLuk. 8.13 ſauing faith.

2. In that they are admitted onely to an outward andAct. 8.13 Rom. 9.4.5 temporarie league of formall profeſſion,1. Ioh. 2.19. 1. Cor. 1.8.9 not to that entire fellowſhip with Chriſt, required vnto ſaluation.

div.head: SECT. XIX. Of the Subiects, to whom the Couenant of Grace is reuealed, viz. the Church.

p.hi: Q. TO come to the third thing propounded touching this Reuelation, to whom doth God reueale his Couenant of Grace?

div.p: A. Ioh 14.22 & 17.9 Mat. 11.25 1. Cor. 2 8 &c. Not to the world, but to his Church called out of the world.

p.hi: Q. What meane you by the Church?

div.p: A. The whole number of Gods Elect, effectually called into Ephe. 5.32 fellowſhip with Christ, by the meanes, and in the manner formerly mentioned; which wee profeſſe to beleeue vnder the title of the holy Catholike Church.

p.hi: Q. Where is this holy Catholike Church?
A.

list.item:
Part already in heauenHeb. 12.13. Reu. 7.14. &c. triumphant in their Maſters ioy,Reu. 6.7. waiting for the fulfilling of the number of their fellow members, and their owne conſummation
in perfect bliſſe:
Part as yetReu. 1.9. & 12.11. militant on earth in the ſeruice & warrefare of their Lord, expecting in due time to be alſo2. Tim. 4.7, 8 crowned with victory, and triumph in glory.

p.hi: Q. Who are true members of the Church militant on earth?

div.p: A. Thoſe alone, who, asEphe. 1.22, 23. Col. 1.18 liuing members of the myſticall bodie, are, by the ſpirit and faithCol 3.3. Pſal. 83.3. ſccretly, and inſeparably conioined vnto Chriſt their head; in which reſpect the true militant Church is both inuiſible, andMat. 16.18 inuincible.

p.hi: Q. But are none to be accounted members of this Church, but ſuch as are ſo inſeparably vnited vnto Chriſt?

div.p:
A. Truely, and properly 1. Joh. 2 19 none other: howbeit, becauſe God vſeth outward meanes, with the inward, for the gathering of his Saints, and calleth, them as well toAct. 2 42. Cant. 1.7 outward profeſsion among themſelues, as to inward fellowſhip with his Sonne, whereby the Church becommeth viſible; hence it commeth, that ſo many asAct. 8.13 partaking
the outward meanes, doe ioyne with theſe in league of viſible profeſſion, are therefore, in humane iudgement, accounted members of the true church, and1. Cor. 1.2. Saints by calling; vntill the Lord (who onely knoweth who are his) doe make knowne the contrarie. As wee are taught in theMat. 13, 24.47. &c. parables of the tares, the drawnet, &c.

p.hi: Q. Hath Chriſt then his Church viſible vpon earth?

div.p: A. Yea, throughout the world, in the particularRom. 3.3 congregations of Chriſtians, called to the profeſſion of the true faith & obedience of the Goſpel. In whichRom. 11.5 viſible aſſemblies, and not elſe-where, the true members of the Church inuiſible, on earth, are to bee found; and vnto which therefore all that ſeeke ſaluation muſt gladlyEſay 60.4. ioyne themſelues.

p.hi: Q. Are we to acknowledge one viſible Church, or many?

div.p:
A. Ephe. 4.4. &c. Cant. 6.8 Gal. 3.28. One alone, as there is but one Lord, one Spirit, one Faith, and one Baptiſme: notwithſtanding the parts of this one Church may bee diſtinguiſhed
in reſpect
1. Of time, as the ChurchesHeb. 13.8 before Chriſt, and ſince: Primitiue and preſent reformed: &c.
2. Of place, as the Churches of Iudea, Aſia, England, France, Germanie, &c. which all, beeing1. Tim. 3.15 one, yet (as the ſea) receiue ſeuerall names from the countries where through they paſſe, and areReu. 1.11 accounted as ſo many ſeuerall Churches.

p.hi: Q. Muſt not then this one viſible Church haue one viſible head here on earth?

div.p: A. No: For it is viſible not in the whole, but in the parts, whereto the circumſtances of time, and place for opportunitie of viſible profeſſion, do agree: and therefore, as Catholike, or vniuerſall, the Church hath no head, butEpheſ. 1.22.23. Chriſt alone, alwaiesMat 28.20 preſent by his word and ſpirit, to giueGal. 2.20 life, ſenſe, and motion to euery member.

p.hi: Q. Is the Church alwaies viſible in her parts?

div.p:
A. Chriſt hath, andRom. 11.1, 2, 3, 4. euer had, from the beginning, his Church viſible
vpon earth, that is, ſome companies of beleeuers making profeſsion of the ſame common faith; howbeit many times by perſecution forced toReu. 12.14. hide themſelues from the eye of the world, & happily by the rage of the enemie, ſo ſcattered, that (as in the1. Kin. 19, 10 daies of Elias) they can hardly be knowne, or haue entercourſe betweene themſelues.

p.hi: Q. What are the infallible notes, wherby to diſcerne a true viſible Church, with which we may ſafely ioyne?

div.p:
A. The ſame, and no other, which are the onely outward meanes, ordained by God, for the calling and gathering of his Saints, and which giue being to a Church, prouing it to bee a1. Tim. 3.15 pillar of truth, viz. theMat. 28.19, 20. word preached, and Sacraments adminiſtred, according to the commandement of Chriſt our Sauiour; as for other notes, they are either
1. Accidentall, and in great part ſeparable, or
2. Vtterly impertinent, & forged, for the vpholding of the Romiſh ſynagogue.

p.hi: Q. May not ſuch a Church erre, and bee corrupted, or fall, and become no Church?
A.

list.item: 1. The Church conſidered in her true members, canMat. 16.18. Phil. 1.6 1. Theſ. 5.24. neuer vtterly fall; howſoeuerCant. 1.4 no congregation bee ſo pure, that it may be ſaid at any time to be free from all corruption, or ſo conſtant, but that, at times, it may be ſhaken, in the very foundation of truth: as may appeare by the churches of1. Cor. 15.12.33 Corinth, Gal. 3.1. &c Galatia &c.

2. Being conſidered with reſpect to the place, God doth not alwaies continue a ſucceſsion of true beleeuers within the ſame limits and borders; and hence we ſay, that diuers Churches are fallen, as thoſe of Aſia, &c. neither is any place ſo priuiledged, but that for ſinne theReu. 2.5 Candleſticke may in time bee thence remoued.

p.hi: Q. How may wee iudge of a Church corrupt, or ceaſing to be a Church?
A.

list.item: 1. Where God, vtterlyAct. 13.46 taking away the meanes of his word and worſhip, hath apparently giuen theEſay 50.1. bill of diuorce, there are wee not to acknowledge any Church at all: as at this day in Ieruſalem, once the holy Citie.

2. But where theſe meanes are yet continued, wee are to acknowledge aReu. 2.1 • , 13 Church of Chriſt, howſoeuer more or leſſe corrupt, according to the greater, or leſſe abuſe of Gods word and worſhip.

p.hi: Q. Since Churches may be ſo diuerſly corrupted, from which, and how farre are we to ſeparate?

div.p:
A. From Churches mortally ſicke ofTit 3.10, 11 hereſie, orReu. 18.4 idolatry, as it were of a contagious plague or leproſie, wee are to ſeparate; Howbeit, whiles there is yet any life, rather from the ſcab, or ſore, then from the bodie: that is, from the preuailing faction, maintaining fundamentall errours, and forcing to idolatrous worſhip. Such is our
ſeparation from the preſent Church of Rome, not from ſuch therein, who, either, meaning well in generall, areReu. 2.24. ignorant of the depth of Satan, or1 •• n. 19.18 ſecretly diſſent from thoſe damnable corruptions; with whom, as a bodie yet retaining life, wee deſire toPhil. 1.18 ioyne, ſo farre, as wee may with ſafety from the foreſaid contagion.

p.hi: Q. Are wee to continue fellowſhip with all other Churches, not ſo deadly and dangerouſly corrupt?

div.p: A. From Churches holding the foundation, in ſubſtance of faith and worſhip, though otherwiſe not free from blemiſh, wee are1. K • n. 15.14 & 2 • .43 not to ſeparate, farther then in diſlike and refuſall of that wherein they doe apparently ſeparate from Chriſt, in reſpect either of maners, doctrine, or forme of publique worſhip.

p.hi: Q. To conclude touching the Church, what diſtinction is there of the particular members?
A.

list.item:
1. Generally, they are all theEpheſ. 3 15 familie of Chriſt, andIoh. 10.2, 3, 4. ſheepe of
his flocke, hearing his voice, and following him.

2. More ſpecially out of theſe Chriſt, the chiefe Prince and Shepheard, hath inſtituted, as guides vnto reſt,
1.1. Cor. 12 28 Miniſters, called Paſtors, Joh. 21.15. 1. Pet. 5.2 to feede his flocke, with the wholeſome foode of the word and Sacraments.
2. Princes and Magiſtrates, to ſee to the wayes of his houſhold, that all, both2. Chro. 35.3. &c. & 34. ver. 32, 33 Miniſters and people, doe their office and dutie, euen in things concerning God.

div.head: SECT. XX. Of our Communion with Chriſt in regard of his Prieſtly office, viz. our Juſtification.

p.hi:
Q. THus much of the benefit, flowing vnto vs from the Propheticall
Office of Chriſt, what fruit haue we of his Priestly function?

div.p: A. OurRom. 3.25 2. Cor. 5.19 Reconciliation with GOD, through him, made vnto vs of God1. Cor. 1.30 righteouſneſſe, whereby alone we are perfectlyRo. 8.33, 34 iuſtified (i.) acquitted & accounted iuſt in the ſight of God.

p.hi: Q. How doth Chriſt become righteouſneſſe vnto vs, for iuſtification in the ſight of God?

div.p: A. Onely by Gods free and graciousRo. 5.18, 19 imputation of the righteouſnes of Chriſt vnto vs,Phil. 3.9 in which, as in the garment of our elder Brother, wee are accepted, and obtaine the bleſsing from him, our heauenly Father.

p.hi: Q. What righteouſneſſe of Chriſt is it, that God imputeth to vs?

div.p:
A. Not the eſſentiall righteouſneſſe of his diuine nature, but onely that perfectHeb. 7.26. integritie of the humane nature, which in him was without all guile; and that abſolute obedience, whereby, in that nature of ours, hee
1.Mat. 3.15 Fulfilled in act euery branch of the law of God.
2.Eſay 53.5 1. Pet. 2.24. 1. Joh. 2.2 Satisfied by his ſufferings, for the ſinnes of the whole world of his Elect.

p.hi: Q. How can Chriſts righteouſneſſe be accounted ours?
Q. How is this claime and application made?

div.p: A. On our part byRom. 5.1 faith alone, and that, not conſidered as a vertue inherent in vs, working by loue, but onely as anRom. 10 10 inſtrument, or hand of the ſoule ſtretched forth to lay hold on Chriſt,Ier. 23.6 The Lord our righteouſneſſe.

p.hi: Q. But how are wee made Prieſts vnto God, by our Communion with Chriſt?

div.p:
A. OurEph. 1.6. perſons receiued into fauour,
wee are admitted, as a1. Pet. 2.5 ſpirituall Prieſthood, to offer vp the ſacrifices of our obedience and thanksgiuing; which howſoeuerEſa 64.6. imperfect in themſelues, and deſeruing ratherPſal. 143.2. Tit. 3.5. puniſhment then reward, are yet, as our perſons, made acceptable vnto GOD, and haueMat. 10.41, 42. promiſe of reward, by the onely merite and interceſsion of the ſame our high Prieſt.

div.head: SECT. XXI. Of our Communion with Chriſt in regard of his Kingly Office, viz. Glorification: and that begunne in this life: and firſt in our condition.

p.hi: Q. TO proceede to the third, what benefit receiue we by our Communion with Chriſt, in regard of his Kingly office?

div.p: A. OurRom. 8.30. Glorification, the third inſeparable companion and conſequent of our Calling, and Iuſtification, before-mentioned, whereby our condition and whole nature beeing changed and reſtored, according to theVer. 29. image of CHRIST our King, wee are made in him no leſſeReu. 1.5. Kings then Prieſts, euen a1. Pet. 2.9 royall Prieſthood.

p.hi: Q. How is our Glorification accompliſhed?

div.p: A. It isCol. 3.3, 4 begunne in this preſent life, and ſhall bee perfected in the end of this life, and in that which is to come; as ſhall be ſhewed.

p.hi: Q. How is our Gl • rification begunne in this life?

div.p: A. Reu. 20.6 Partly in regard of our condition, wherein wee are made bleſſed, and partly in regard of our nature and conuerſation, wherein wee are made holy.

p.hi: Q. How are wee made bleſſed in our condition?

div.p:
A. In that being in Chriſt, wee are in part,1. Joh. 4.17 1. Cor. 3.22, 23. admitted into the ſame
relation wherin Chriſt ſtandeth, both with God himſelfe, and with the creatures, and ſo inueſted in his perſonall prerogatiues; whereby we are gloriouſly exalted, both in our ſpirituall, and outward eſtate.

p.hi: Q. Wherein conſiſteth the exaltation of our ſpirituall eſtate?

div.p: A. In that we are not onelyCol. 3.4. 1. Joh. 3.2. aſſured of the fruition of the glorious and bliſſefull preſence of God, in heauen hereafter, but euen now in this life, in part,Joh 5.24. 1. Joh. 3.14. poſſeſſed thereof; being admitted vnto two degrees of happie communion with his Maieſtie.

p.hi: Q. Which is the firſt degree?

div.p: A. Fellowſhip with God; wherebyEph 2.12.13 & 18.19. 1. Joh. 1.3. Heb. 12.22.23 we, that were once farre off, and aliens from him, are now brought into a neare league and confederacie with him, and with his Saints, through the meanes of our Lord Ieſus Chriſt; who in our humane nature is ſtiledZech. 13.7 Gods fellow.

p.hi: Q. Which is the ſecond degree?

div.p:
A. Adoption; that is, power and priuiledge to be called theEph. 1.5. Sonnes of
God, deriued vnto vs from Chriſt,Heb. 2.10. who being the eternall Son of God, became, by incarnation, our Brother, that, by him, God might bring many ſonnes and daughters vnto glorie; euen as many as doe by faithJoh. 1.12. receiue him; who alſo by theGal. 4.5, 6. ſpirit of adoption are taught to call God Abba, Father. And thus we, which byEph. 2.3. nature were heires of wrath, are in, and with Chriſt (theHeb. 1.2. heire of all things) madeGal. 4 7.
