Rom. 8.17. heires of Gods fauour and kingdome; procured for vs as a purchaſe, by the right of iuſtification, and conueyed vnto vs, as an inheritance, vnder the tenure, & title of Adoption.

p.hi: Q. What enſueth vpon this, to make vs ſpiritually bleſſed?

div.p: A. 1. Pet. 1.8, 9. Ioy in the holy Ghoſt, vnſpeakable and glorious, we being atRom. 5.1, 2 & 14.17. peace with God, hauing acceſſe by faith vnto this grace wherein we ſtand, & reioycing vnder the hope of the glorie of God.

p.hi: Q. Doe the children of God alwayes thus reioyce?

div.p:
A. Ioy, conſidered as aPſal. 4.6, 7. delightfull apprehenſion of the fauor of God, gladding
the heart, though itPhil. 4.4. ought continually to be laboured for, and preſerued, yet it may be at times, and for a time, not only darkened and daunted, but euenPſal. 51.12 loſt, and to be reſtored: yet is it, as allRom. 11.29 gifts of God, perpetuall and without repentance, if we regard
1. The matter of reioycing, which is GodsMal. 3.6. vnchangeable loue and grace.
2. The cauſes and fountaines of ioy in the regenerate, which are the neuer-failing graces ofLuc. 22.32 faith, Rom. 5.5. hope, and1. Cor. 13.8 loue, towards God in Chriſt.
3. The valuation, euen inPſal. 6.8. deepeſt diſmay, of our part and helpe in Chriſt, aboue the pleaſures of ten thouſand worlds.
4. The pretence and claime of the faithfull heart,Pſal. 42.5. promiſing and challenging vnto it ſelfe a comfortablePſa. 126.5. & 97.11. harueſt of ioy, for the preſent ſeed-time of ſorrow.

p.hi: Q. Wherein conſiſteth the exaltation of our outward eſtate?

div.p:
A. In the1. Tim. 4.10 Rom. 8.32. promiſes and bleſſings of this preſent life, which are the royalties
and prerogatiues of the faithfull: onely withMar. 10 38. reſeruation (ſo farre as God ſhall ſee good) of the condition of the Croſſe.

p.hi: Q. What are thoſe prerogatiues?

div.p:
A. They are many and great: but may, for the moſt part, bee referred to fiue: whereof the firſt is
Hoſ. 2.18 Heb. 1.14 & 2.5, 8 Amitie with all the creatures, which are a new reconciled and ſubdued vnto the faithfull members of Chriſt.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſecond?

div.p: A. Gal. 5 13. Chriſtian libertie; whereby not onely our right, forfeited in Adam, is recouered and reſtored vnto vs by Chriſt, the1. Cor. 15.47. ſecond Adam, the Lord from heauen; but alſo the reſtraint of theGal. 5.1. &c Col. 2.20. ceremoniall law is remooued: and now vnto theTit. 1.15 pure, in Chriſt Ieſus, all things are pure, andRom. 14.14 nothing vncleane in it ſelfe; vnleſſe through weakeneſſe of conſcience in him that vſeth them, or inVer. 15 thoſe that take offence at them, they become accidentally vncleane, or ſcandalous.

p.hi: Q. What is the third?

div.p:
A. Pſa. 34.9.10 & Pſa. 128. Sufficiencie of earthly comforts,
as tokens of Gods loue, and pledges of better things, wherewith many times the godly are ſo bleſſed, that they becomePſal. 21.6 bleſsings vnto others.
Q. What is the fourth?

A. Pſ. 31.20 & 37.19 Immunitie from outward euils, as puniſhments of ſinne; which yet if, as trials and chaſtiſements, God inflict vpon them, they are aſſured to findeEſay 27 7 mercy and mitigation in the hand correcting:1. Cor. 10.13. 2. Cor. 12.9 ſtrength to beare what is laid vpon them: the ſpeciall prouidence of God cauſing all things toRom. 8.28. worke together for the beſt vnto them: and finally, a1. Cor. 10.13 Pſal. 149.4 glorious iſſue out of all troubles in due time.

p.hi: Q. What is the fift prerogatiue?

div.p: A. Dignitie and praeeminence; in that the faithfull haueGen. 9.26, 27. Pro. 14.19 Pſal. 105, 14, 15. dominion and vpperhand ouer the wicked, their enemies, & areMar. 6.20 Act. 5.13 honorable in the eyes and hearts of men, though not ioyning with them in profeſſion.

p.hi: Q. What • nſueth here vpon, to make vs outwardly bleſſed?

div.p:
A. Pro. 10.22 Ioy, without mixture of ſorrow,
in proſperitie, and in affliction abundant2 Cor. 1.5 conſolation.

div.head: SECT. XXII. Of Glorification begunne in our nature, viz. Sanctification.

p.hi: Q. HOw are we made holy in our nature?

div.p: A. By the grace of Sanctification; which is theTit. 3.5. renewing of our nature according to the2. Cor. 3.18 Epheſ. 4.24 image of God, in righteouſneſſe & true holineſſe, making vs after a ſort2 Pet. 1.4 partakers of the godly nature.

p.hi: Q. How farre forth, and by whom, is our nature in this life renewed?

div.p:
A. This renewing is of our1. Theſ. 5.23 Rom. 12.2 whole nature, ſpirit, ſoule, and bodie, our vnderſtanding being enlightened, our will enfranchiſed, and our outward man reformed; butIoh. 13.10 not wholly in this life: being the worke ofPſ. 51.10 Ezek. 36.26 God, not of our ſelues, yetEzek. 18.31 required at our hands, both to ſhew vs what wee ought to doe
by the power of grace, and to ſtirre vs vp to ſeeke, by prayer and all holy endeuour, to attaine vnto that ſupernaturall ſtrength.

p.hi: Q. By what meanes is this worke of God wrought in vs?

div.p: A. By the power andRom. 6.5. & • .2. Joh 15.3 Rom. 8.13 Act. 1 • .9 efficacie of the death, and reſurrection of Chriſt, conueyed vnto vs by his word and Spirit, which being apprehended by faith, and ſetting faith on worke, are auaileable vnto each part of our ſanctification.

p.hi: Q. What are the parts of Sanctification?

div.p: A. They are two, according to the powerfull meanes whereby they are wrought, Viz.

list.item: 1.Rom. 6.6, 7. Mortification, or dying vnto ſinne, and thereby freedome from the dominion thereof, by the vertue of the death of Chriſt.
2.Ro. 6 4.11 Viuification, or quickning vnto newneſſe of life, by the power of the reſurrection of Chriſt; in regard whereof it is alſo called ourReu. 20.6. firſt reſurrection.

p.hi: Q. How doth Sanctification differ from the former grace of Iustification?

div.p:
A. In many maine, and materiall differences, as
1. In the order, not of time, wherein they goe bothRom. 8.30. together, nor of knowledge and apprehenſion, wherein this1. Cor. 6.11 latter hath precedence: but of nature, wherein the former is the2. Cor. 7.1 ground of this latter.
2. In the ſubiect, the righteouſneſſe whereby we are iuſtified, being inherent in Chriſt for vs, but this of ſanctification Rom, 8.10 in our ſelues from him.
3. In the cauſe, our iuſtification being from the merite, our ſanctification from theEpheſ. 1 19. &c. & 2.1 efficacie, of the death and life of Chriſt.
4. In the inſtrument faith, which in iuſtification is onely as an hand receiuing, in ſanctification aAct. 15.9 Gal. 5.6 co-working vertue.
5. In the meaſure, Iuſtification being in all beleeuers, & at all times, alike, but ſanctification wrought2. Cor. 3.18 2. Pet. 3.18 differently and by degrees.
6. In the end, which beeing in both eternall life; Ro. 6.22.23 yet is the one among the cauſes of reigning, the other only as the high way to the kingdome.

div.head: SECT. XXIII. Of the rule of Sanctification, viz. the Law, with the direction of the Goſpell.

p.hi: Q. VVHat is the rule & ſquare of our Sanctification?

div.p: A. The wholePſal. 119.9 word of God, as containing thatRom. 12.2 will of his, which is1. Theſ. 4, 3. &c. euen our ſanctification.

p.hi: Q. What meane you by the whole word?

div.p: A. Job. 22.22 Ioh. 17.17 Both the Law and Goſpell, the old Teſtament and the new.

p.hi: Q. Are wee not then deliuered from the law by the meanes of Chriſt?

div.p:
A. From theGal. 3.10, 11, 12, 13. burthen of the law, exacting in our owne perſons perfect obedience, and from the curſe of it, due vnto diſobedience, wee are
deliuered by Chriſt:

But from the Commandement, as aJam. 2.8 rule of life, we are not freed, but contrariwiſe enclined and diſpoſed, by hisPſal. 51.12 & 119, 2, 45 1. Ioh. 5.3 free ſpirit, to the willing obedience thereof. Thus to the regenerate the Law becometh as it were Goſpel; euen aJam. 1.25. & 2.12 law of libertie.

p.hi: Q. How is the Goſpell a rule of obedience, being the rule of faith?

div.p:
A. The Goſpel1. Tim. 1.11 Eph 4.20, 21 directeth the faithfull to the obedience of the Law: only with difference,
1. Of the manner, the Law propounding God to bee worſhipped of vs in himſelfe, as our Creator, theIoh. 14.1. & 5.23 Goſpel in Chriſt, as our Sauiour.
2. Of the end, the Law requiring all duties, as for the procurement of our owne ſaluation, the Goſpell in way of1. Theſ. 5.18 thankefulneſſe for ſaluation in Chriſt, alreadie beſtowed.
3. Of the effect, the Law (like Pharaoh, that required bricke, but allowed no ſtrawe)Rom. 10.5, 6. &c. demanding obedience, but vouchſafing no aſsiſtance,
(ſuppoſing man as in the ſtate of Creation) but the Goſpell both requireth, and conferreth faith vnto the Elect, and that not onely as a hand to lay hold on Chriſt; but alſo as the chiefe vertue, working by loue in all parts of obedience; without which euen the Goſpell is law, that is, a2. Cor. 3.6 killing letter, as to the vnregenerate.

p.hi: Q. Doth not the Goſpell adde other precepts, or counſels to thoſe of the law?

div.p:
A. Not any other, in ſubſtance of action, but onely reneweth & enforceth 1. Ioh. 2.7, 8 thoſe of the law: and ſpecifyeth ſome duties, as of faith in the Meſſiah, of the Sacraments &c. which haue their generall ground from the law. As for thoſe, that are propounded in forme of counſell, and doe concerne things indifferent, they are notReu. 3.18 therefore arbitrary courſes of higher perfection (much leſſe meritorious of greater glory) but, as they are applied with due circumſtances, neceſſary precepts, referred to ſome one or other commandement of the law; theMat 19 23 reiecting wherof
excludeth from the kingdome of God.

p.hi: Q. What is that law, which with the direction of the Goſpell, is the rule of Sanctification?

div.p: A. Onely the morall law, or law of nature, engrauen by God himſelfe, firſt in the heart of man in his creation, after in Deut. 10.4 tables of ſtone, in the dayes of Moſes, & ſo publiſhed, & committed vnto the Church for all ages, as theIam. 2.8 royall law, for obedience to God our King, commonly called theExod. 34.28 Deut. 4.13 Decalogue, or ten Commandements.

p.hi: Q. What are we to conceiue of the Ceremoniall and iudiciall lawes?

div.p: A. They are onely added as ſpeciall explications and applications of the law morall, vntoRom. 9.4 that preſent Church and people of the Iſraelites: Viz.

list.item: The former for direction in rites of outward worſhip,Heb. 10.1. &c. ſhaddowing the grace of the Goſpell, now vtterlyVer. 9. aboliſhed, the ſubſtance being exhibited:

The latter for forme of pollicy, and ciuill gouernment, and therefore ceaſing with the diſſolution of
that common wealth, for which it was ordained.

div.head: SECT. XXIIII. Of the Decalogue.

p.hi: Q. TO deale onely therefore with the morall • aw, what order are wee to obſerue in handling of the Decalogue?

div.p:
A. We are to conſider
Firſt in generall,
The preface.
The diuiſion.
The rules of interpretation.
Secondly the ſeuerall Commandements in particular.

p.hi: Q. What is the preface of the Law?

div.p: A. Thoſe words of God,Exod. • 0.2 I am the Lord thy God, which brought thee out of the land of Egypt, out of the houſe of bondage. Wherein hee layeth a two-fold ground of obedience, Viz.

list.item: 1. Frō his nameExod. 3.14. Iehouah importing his eternal being of himſelf, &Rom. 11.36 communicating of life & all bleſſings to mankinde, wherby he is thePſal. 36.6 Sauiour of all men.

2. From the Couenant of grace, whereby he is our God, the1. Tim. 4.10. Sauiour of them that beleeue; aſſuring them all gracious deliuerances, by vertue of that his couenant, from all euils and enemies, both bodily, and eſpecially ſpirituall, vnder the figure of the late deliuerance of the Iſraelites out of Aegypt.

p.hi: Q. How is the Law diuided?

div.p:
A. Two wayes:
1. Into ten Commaundements, or words, propounded
Some affirmatiuely, as the 4. and 5. others negatiuely, as all the reſt.
Some with reaſons annexed, as the 2, 3, 4, 5: the reſt without.
2. Into two Tables, whichMath. 22. Chriſt calleth the two great Commaundements, viz. the
1. Containing ourVerſe 37.38. duetie to God in the foure firſt Commandements.
2. OurVerſe 39. duetie to our neighbor, in the 6. laſt.

p.hi: Q. What are the rules of interpreting the Law?

div.p: A. They are principally theſe three, viz.

list.item: 1. That where anyMatth. 4.10. 1. Cor. 15.34. duetie is enioyned, as in the affirmatiue Commandements, the contrarie ſinne is forbidden: and where anyEph. 4.28. ſin is forbidden, as in the negatiue, the contrarie duetie is required.
2. That vnderMatth. 5.21, 22, &c. 1. Iohn 3.15. one maine duetie, or crime expreſſed, all degrees of good, or euill in the ſame kind, are either commaunded, or forbidden.
3. That with the ſinne forbidden, or duetie enioyned, allTheſ. 5.22 Heb. 10 24, 25. occaſions, or furtherances thereto, are conſequently condemned, or required.

div.head: SECT. XXV. Of the firſt Commaundement.

p.hi:
Q. TO come to the ſeuerall Commaundements, and firſt of
the former Table; What are the words of the firſt Commaundement?
A.
Thou ſhalt haue none other gods before me.
Q. What is the ſcope and meaning of this Commaundement?

div.p: A. That the inward and ſpirituall worſhip of theProu 23.26 heart, whereinDeut. 5.29 God eſpecially delighteth, and which is theProu 4.23. Mat. 12.35. ground of the outward, be giuen to him the onely God, and to none other; and that ſincerely without hypocriſie, as in his ſight, whoJer. 17.10. ſearcheth and knoweth the heart.

p.hi: Q. What is forbidden in this Commaundement?
A.

list.item: 1. Originall corruption, ſo far forth as it is theRom. 8.7. fountaine of impietie againſt God: with all the ſtreams ofPſal. 14.1. Atheiſme, errour, Pſ. 10.3, 4. hatred of God, prophaneneſſe, preſumption, ſecuritie, infidelitie, Rom. 1.21. ingratitude, &c.

2. All inward Idolatrie, whereby men ſet vp anEzek. 14.3 Idoll in their heart, in ſtead of God, giuing thereto any part of ſpirituall adoration; as byActs 12.23 pride, 2. Tim. 3.4 1. Sam. 2.29. inordinate
loue,
• ſa. 51.12, 13. carnall feare, Pro. 18.11 Ier. 17.5. fleſhly confidence, &c.

p.hi: Q. What is required in this Commandement?

div.p: A. The ſetting vp, andEſa. 8.13. ſanctifying of the Lord God in our hearts, yeelding him, in Chriſt, the ſpirituall worſhip ofPſal. 73.25. faith and affiance, Deut. 6.5. loue, and1. Theſſ. 5.18. thankfulneſſe, Heb. 12.28 feare and reuerence, &c. which is due vnto his Maieſtie.

p.hi: Q. What are the helpes or hinderances of the obedience of this Commaundement?
A.

list.item: 1. The onely means to ſettle and vphold vs in this ſpiritual worſhip of God, is to endeuor to attaine and encreaſe in the2. Pet. 3.18 knowledge of him in Ieſus Chriſt: to conſiderPſal. 116.1, 12 1. Ioh. 3.1. what great things he hath done for vs: yeaPro. 3.6. in all our wayes to take knowledge of his preſence, promiſes, and prouidence.

2. Contrariwiſe, theHoſ. 4.1. & 8.12. neglect of the knowledge of God, andEſa 5.12. & 26.10, 11. not conſidering his word, and workes, are theEſa. 1.3, 4. ground of all
impietie, and ſpirituall Idolatrie, here forbidden.

div.head: SECT. XXVI. Of the ſecond Commaundement.

p.hi: Q. VVHat are the words of the ſecond Commaundement?

div.p: A. Exod. 20.4, &c. Thou ſhalt make thee no grauen image, neither any ſimilitude, &c.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſcope and meaning of this Commaundement?

div.p: A. To bind all men to thatDeut. 12.32 onely outward forme of worſhip, which God himſelfe in his word preſcribeth; and that by a twofold reaſon:

The firſt taken from the Couenant of grace, whereby he is the Lord our God: which Couenant on our part is by no ſinne ſo directly violated, as by Idolatrie, called therfore in Scripture ſpiritualIer. 3.8. Adulterie:

The ſecond, from the nature of God, which is, in this caſe to bee iealous;
which he ſheweth
1. By viſiting, and puniſhing, vnto the third and fourth generatiō, ſuch as (howſoeuer pretending loue) do thus declare their hatred of him:
2. By extending his mercie vnto thouſands of ſuch, as ſhew their loue of him, by obedience to this his Law.

p.hi: Q. What is forbidden in this Commaundement?

div.p:
A. Euerie forme of worſhip,Deut. 12.31. though of the true God,Mat. 15.9. contrarie to, or diuers from, the preſcript of Gods word; called by the ApoſtleCol. 2.23. Well-worſhip: together with all2. Kin. 16.10 corruptions in the true worſhip of God, and all luſt and inclination of heart, vnto ſuperſtitious pompes and rites in the ſeruice of God. All theſe the Lord forbiddeth vnder one inſtance ofPſ. 97.7. Images, wherein he foreſaw there would be greateſt abuſe, and therefore expreſly condemneth,
1. TheDeut. 4.15, &c. Hab. 2.18. making of any Images to repreſent God, or for religious vſe.
2. The worſhipping of them, or ofExod. 32.5. God in them, or vſing of anyEſay 44.15 Exod. 32.4. geſtures of religious adoration vnto them.

p.hi: Q. What is required in this Commaundement?

div.p:
A. That wee performe, with diligence, andEccl. 4.17. & 5.1, &c. reuerence, all parts of Gods outward worſhip preſcribed, whether
Ordinarie, asAct. 2.42. hearing, and reading the word, Prayer, the vſe of the Sacraments, the Diſcipline and cenſures of the Church:
Or extraordinary, asJoel 2.12, 15. faſts publike or priuate, ſolemnePſal. 50.14 thankſgiuing for ſpecial bleſſings, together with vowes, lots, and oathes, &c.

p.hi: Q. What are the helpes or hinderances of the obedience of this Commaundement?

div.p:
A. It is required, vnto the obedience of this Commaundement;
1. That all men labor forMic. 6.6, 7.8. knowledge of the expreſſe will of
God touching all parts of his worſhip, and ioyne together with1. Cor. 14.40 order and decencie in the performance thereof: And that ſuch, whom it concerneth, take care that faithfull and ableTit. 1.5, &c. Miniſters be ordained in euerie congregation, and that ſufficient1. Tim. 5.17, 18. maintenance, for2. Chr. 31.4 encouragement, be allotted them: ThatLuk. 7 5, 6. places for publike aſſemblies be erected and preſerued: That2 King. 6.1, &c. Schooles and Vniuerſities bee founded and maintained: That1. Sam. 10.25. Bookes of neceſſarie vſe vnto edification (eſpecially theReuel. 1.3. holy Booke of God) bee ſet ſorth and divulged: That, as occaſion requireth, Synods andAct 15.6. Councils be called and aſſembled, &c. Finally, that ſuch, whoſe calling and abilitie reacheth no farther, doe yet affoord the helpe of theirMat. 9.38. prayers vnto all theſe.
2. That noCol. 2.18. power bee admitted in the Church to preſcribe other
formes of worſhip, no2. Cor. 6.14 affinitie or ſocietie with Idolaters, no2. Chro. 15 13, 16 Reu. 2.20 toleration of ſuperſtition, no1. Cor. 10, 20, 21 preſence at Idolatrous worſhip be afforded: no relicks, or monuments of Idolatry, as2. Kin. 18.4. Images, Act. 19.19 bookes, Pſal. 16.4 names, and ſuch like be retained.

div.head: SECT. XXVII. Of the third Commandement.

p.hi: Q. VVHat are the words of the third Commandement?
A.
Thou ſhalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vaine, &c.
Q. What is the meaning of this Commandement?

div.p:
A. That we impeach not, but by all meanes aduance, the glorious Pſal. 29.2 name of God, in all things, whereby hee maketh himſelfe knowne to men, as his holyPſal. 68.4 titles, and attributes, Pſal. 138.2 word, and
Pſ. 145.10. workes: and that vnder a dreadfull penaltie viz. that howſoeuer mans law, for the moſt part, taketh not hold of offenders in this kinde, yet God will not Pſal. 1.5 acquit them, nor ſuffer them to eſcape his righteous, and fearefullZech. 5.3. Iam. 5 12 Iudgement.

p.hi: Q. What is forbidden in this Commandement?

div.p:
A. EueryMal. 1.6, 12 wrong offered to the name and glorie of God, as namelyTit. 1.16 hypocriſie: theRom. 1.24 euill life of profeſſors:Mat. 10.33 ſhrinking in caſe of perill, and denying God the honour of our ſuffering for him: abuſing his word, or any part thereof, vnto2. Pet. 3.16 idle and curious queſtions, Eſay 22.13 ieſting and profane mirth, defence ofMat. 4.6. errour,Act. 19.13. charmes or ſorceries: &c. Vnreuerent mention of his titles, as Lord, God, Ieſus, &c. in fooliſh admiration, idle wiſhes, G • n. 16.5 2. S • m. 16.8. imprecations, and curſings, &c.Iob. 3 2, 3 &c. murmuring at his prouidence, vnder the names of fortune and chance: Deut. 29 19 preſuming vpon his mercy, to harden our hearts in ſinning: cauilling at the doctrine ofRo. 9.19, 20 predeſtination &c. not Act. 17.27. ſeeing God in his
workes, or not vſing them as we ought. Finally in an oath, whether by ſwearing by anZeph. 1.5. Amo. 8.14 Idoll: or by calling God for a witneſſe, either of vaine and friuolous things byJam. 5.12 Ier. 23.10. vſuall ſwearing, or of our furious anger by1. Sam. 14.39 2. Kin. 6.31 paſsionate ſwearing, or of an vntruth, byLeu. 19.12. Zech. 5.4. forſwearing.

p.hi: Q. What is required in this Commandement?

div.p:
A. Whatſoeuer may aduance Gods glorie; as theTit. 2.10 Mat. 5 16 holy conuerſation of profeſſors:Reu. 2 13 confeſsion of Chriſt vnto ſuffering, yea martyrdome, if cauſe be: reuerentPro. 31.26 Pſal. 71.15 mention of the titles, attributes, word, and workes of God; eſpecially obſeruing and recounting, whatPſal. 66.16 & 103.23, &c. ſpeciall mercies hee hath vouchſafed vs in particular: receiuing, and vſing all the creatures of God to his glory, with thanksgiuing: Finally, in the matter of an oath, when we ſweare
1. InIer. 4.2 truth, affirming what wee know to bee true, andPſal. 15.4. & 24.4 verifying by deede what wee vndertake.
2. In iudgement, which is a due conſideration both of the nature, and greatneſſe of an oath, wherein God is taken to2. Cor. 1, 23 witneſſe againſt the ſoule of the ſwearer, if hee deceiue: and of the due calling, and warrant of an oath, whether publique, being demaunded by theGen. 43.3 1. Sam. 24.22, 23 Magiſtrate, without perill to the ſwearer, orExo. 22.11. 1. Sam. 20.17 2. Cor. 1, 23 priuate, in caſe of great importance, when the truth cannot otherwiſe be cleared.
3. In righteouſneſſe, that is, both in the due forme viz. byMat. 5.34 • . Eſay 25.16 Jer. 2 • 6 God alone, not by any creature, or Idoll: and to a right end, which is theEſay 45.23 with Phil. •
••
glory of God, andHeb. 6.16 peace among men.

p.hi: Q. What are the helpes or hinderances of the obedience of this Commandement?

div.p:
A. Firſt, that wee both enure our hearts to
•• ut. 28.58 E • cleſ. 9.2 feare & reuerence the great and dreadfull name of the Lord our God, and keepe a carefull watch ouer our
Pſal. 39.1 lips, and liues, leaſt by any meanes we diſhonour him.

Secondly, that we auoide, both the company of profane perſons, whoPſal. 73.9 ſet their mouth againſt heauen, and all vnneceſſarie dangers, wherebyMat. 26.69. &c. diuers haue beene occaſioned to deny the Lord.

div.head: SECT. XXVIII. Of the fourth Commandement.

p.hi: Q. VVHat are the words of the fourth Commandement?
A.
Remember the Sabbath day to keepe it holy &c.
Q. What is the meaning of this Commandement?

div.p:
A. To challenge at the hand of euery man, in behalfe both of himſelfe and of all that are vnder his roofe andNehem. 13.15. &c. Joſ. 24.15 gouernement, one day, (and now ſince the reſurrection of Chriſt the firſt) of the ſeauen, in euery weeke, to be ſet apart vnto an holy reſt, for Gods publique
and ſolemne worſhip; and that vpon a fourefold reaſon:
1. From equitie, becauſe God alloweth vs ſix dayes for our affaires, and reſerueth but one for himſelfe.
2. From his owne right, becauſe this day is his and not ours.
3. From his example, who on the ſeuenth day reſted from his work of Creation.
4. From hope of bleſsing, becauſe God hath bleſſed, and ſanctified the Sabbath not onely as a day of ſeruice to himſelfe, but alſo as a time andExod 31.13 Eſay 56.6, 7. meanes to beſtow encreaſe of grace vpon ſuch, as doe conſcionably obſerue the ſame.

p.hi: Q. What are the duties required in this Commandement?

div.p: A. Three, Viz.

list.item:
1. To remember the Sabbath day: that is not onely to looke back vnto theGen. 1.2, 3 firſt ſanction of it in Paradiſe, before all ſacrifices and ceremonies (which reaſon, among many others,
may perſwade, that it is not ceremoniall, but perpetuall, not to ceaſe till it be perfectlyHeb. 4.9.10 conſummated in the heauenly Sabbath) but alſo ſo to beare it in minde, as to liue in continuall practiſe of the duties wee learned the Sabbath paſt, andLuk. 23.54 preparation of our ſelues, and our affaires, that wee may freely and duely attend on the Lord in the Sabbath approching.

2. ToEſay 58.13 make it our delight, to conſecrate it as glorious to the Lord, performing, with care, and deſire of profit, the duties thereof in publique and priuate: to wit:
OfAct. 13.13, 15 Pſal. 92 See the title. pietie, as hearing and reading the word, communicating in the Sacraments, prayer, ſinging of Pſalmes, conferring, & meditating of the word and workes of God, eſpecially feeding our ſoules with the contemplation of the heauenly Sabbath, &c.
Of1. Cor. 16.2 Nehe. 8.12 mercie, as collections for the poore, viſiting the ſicke, comforting the ſad, reconciling ſuch
as are at variance: and ſuch like.
Wherein ſuch, as are neceſſarily debarred from the publique duties muſt, withMat. 24.20 Pſal. 42.6 ſorrow for ſuch reſtraint, vſe more carefully thePſal. 63.1, 2 priuate meanes.

3. ToExod. 34.21 & 31.13 reſt from our ordinary, though lawfull buſineſſes, for the ſpace of that whole naturall day; yea to allow reſt to the very cattel, both that we may ſhewPro. 12.10 mercy, euen to the beaſt, and to repreſent, after a ſort, the euerlaſting Sabbath, wherein allRo. 8.20, 21 creatures ſhall be deliuered from the bondage of corruption: Notwithſtanding ſuch works are excluded, as are preſently neceſſarie, either for theAct. 1.12 Mat. 12.5. actions of pietie belonging to that day, or for extraordinarie exigents of charitie, for the2. Kin. 11.9 &c. preſeruation of the commonwealth, or of our owne or others Mat. 3.4 M • t. 12.1. &c life, or1 Ver. 11. liuelihood, in caſe of preſent neceſſitie, or danger.

p.hi: Q. What is forbidden in this commandement?

div.p:
A. The vnhallowing or profaning of the Sabbath: which is done
1. By making it a common day through commonNeh. 13.15. &c. labour in our ordinarie callings, Eſay 58.13. talking of our worldly affaires, thinking of our owne thoughts, or no other but a common vſe of the creatures.
2. By making it a day of carnall reſt, vnto idleneſſe, Exod. 32.6. feasting, pastimes &c. Which draw our mindes farther from God, then our ordinarie labours.
3. By making it a day of ſinne, or the Diuels holiday, doing that on the Lords day, which isMar. 3.4. no day lawfull, but then moſtEzek. 23.37, 38 abhominable.
4. By beeingAmos 8.5. Mal. 1.1 •
weary of the duties of the Sabbath, thinking long till they be ended.

p.hi: Q. What are the helpes or hinderances to the keeping of this commandement?
A.

list.item:
1. We muſt adde to the forementioned duty of remembrance an ardent endeauour to taſt the
Pſal. 42.2, 3 & 84.1, &c. ſweetnes of holy exerciſes, that ſo wee may come to make the Sabbath our delight.

2. We muſt auoyd, and abhorre, allEzek. 22.26 prophane opinions, either diſannulling the neceſsitie of the Sabbath, or equalling any other day to it; together with ſuch meetings, and companies, exerciſes, and occaſions, whereby we ſhal be in daunger to be drawn to the vnhallowing of this day.

div.head: SECT. XXIX. Of the fift Commaundement.

p.hi: Q. TO proceed to the ſecond Table; What are the words of the fift Commaundement?

div.p: A. Exod. 20.12 Honour thy Father and thy Mother, &c.

p.hi: Q. What is the meaning and ſcope of this Commaundement?

div.p:
A. That the qualitie of mens perſons, and places, in whatſoeuer eſtate,
naturall, ciuile, or Eccleſiaſticall, & with whatſoeuer relation to vs, be duely acknowledged and reſpected, and that vpon aEph 6.2, 3. promiſe of the bleſsing of long life andDeut. 5.16 proſperitie, to ſuch as, in ſo doing, ſhall ſhew that they regard theEph. 6.1. Rom. 13.1, 2. image, and ordinance of God.

p.hi: Q. What is required in this Commaundement?

div.p: A. All due carriage of inferiours to their ſuperiours, and by conſequent, of ſuperiors alſo to their inferiors, and of equalls among themſelues, vnder the ſweet relation betwixt parents and children, or betwixt brethren of the ſame familie, and the generall duetie of honour: importing

Firſt, that all inferiours, as wiues, children, young perſons, ſubiects, ſeruants, hearers, &c. doe readily acknowledge and yeeld to their ſuperiours, Leuit. 19.3 Eph. 6.5 reuerence in heart, word, and behauiour:Eph. 6.1. Col. 3.20. Tit. 3.1. Heb. 13.7. obedience and ſubmiſsion to their commaundements, counſels, and corrections:Tit 2.10. fidelitie: thankfulneſſe: Rom. 13.6, 7. Gal. 6.6. maintenance: 1. Tim 2.1, 2 prayer to God for them, with giuing of thankes:2. Tim. 1.5 Phil. 4.9. imitation
of their vertues and graces, &c.

Secondly, that all Superiours, as huſbands, parents, aged perſons, Magiſtrates, Maiſters, Miniſters, &c. doe anſwerably affoord to their inferiours, Eph. 5.23. Rom 13.4 protection and ſupport:Mat. 7.9, 10 prouiſion of good things for the bodie and the ſoule:Eph. 6.4. education and inſtruction in nurture and the feare of God: Heb. 21.20 & 7.7. Gen. 9.25, 26, 27. bleſſing, according to the power they receiue from God:Tit. 2.7. good example for their imitation, &c.
Thirdly, that equals do in the matter of honour and reſpect,Rom. 12.10 1. Pet. 2.17. & 5.5. Eph. 5.21. preferre each other before themſelues.

p.hi: Q. What is forbidden in this Commaundement?

div.p: A. Firſt the omiſsion of any of the dueties aforenamed.

Secondly the contrarie ſins, whereby either
InferioursIude verſe 8, 9, 10. Pro. 30.11. deſpiſe orRom. 1.30. diſobey their ſuperiours: or
SuperioursTit. 2.15. diſhonour their places, as by vnſeemely carriage, or abuſe of their Authoritie, through too much1. Sam. 2.23, &c. lenitie, or
Eph. 6.4, 9 ſeueritie, &c. or finally
Equals aduance themſelues oneMat. 23.6. aboue another.

p.hi: Q. What are the helpes or hinderances of the obedience of this Commaundement?

div.p: Firſt, on both ſides, there muſt bee endeuour to nouriſh and encreaſeRom. 12.10, 16. naturall affection, humilitie, and wiſedome to diſcerne what isRom. 13.7. fitting for our owne, and others places.

Secondly, in ſeuerall,
The Inferiour muſt ſee Rom. 13.1, 2 God in the place and authoritie of his Superiour, ſetting before his eyes the dreadfull threatnings and examples of Gods vengeance on theEccleſ. 10.8 ſeditious and diſobedient.
The Superior muſt bee the ſame to his Inferior, that hee would haueEph. 6.9. Chriſt to bee vnto himſelfe; remembring the tragicall ends of Tyrants, and vſurpers.

Contrariwiſe, as hinderances of theſe dueties, are to be auoyded,2. Tim. 3.2, 3, 4. ſelf-loue, which maketh men vnfit either
to rule, or to obey: partiall Eccleſ. 7 23 24. enquirie into the dueties of others towards vs, ioyned for the moſt part, with neglect of our owne: the furie of Anabaptiſts: with the companie ofPro. 24: 21, 22. ſeditious perſons, and deſpiſers of gouernement, &c.

div.head: SECT. XXX. Of the ſixt Commaundement.

p.hi: Q. VVHat are the words of the ſixt Commaundement?
A.
Thou ſhalt not kill.
Q. What is the meaning of this Commaundement?

div.p: A. That theGen. 9.5. life and perſon of man be, by man, not impeached, but preſerued.

p.hi: Q. What is forbidden in this Commaundement?

div.p:
A. Whatſoeuer tendeth to the hurt of the ſoule, or bodie; whether
1. Our owne, as
Pro. 6.32. & 8.35. Sinne, eſpecially groſſe ſinnes, andRom. 2.5. Tit. 3.11. obſtinacie in ſinning; reiecting the food of ſpirituall life, by
Pro. 28. • . not hearing, or notJam. 1.22 obeying the word: corrupting or peruerting it, by2. Tim. 4.3. itching eares, or2. Pet. 3 16. vnſtable mindes, &c.
1. Sam 31.4 Selfemurther, 1. Kin. 18.28. launcing or whipping our owne fleſh, ſurfets, 1. Kin. 2.23 capitall crimes, vnneceſſarie dangers, &c.
2. Or our neighbours as,
Pro. 29.12 Euill example, 1 Kin. 12.28 commanding or tempting to things vnlawfull,1 Cor 8.10 11. vnſeaſonable vſe of Chriſtian libertie, Amos 7.13 Eſay 56.10. withholding the food of ſpirituall life,1. Tim 1.4. corrupting it by erroneous, or vaine and curious expoſitions, &c.
The taking away ofGen. 9.6. life, (otherwiſe then in caſe of publikeIoſ. 7.19, &c. iuſtice, iuſtDeu. 20.12, 13. warre, or neceſſarieExod 22 2 defence) al paſsions ofMat 5 22. anger, hatred, enuie, deſire of reuenge, vnmercifulneſſe, &c. bitter andPro. 12.18. curſed ſpeaking, 1. Sa. 25.17 froward & churliſh behauior, ſtriking orLeu. 24.19.20. wounding, cruellIam. 5.4. oppreſsion (withdrawing the meanes of life)Deut. 25.3. extremitie in correction and puniſhment &c.

p.hi: Q. What is required in this commandement?

div.p: A. Whatſoeuer may preſerue, or cheriſh the ſoule and bodie, viz.

list.item:
1. Our owne; as
A careful1. Pet. 2.2 vſe of the means of grace, with diligēce to finiſh ourPhil. 2.12 ſaluation, & make our2. Pet. 1.10 election ſure, by the fruits of faith &c.
Sober and wholſome 1. Tim. 5.43 dyet, with helpe of Phiſicke, when neede is,Ioh. 18.8 preuenting vnneceſſarie dangers &c. Finally willingneſſe to receiue the2 Cor. 1.9. ſentence of death, when God ſhall vtter it: and reſigning ourNu. 27.16 1. Chro 28.1, &c. charge in Church, Common-wealth, or Family, into the hands of faithfull men: ourPſal. 31.5 ſoule to God in Chriſt, with confidence of his loue,Iob. 13.15 though hee kill vs, of the remiſsion of our ſinnes, and ourJob 19.25 &c. reſurrection vnto immortalitie: our bodie to the earth as a pledge, in time to be reſumed.

2. Our neighbours; as
Loue of him, as of our ſelues:
Math. 5.16. good example: Heb. 10.24. counſell, and encouragement vnto wel-doing: ſeaſonablePſal. 141.5. admonition, 1 Theſ. 4.18. conſolation, &c.
Phil. 4.8. Iam. 3.13. Amiable behauior: Iob 29.15. &c. reliefe: Pro. 24.11, 12. reſcue from danger, if wee may:Rom. 12.15 compaſsion and fellow feeling of his good or euill:Matth. 5.9. peace-making; and for that end,1 Cor. 13.7 construing things in the beſt ſence,Eph. 4.32. paſsing by offences, yeaGen. 13.8, 9 parting ſometimes with our right:Mat. 25.36 Iam. 1 27. viſiting and comforting him in ſicknes and affliction, &c.
Finally, decentGen. 23.4. buriall with moderateEccleſ. 12.7 1 The. l. 4.13. mourning.

p.hi: Q. What are the helps or hinderances to the obedience of this Commandement?

div.p:
A. Firſt, it behoueth vs to conſider, that al men are made in theGen. 9.6. image of God, and ofAct. 17, 26. one bloud with vs, and all Christians in the image of Chriſt alſo, in whom wee are all1. Cor. 12.27 one body: that God hathGen. 9.6. appointed the magiſtrate to puniſhLeuit. 2.4.20, 21. proportionably euerie offender in this kind; yea himſelfe extraordinarily bringethGen. 4.9. &c. Pro. 28.17. Act. 28.4. murtherers
to light and puniſhment.

Secondly, we muſt abhor the falſe opinion of the world, placing manhood inGen. 4.23.24. reuenge and bloudſhed: thePro. 22.24, 25. company of furious and vnmercifull men:Pro. 1.19. greedy deſire of gaine, &c.

div.head: SECT. XXXI. Of the ſeuenth Commandement.

p.hi: Q. VVHat are the words of the ſeuenth Commandement?
A.
Thou ſhalt not commit Adultery.
Q. What is the meaning and ſcope of this Commandement?

div.p: A. That all2 Cor. 7.1. 1 Theſſ. 4.3, 4, 5. vncleanneſſe and impuritie auoided, chaſtitie by all means be preſerued.

p.hi: Q. What is forbidden in this Commandement?

div.p:
A. All impurity and fleſhly pollution; as filthyMatth. 5.28 imaginations and lusts: Ephe. 4.29. & 5.4. ſpeaking or1. Cor. 15.35 giuing eare to corrupt & rotten communication: Ezek. 16.49 idleneſſe: intemperance in diet:Eſa. 3.16. &c. immodestie in the apparell & ornaments of the body:Ezek. 23.14. laſciuious
pictures: Pro. 6.13. & 7.10. &c. impudencie or lightneſſe in countenance, or behauiour: nightly pollutions:Heb. 13.4. fornicatiō, & adultery; both which are aggrauated by the circumſtances of2 Sam. 13.14 inceſt, &Deut. 22.25 rape: vnlawfull entrance into mariage; when the parties are in theLeuit 18.6, &c. degrees of conſanguinitie, or affinitie, prohibited, of aGen 6 2. diuerſe religion, Mal. 2.15. formerly maried, or contracted to ſome other, or wantingExod. 22.16 17. due conſent of parents, or betwixtGen. 29.23. themſelues: abuſe of the marriage bed Leuit. 18.19 vnſeaſonably, or intemperately: Finally the vnnaturall vſe, or luſt after theRom. 1.26, &c. ſame ſex, or a diuersLeuit. 20.15, &c. kinde &c.

p.hi: Q. What is required in this Commandement?

div.p:
A. 1 Theſſ. 5.23. Chaſtity and purity in heart: Eph. 4.29. ſpeach ſauoring of ſobriety & grace: the1 Theſ. 4.4. poſſeſsing of our veſſels in holineſſe and honor:1 Cor. 9.27. temperance in dyet, and conuenient abſtinence: labour in our vocations:1 Tim. 2.9. modeſty in apparell:Tit. 2 3. grauity in behauiour: Finally in thoſe that haue not the gift of continencie, holy1 Cor. 7.9. wedlocke; and therein mutuallPro. 5.19. delight, due1 Cor. 7.3, 4.5. beneuolence, Rom. 7 2. fidelitie,
andPro. 31.11 confidence each in other &c.

p.hi: Q. What are the helpes or hinderances to the obedience of this Commandement?

div.p: A. Firſt, vnto thoſe forementioned helps, there muſt bee added care to keepe aEccleſ. 7.28 good conſcience: watchfulneſſe ouer our owneMal. 2.16 ſpirit: aJob. 31.1. couenant with our eies: loue of God and of hisPro. 2.10. &c. wiſdome, Pſal 119.37. prayer, holy meditations &c.

Secondly we muſt abhorre the1 Tim. 4.1.3 doctrine of diuels, deprauing and denying holy marriage: theProu. 22 14. breach of peace with God: running on inEccleſ. 7.28 ſinne, namelieRo. 1 25, 26 ſuperſtition; in which caſes God giueth men ouer to vile luſts: Finally lewdPro. 5.20. & 7.25. company, Gen. 34.1. &c. idle and vnwarrantable exerciſes, and whatſoeuer prouocations vnto this kinde of ſinne.

div.head: SECT. XXXII. Of the eight Commaundement.

p.hi: Q. VVHat are the words of the eight Commaundement?
A.
Thou ſhalt not ſteal • .
Q. What is the meaning of this Commaundement?

div.p: A. That wee no way impeach or hinder, but by all meanes preſerue and further the wealth both of our ſelues and our neighbours.

p.hi: Q. What is forbidden in this Commaundement?

div.p:
A. Whatſoeuer is preiudiciall to the wealth
1. Of our ſelues; asPro. 23.21. idleneſſe and2 Theſ. 3.11 inordinate liuing: vnlawfull meanes of gaine, asPro. 21.17. gaming, ſtage-playing, fortune-telling, Act 19.19. figure-caſting, &c.Eccleſ 4.8. & 6.2. defrauding our ſelues of the vſe and comfort of that which God hath giuen: waſting and conſuming our ſubſtance by heedleſſe
Pro. 6.1. &c. ſuretiſhip, Luc. 15, 13. lauiſh ſpending, &c.
2. Of our neighbour; as1 Ioh. 2.16. 2. Pet. • .14. couetouſneſſe, which is the luſt of the eye: Pro 20.25. ſacrilege: robbing of theEſa 3.15. & 5.8. commonwealth by encloſures, ingroſsings, forſtallings, monopolies, &c. priuieZech. 5.3. ſtealth, Pro. 1.11. &c. robbery, piracie, Eſa. 1.23. vpholding theft in others by impunity, &c.Pro. 22.22 23. Amos 5 11. oppreſsion and extortion:Pro. 22.28. remouing bounds or land marks:Ioh. 12. • . falſe dealing in matters committed to our truſt (the ſinne of factors, executors, and depoſitaries:)Pro. 20.14 debaſing that we would buy, extolling that wee would ſell: Deut. 25.13, 14. falſe weights, meaſures, lights, &c. buying or ſelling things not vendible, as theAct. 8.19 20 gifts of the holy Ghoſt, charge of ſoules, church-goods, thingsEſa. 55.2. vnprofitable or hurtfull to the buyer; as diſpenſations for ſin, charmes, &c. inhancing theAmos 8.4. price: Pſal. 15.5. vſury, which is increaſe, exacted meerly for the loane:
wrongfull detaining of theLeuit. 19.13 laborers hire, the ſtray orLeuit. 6.3 loſt thing, the thingPſal 37.21. borrowed: Exod. 23.8 briberie, which is the ſale of iuſtice, or iniuſtice:Pro. 28.7. feeding ofTit 1 12. idle perſons, as Monks, 2. Theſſ. 3.10. wandring beggers, &c.

p.hi: Q. What is required in this Commandement?

div.p:
A. Whatſoeuer may proſper and further the wealth
1. Of our ſelues, as aEph. 4.28. Gen. 3.19. lawful calling, with faithfull labour therein: honeſt care of keeping that we haue byPro. 27.23, 24. frugalitie, wiſely ordering and limiting our expences to the proportion of our meanes: conuenientEccl. 2.26, & 5 18. vſing of our wealth, withHeb. 13.5. contentation of mind, by timely & moderate ſpending, &c.
2. Of our neighbor, asPro. 11.25. liberalitie in giuing, andPſal. 37.26. lending: iuſtice inLeuit. 25.14. bargaining; whenMath. 7.12. reſpect is had to our neighbours profit, as to our owne:Pſal. 15 4. keeping of all iuſt couenants: Ezek. 18 16 reſtoring
the pledge or thing borrowed: moderation inMath. 18 28 1. Cor. 6.7. recouering our owne by ſuite of law: Finally amends for former iniuſtice byLuc. 19 8. reſtitution, either to the party wronged,Num. 5.7, 8. or to his kindred, or, if none, bee found, to God and the Church.

p.hi: Q. What are the helps or hinderances to the obedience of this Commaundement?

div.p: A. Firſt wee muſt labour for faith in GodsHeb. 13.5, 6 promiſes and prouidence, Godlineſſe, which is1. Tim. 6.6, &c. great gaine and giueth contentment in whatſoeuer eſtate, withPro. 30.8. prayer to God for foode conuenient &c.
Secondly we muſt auoide the1. Tim. 6.10 loue of money, the roote of all euill, the company ofPro. 1.10. &c. 1 Pro. 23.20. lewd andPro. 23.20. ryotous perſons &c.

div.head: SECT. XXXIII. Of the ninth Commandement.

p.hi: Q. VVHat are the words of the ninth Commandement?
A.
Thou ſhalt not beare falſe witneſſe againſt thy neighbour.
Q. What is the meaning of this Commandement?

div.p: A. That wee impeach not truth, or the credit of our ſelues, or our neighbour, but by all meanes maintaine and vphold the ſame.

p.hi: Q. What is forbidden in this Commandement?

div.p:
A. Whatſoeuer is contrarie to a true and iuſt opinion or report: asApoc. 3.17. ouerweening, orPſal. 31 21. vnderweening the good things in our ſelues:Act. 8.9 bearing our ſelues aboue our worth: Pro. 27.2 boaſting:1. Sa. 15 21 excuſing our ſelues vniuſtly: debaſing our ſelues, whether byIob. 27.5 vility denying Gods graces, or byCol. 2.18. diſſimulation drawing others to commend vs:Col. 1.9 Apoc. 22.15. lying or aequiuocation: 1. Cor. 13.5 ſuſpition: contempt:
2. Cor. 12.6 fooliſh admiration, or expectation of others:Eſay 58.9 Pſal. 22.7 pointing at, or deriding: 1. Tim. 4.16 forbearing to ſpeake in the cauſe or credit of our neighbour:Pro. 27.14 flatterie: Pro. 24.24 excuſe, or defence of euill: Pſal. 15.3. falſe accuſation: Mat 26.61. reporting words beſides the meaning of the ſpeaker:1. Sa. 22.9. vttering truth with deſire to doe hurt: Gen. 9.22 Pſa. 38.18, 19 reioycing or making our ſelues merry with the infirmities & infamie of our neighbour: &c.

p.hi: Q. What is required in this Commandement?

div.p:
A. Whatſoeuer may nouriſh truth, and the good name, of our ſelues, or others: as toPro. 10.19 ſpeake ſparingly, ſeeing in many words there cannot want iniquitie: to ſpeake thePſal. 15.2. truth from our heart: to know and2. Cor. 13.5 & 10.12. &c. iudge truely of our ſelues: to loue our ownePhil. 4.8. good name, and to2. Cor. 12.11. defend it, when neede requireth; yet modeſtly and vnwillingly: to iudge vprightly, and, as much as we may, in the 1. Cor. 13.7 Iam. 3 27 beſt ſence, of our neighbour: to loue, andMat. 1.19 tender his credit as our owne: to3. Ioh. ver. 12. commend him wherein hee deſerueth well, yet rather abſent,
then preſent: toLeu. 19.17. 1. Cor. 11.22 reproue him when iuſt cauſe is, but rather to his face, then behinde his backe, and withReu. 2.2, 3, 4. &c. remembrance of what is praiſe worthy: &c.

p.hi: Q. What are the helpes or hinderances to the obedience of this Commandement?

div.p: A. Firſt we muſtPſal. 39.1 keepe our mouth, as with a bridle; yea pray to God toPſal. 141.3 ſet a watch before the doore of our lips.

Secondly, we muſt abhorre the popiſh doctrine, maintaining aequiuocation, and teaching to1. Tim 4.2 ſpeake lyes through hypocriſie: alſo2. Tim. 3.2 pride, and ſelfeloue, which thruſt men forward to boaſting and vaunting: Finally, exceſſiue drinking, and whatſoeuer elſe cauſeth the heart toPro. 23.33. vtter peruerſe things.

div.head: SECT. XXXIIII. Of the tenth Commandement.

p.hi: Q. VVHat are the words of the tenth Commandement?
A.
Thou ſhalt not couet thy neighbours houſe &c.
Q. What is the meaning of this Commandement?

div.p: A. That in the moſt inward diſpoſition of our heart, wee decline not from the rule of charitie; as to luſt after our neighbours houſe (orCant. 8.7 whole poſſeſsion) his wife (which is hisGen. 39.9 chiefeſt and choiſeſt treaſure) hisExo. 21.16 ſeruants (which are precious aboue all outward poſſeſſions) his cattel, (which are next vnto the ſoules vnder his keeping:) Finally any thing, how ſmall ſo euer in our account, belonging to him. But that in all things wee keep our ſelues within the rule of brotherly loue.

p.hi: Q. What is forbidden in this Commandement?

div.p: A. All luſts, contrarie to charitie. Viz.

list.item: 1.Mat. 15.19 Rom. 7 7 Iam. 1.14. Originall corruption, ſo farre forth as it is the fountaine of ſinne, againſt the ſecond Table.

2.G • l 5.17, 19 &c. Actuall luſts: as thoughts of the minde, deſires of the heart,
fond wiſhings and wouldings, delightfull remembrances, andJer. 4.14. meditations of euill, &c.

p.hi: Q. What is required in this Commandment?

div.p: A. That wee diſpoſe of all our thoughts, & affections, according to charitie; whereto belongeth1. Tim. 6.8. Pſal. 16.6 contentment with our portion. 3. Joh. v. 2. wiſhing & delighting in our neighbours welfare, as our own:Gal. 5 16, 17. ſtriuing againſt luſt by the help of the ſpirit, and power of the death of Chriſt, &c.

p.hi: Q. What are the helpes or hinderances to the keeping of this Commandement?

div.p: A. Firſt we muſtPro 4 23 keepe our heart aboue all keepings, filling it with holy thoughts, andCol. 3.2 meditation of thoſe things that are aboue, andPſa. 119.36 praying to God to encline it to his teſt • monies, not vnto couetouſneſſe. &c.
A. Secondly, wee muſt auoid thePro. 17.24 gazing and wandring eye, that is in the corners of the world, together with all occaſions, and obiects of luſt: &c.

div.head: SECT. XXXV. Of the effect or exerciſe of Sanctification, viz. Repentance.

p.hi: Q. THus farre of the Law, the rule of Sanctification: What is the effect, or exerciſe thereof?

div.p: A. Repentance, which is aRo 12.1, 2 through change of our purpoſe of heart, & courſe of life, from theEſay 1.16, 17 euill, which Gods word rebuketh in vs, to the good, which it requireth of vs.

p.hi: Q. How is this change wrought in vs?

div.p:
A. When the ſinner, once humbled with the terrours of the Law, flyeth to the comforts of the Goſpell, hee thereZech. 12.10 ſeeth, in Chriſt crucified, not onely the mercie of God diſcharging him of all his ſinnes, but alſo how deepe the wounds of ſinne are, wherewith hee hath pierced his Sauiour, and how ſeuere the wrath of God is againſt ſin, euen to the ſlaughtering of his owne Sonne:1. Pet. 4.1 hence commeth he toPſal 97.10. hate his ſinne, as God hateth it, and to look
back thereon with2. Cor. 7.1 •
godly ſorrow, reſoluing for euer after to forſake all his ſinnes, and to liue in new obedience.

p.hi: Q. When is this Repentance to bee • actiſed of vs?

div.p: A. The practiſe of Repentance • ught to be a continuallRom. 12.9 abhorring of euill, and cleauing vnto that which is good, for as much1. Pet. 4.2, 3 time as remaineth in the fleſh after conuerſion: yet, at times there ought to be a more ſpeciall practiſe and renewing thereof, asPſal. 31 after great fals, inAmos 4.12. feare of imminent iudgements, or when we wouldGen. 35.2, 3 &c. fit our ſelues to receiue ſpeciall mercies.

p.hi: Q. In what manner muſt the ſpeciall practiſe of Repentance, in ſuch caſes, be performed?

div.p:
A. There muſt be
1. A ſeriousLam. 3.40. ſearch and enquirie after all ſinnes, as Traytors againſt God; but eſpeciallyIer. 8.6 Pſal. 18.23 ſpeciall ſinnes, as the Arch-Rebels.
2. Humble confeſsion of ſinnes; and that
1. Of neceſsitie vnto GOD, withPro. 28.13 Ier. 31.18, 19 ſhame of face, and true ſorrow of heart.
2. Vnto men conditionally; Viz. if either the Church, for2. Cor. 2.6. ſatisfaction of the publique offence, do enioine open acknowledgement: or ſomeLuk. 17.4 perſonall wrong demaund priuate reconciliation: or the weakeneſſe of the labouring conſcience doe require the ſecretIam. 1.16. aſsiſtance of a faithfull, and able, Miniſter, or Brother.
3. Feruent and faithfullPſal. 51.1, 2 &c. prayer to God in Chriſt both forVer. 7. pardon of what is paſt, and for ſupply ofVer. 10. renewing grace, for the time to come.

p.hi: Q. Seeing many doe falſely pretend that they repent, how may we know that our Repentance is true?

div.p:
A. A true tryall of vnfained Repentance may be taken
1. From the generalitie of it, Viz. if it extend to the abhorring and ſhunning ofPſ. 119.128 & 139.24 all ſinnes, and to the
loue and practiſe ofPſal. 119.6. all duties, without reſeruation.
2. From the through performance of each part, Viz.
1. Of hatred of ſinne in ſpirituall warfare againſt it, and that euen vnto Heb. 12.4 blood if neede be.
2. Of the loue of righteouſneſſe, in bringing forthMat. 3.8. fruits worthy of amendment of life, to wit, good workes.

div.head: SECT. XXXVI. Of the Spirituall warfare.
div.p: Q. VVHat is the Spirituall warfare?
A. The daily exerciſe of our ſpirituall ſtrength, and armour againſt all aduerſaries, with aſſured confidence of victorie.

p.hi: Q. What is our ſpirituall ſtrength?

div.p:
A. The powerfullEpheſ. 6.10 aſsistance of God in Chriſt, who hath loued vs,
whereby wee becomeRom. 8.37 more then conquerors.

p.hi: Q. What is our ſpirituall armour?

div.p: A. The complete furniture of ſauing and ſanctifying graces; called therefore the2. Cor. 6.7. armour of righteouſneſſe, and theEpheſ. 6.11 Panoplie or whole armor of God Viz.

list.item: TheVer. 14. &c girdle of veritie, or ſinceritie.
The breſt-plate of Righteouſneſſe, that is, holineſſe of life, and good conſcience.
The ſhoes of the preparation (or reſolution to goe through with the profeſſion) of the Goſpell of peace.
The ſhield of Faith.
The helmet of the hope of Saluation.
The ſword of the Spirit, which is the (ſound knowledge and wiſe application of the) word of God.
Finally continuall, & inſtant prayer in the Spirit.

p.hi: Q. Who are our aduerſaries in the ſpirituall conflict?

div.p:
A. They are either our friend prouing vs, or our enemies ſeducing
and endangering vs.

p.hi: Q. Who is that friend of ours, that for our probation entereth into conflict with vs?

div.p: A. God himſelfe, who though heeJam. 1.13 tempt no man vnto euill (no more then hee can himſelfe bee tempted) yet, as a Maiſter of defence, enureth vs to the conflict, by contending with vs, euen in his owne perſon. Viz.

list.item:
Sometimes by
Gen. 22.1, &c. Probatorie commandements, or
Ge. 32.24 Senſible apparitions.

But more ordinarily byIob 6.4. ſtriking our hearts with his terrors, Pſal. 77.7 withdrawing the comfort of his gracious preſence, 2. Chro. 32.31. leauing vs, for a time, to our ſelues, that by our falles wee may acknowledge our owne weakeneſſe: FinallyHeb. 12.5, 6 Reu. 3.19. exerciſing vs vnder the croſse, and yoake of outward afflictions.

p.hi: Q. How muſt wee contend with God?

div.p:
A. No otherwiſe, thenHoſ. 12.3.4 Iacob, and other holy men haue done, that is, by obedience, humilitie, patience, & feruent prayer vnto God; who onely enableth
vs to preuaile with himſelfe,Gen. 32.28. giuing vs the bleſsing, and name of Iſrael.

p.hi: Q. What are thoſe enemies of ours, that ſeeke to ſeduce and endanger vs?

div.p: A. Whatſoeuer marcheth vnder the banner of Satan, the2. Cor. 4.4 God andEpheſ. 6.12 Prince of the darknes of this world, who ſometimes2. Cor. 12.7 Zech. 3.1 immediately aſſaileth vs with impious and odious ſuggeſtions, but more vſually employeth his forces, or attendants.

p.hi: Q. What are the attendants of Satan?
A

list.item: 1. The1. Ioh. 2.15. world, which he abuſeth as his ſtorehouſe, and armorie of temptations, that is, bothVer. 16 allurements to euil with hope of gaine, pleaſure, or preferment, andIoh. 16.33 diſcouragements from dutie, with feare of loſſe, trouble, reproach, &c.

2. Our owneGal. 5.24. fleſh, which as a treacherous party within vs, being by Satan ſtirred vp, and inueigled with the baites of the world, or diſcouraged with the euill intreaty thereof,1. Pet. 2.11 fighteth on his ſide againſt our ſoule, that is, our ſpirituall life and welfare.

p.hi: Q. How doe theſe enemies fight againſt our ſoule?

div.p: A. By imploying all force, & fraud, to draw vs by ſinne, from the1. Ioh. 2.25 obedience, and fauour of God, vnto damnation.

p.hi: Q. What muſt we doe being thus aſſailed?

div.p: A. Wee muſtEph. 6.13, 14 ſtand faſt, beeing ſtrong in the Lord, and in the power of his might, and taking vnto vs the whole armour of God, that wee may bee able to reſiſt in the euill day, and to leade our captiuitie captiue.

p.hi: Q. How may wee bee able to ſtand againſt the aſſaults of the Diuell?
A.

list.item: 1. We muſt labour to2. Cor. 2.11 enforme our ſelues, that we may not be ignorant of his enterpriſes, or ſtratagemes.
2. We muſt boldly Iam. 4 7. 1. Pet. 5.9 reſiſt, that is,Eph. 4 27. giue no place or ground vnto him, or admit any conference with him, but rather neglect and deſpiſe his ſuggeſtions.

3. Wee muſt take the Epheſ. 6.16. ſhield of Faith in Chriſt, and his aſſiſtance
(Pſal. 16.8 ſetting him on our right hand, who isEſay 6 3.1. mighty to ſaue,) whereby wee may quench all the fierie darts of that wicked one.

4. Wee muſt brandiſh againſt him theEphe. 6.17. ſword of the Spirit, that is the word of God, after the example of ourMat. 4.4, &c. Sauiour, keeping our ſelues to that onely, which God reuealeth to vs, and requireth of vs.

p.hi: Q, How may we withſtand temptations from the world?

div.p: A. By our1 Joh. 5.4 faith, which ſetteth a better world, euen Gods heauenly kingdome, before our eyes, and ſo enableth vs, both toHeb. 11.24, &c. contemne andGal. 6.14 crucifie the loue of this preſent world, and toHeb. 11 36, 37. endure manfully, the threates and wrongs thereof, both confeſsing Chriſt in perill, and ſufferingReu. 12.11 martyrdome for his ſake, if wee bee thereto called.

p.hi: Q. How may we withſtand the temptations of our owne fleſh?

div.p:
A. By1. Pet. 4 1. ſetting before our eyes the
patterne of the death of Chriſt, and arming our ſelues with the ſame minde, that it behooueth vs alſo to ſuffer in the fleſh, ceaſing from ſinne; hereto crauing and employing the power of the ſame death of Chriſt, toRo. 6, 2. &c ſubdue and crucifie our carnall luſts and affections; whereto alſo belongeth the help of1. Cor. 9.25, &c. Abſtinence for the repreſſing of the inordinate deſires of nature.

div.head: SECT. XXXVII. Of good workes in generall.

p.hi: Q. THus farre of the ſpiritual warfare: What is a good worke?

div.p: A. Whatſoeuer thing is done of us,2. Cor. 3.5. not by the force or conduct of nature, but by the power of theRom. 8.10 ſpirit of Chriſt, dwelling in vs, and according to the rule of theRom. 12.2 knowne will of God, vnto the1 Cor. 10.31 glory of God, the2. Pet. 1.10, &c. aſſurance of our election, and the1. Cor. 10.23 edification of others.

p.hi: Q. Is there no concurrence of nature, in the doing of a good worke?

div.p: A. Taking nature (in the common ſenſe of Scripture) for thatEpheſ. 2.3 1. Cor. 2.14 hereditarie corruption, that cleaueth to all the ſonnes of Adam, Rom. 8.7 no good work hath any ground or help from nature, but is altogether contrarie thereto: but if we vnderſtand byRom. 2.14 nature, the created abilities of ſoule, and body, as the light of reaſon, libertie of will, motion of the bodily members &c. wee acknowledge nature to beMat. 16.17 not the principal mouer, or guide, but the1. Theſ. 5.23 thing moued, & guided by grace, in well doing.

p.hi: Q. Are there any workes of men perfectly good?

div.p: A. None, no not of the moſt perfect, in this life, by reaſō of theEſay 64.6 Gal. 15.17. remainders of corruption, but onely the workes of Chriſt, in whom alone there was1. Pet. 2.22 no mixture of ſinne.

p.hi: Q. Can all men doe good workes?

div.p:
A. No, but onely the regenerate, who are, for that purpoſe,Epheſ. 2.10 2. Tim. 2.21 created a new, and indued in meaſure, with the ſpirit of Chriſt, and power of his reſurrection:
As for the vnregenerate, they areMat. 7 17, &c. Jer. 13.23. the euill tree, that bringeth forth onely euill fruit.

p.hi: Q. Are there not ſome good workes, ſpecially commended to vs in the word of God?

div.p: A. Yes: and namely, among the duties of the firſt Table, Prayer, and among thoſe of the ſecond Table, Almes; touching which therefore ourMat. 6.1.5, &c. Sauiour giueth ſpeciall directions in the ſixt of Matthew.

p.hi: Q. Is not faſting alſo (of which our Sauiour in the
ſame place entreateth) a ſpeciall good worke?

div.p: A. Faſting is not properly a good worke, but an helpe, and aſsiſtance thereto, namely to Prayer, as ſhall appeare.

div.head: SECT. XXXVIII. Of Prayer.

p.hi: Q. TO proceede then; What is prayer?

div.p:
A. It is thePhil. 4.6. requeſt of an humble, &
ſanctified heart, together with thankſgiuing, offered by the power of theRom. 8.26. ſpirit of prayer, as a ſpeciallPſal. 50.15 ſeruice vnto God, in theIoh. 14.14. name of Chriſt, in behalfe of our ſelues, and Eph. 6.18. others, with1 Joh. 5.14 aſſurance to be heard, in what we pray for, according to the will of God.

p.hi: Q. Why doe you call it a requeſt with thankſgiuing?

div.p: A. Becauſe in all our prayers, there muſt bee both1. Theſſ 5.17. petition of the good things we need, andVerſe 18. thankefull acknowledgement of thoſe we haue obtained: As for thoſe formes, which containe neither ſupplication, nor giuing of thankes (as the Articles of our faith, the Decalogue &c.) they may and ought, for other good purpoſes, bee committed to memory andDeut 6.7. rehearſed, but to vſe them as prayers, M •• h. 6 7. ſauoreth of deepe ignorance, if not of ſuperſtition.

p.hi: Q. Why doe you call it the requeſt of the heart?

div.p:
A. Not to exclude the vſe of bodilie geſture, much leſſe of the voice and tongue, in the action of inuocation;
(therefore called theHoſ. 24.3. Calues of the lips) but to ſhew
1. That the1. Cor. 14.15. Pſal. 45.1 & 108.1. heart is, on our part, the firſt, and principall moouer, and ſpeaker in prayer, from whence both voyce and geſture haue their force, and grace.
2. That prayer, in ſudden occaſions, may beExod. 14.15 Nehem. 2.4. ſecretly, and powerfully offered, and is of God accepted, and heard, when neither any voice is vttered, nor any bodily geſture imploied.

p.hi: Q. Why doe you adde, of an humble, and ſanctified heart?

div.p:
A. Becauſe, as in generall, Pſal. 109.7 none can pray or doe any thing acceptably, but ſuch as are truely regenerate, andPſal. 51.15 ſanctified vnto this, and euery good worke: ſo in ſpeciall (and for the preſent action of prayer) it is required as thePſal. 51.17 ſumme of all ſacrifices, that the heart be humble, and contrite, Dan. 9, 8, 9 acknowledging it owne vnworthineſſe, by reaſon of ſinne,Pſal. 143.6 feeling the want of Gods grace and mercy, andLuk. 15.18, 19. ſubmitting it ſelfe vnto him, willing to be beholding
for the leaſt degree of fauour.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſpirit of prayer?

div.p: A. An eſpeciall grace and operation of theIude verſ 20. holy Ghoſt (called therefore theZech. 12.10. ſpirit of grace and deprecation) enabling vs toPſal. 62.8 powre out our ſoules vnto the Lord, withRom. 8.26. ſighs, that cannot be expreſſed.

p.hi: Q. Are wee to direct our prayers to God alone?

div.p:
A. Yea, to one God in Trinitie, and to none other: for he alone
1. As the ſearcher of the hearts, Pſal 65.2 heareth the voice, andRom. 8.27. knoweth the meaning of the ſpirit of praier.
2. IsEph. 3.20. able to grant whatſoeuer we demand.
3. Challengeth ourRom. 10.14 faith, and confidence, without which wee cannot pray.
For which cauſes, the Scripture alloweth not prayer to any other.

p.hi: Q. In whoſe name, or for whoſe ſake, muſt we ſue to God?

div.p:
A. In the onelyDan. 9.17. Joh. 16.23.24. name and for the onely ſake, of his ſonne, our Lord Ieſus Chriſt, the alone 1. Tim. 2.5. mediator betweene
God and man, as of1. Joh. 2.1, 2 Rom. 8.34. propitiation, ſo of1. Joh. 2.1, 2 Rom. 8.34. interceſsion; who through theHeb. 10.19, &c. vaile of his fleſh, and merit of his blood, hath prepared for vs a new, and liuing way, whereby we may bee bold to enter into the holie place: inGal. 4.5. whom alone wee are made children of God, and haue liberty to call him Father; Finally in, with, and for Rom. 8.32. whom, God giueth all good things to his Elect.

p.hi: Q. For whom are wee to pray?

div.p:
A. For our ſelues, and others: vs, and ours: In a word
1. For1. Tim. 2.1. all men, euen ourMath. 5.44. enemies, becauſe of the commonIam. 3.9. image of God, andAct. 17.26. blood of mankinde, whereof we are all made; vnleſſe it be apparent, that1. Ioh. 5.16. any one hath committed the vnpardonable ſin: butGal. 6.10. Eph. 6.18. principally for thoſe of the houſhold of faith.
2. For all 1. Tim. 2.2. ſorts and degrees of men; eſpecially publique perſons, as rulers, and ſuch as are in authority:Eph 6.19. Col 4.3. miniſters, that watch ouer our ſoules &c.

p.hi:
Q. What aſſurance haue we, that wee
ſhall be heard in what we pray for?

div.p: A. Becauſe we pray to that God, thatPſal. 65.2 heareth the Prayer, and is theHeb. 11.6. rewarder of all that come vnto him, and inIoh. 11.42 his name, to whom God denyeth nothing; and therefore howſoeuer wee are not alwaies anſwered at thePſal. 77.3 preſent, or in the2. Cor 12.9 ſame kinde, that wee deſire, yet ſooner or later, we are ſure to receiue, euen aboue that wee are able to aske, or thinke; if wee continue,Luc 11.5, &c. & 18.1. with conſtancie, patience, and importunitie, to ſue vnto him according to his will.

div.head: SECT. XXXIX. Of the Lords Prayer, the perfect forme and plat-forme of Prayer: and of the preface thereof.

p.hi: Q. VVHere is that will of God reuealed, according wherto we muſt direct our Prayers?

div.p:
A. Throughout the whole booke of the Scriptures of God; which enforme
vs, as concerning other duties, ſo eſpecially concerning this of prayer, recording alſo for this purpoſe, many excellent prayers, as of Moſes, Dauid, Nehemiah, Paul, &c. but moſt abſolutely in that paſſage, or portion, deliuered by our Sauiour himſelfe, and propounded by his holy Euangeliſts, Mathew, and Luke; by theMath. 6.9. one as the moſt perfect platforme, to be imitated; by theLuk. 11.2 other, as the moſt excellent forme, to be vſed of all Chriſtians; and therefore commonly called the Lords Prayer.

p.hi: Q. What are the words of the Lords Prayer?

div.p: A. Our Father which art in heauen, &c.

p.hi: Q. What are the parts of this Prayer?

div.p: A. They are three Viz.

list.item: 1. A preface of compellation, for entrance into Prayer, in the firſt words, Our Father which art in heauen.
2. A bodie of petitions, containing the matter of Prayer, in the words following.

3. A concluſion for confirmation and
cloſe of Prayer, in the laſt words, For thine is the kingdome &c.

p.hi: Q. To begin with the preface, why doth our Sauiour direct vs, to giue ſuch titles vnto God, in the entrance of our prayers?

div.p: A. That thereby wee may teſtifie, encreaſe, and ſtrengthen our faith in God, conſideringHeb. 11.6 what he is to vs, to whom we are about to pray.
Q. What are we to conſider from this, that we are taught to call God [Our Father?]
A. Wee are hereby directed to meditate vpon a two-ſold relation:

The firſt between our ſelues & God, who in Chriſt is become our Father, and giueth vs both theIoh 1.12. priuiledge, andGal 4.6 ſpirit of ſonnes, ſo to call him; from whence ariſeth, not onely confidence in hisPſ. 103.13 fatherly loue and compaſsion towards vs, as his children, but alſo neceſsitie of dutie, on our parts, that we bothMal. 1.6 •
honour andMat. 5.45 imitate him, as ourEpheſ. 5.1 1. Pet. 1.17 Father.

The ſecond betweene our ſelues, and ſo many as are, or may be, Children of
the ſame Father with vs; with whom therfore at all times; (Mat 5 23, •• . 1. T • m. 2.8. eſpecially when wee make our prayers) wee muſt maintaine, or renew, loue and peace: and for all whom, as for our ſelues, wee are to be ſuiters vnto our God, and Father, and they in like manner for vs; that, euery one praying for all, and all for euery one; wee may iointly encreaſe, and enioy the benefite of the common ſlocke of prayers laid vp in the hands of God.
Q. Whereto doe the words following direct vs, when wee ſay [which art in heauen?]

A. To the meditation of the glorie, powerfull prouidence, wiſedome, and holineſſe of God, in which regards hee isPſal. 11.4. Eſay 57. • 5 ſaid to dwell in the high and holy place: not that hee is excluded from, or included in any plate (whoIer 23 24 filleth all places, yea1. Kin. 8.27. whom the heauen of heauens cannot containe) but
1. Becauſe his wiſedome, power, and glorie appeareth moſt euidently in the rule of thePſ. 14.1, &c & 8.3. heauens,
as of the moſt excellent bodily creatures,Pſ. 103.19. by which inferiour natures are ruled.
2. BecauſePſ. 123.1. Col. 3.1, 2 there, and not on earth, wee ſhould now ſeek him, where alſo wee hope, another day, to dwell with him, in the ſame happy fellowſhip, which now the holy Angels, & bleſſed ſoules doe enioy.
3. To teach vs to prayEccleſ. 5.1 reuerently before him, who is ſo high aboue vs, yea feruently alſo, that our prayers may2. Chro. 32.20. aſcend into heauen.
4. That acknowledging him to ride on the heauens for our help,Pſal. 125 3 able (as in heauen) to doe for vs, whatſoeuer (as a Father) hee will, wee might, with full confidence in his power and loue, askePſal. 2.8 Luc. 11.13 euery good thing of him.

div.head: SECT. XL. Of the firſt Petition.

p.hi: Q. TO come to the body, and matter of prayer; How many Petitions are there in the Lords Prayer?

div.p: A. Six; wherof the three firſt are referred to things concerning GOD,Ioh. 12.27, 28. whoſe glory & ſeruice we are to preferre before our own good: the three latter, to things concerning our ſelues,Pſa. 50.15. which wee muſt refer to the former.

p.hi: Q. To begin therefore with thoſe that concerne God; What are the words of the firſt Petition?
A.
Hallowed be thy Name.
Q. What is the meaning of theſe words?
A

list.item:
1. By the Name of God wee are to vnderſtand GodEſay 26.8 himſelfe, as he maketh knowne to vs the fame, & glorie of his nature, otherwiſeGen. 32.29 vnconceiueable, whether by his
Exod. 3 14▪ & 6.3. Titles, as Iehouah, Elohim, &c. orExo. 33.28, 19. &c. & 34.5, 6. &c. Attributes, as of loue, wiſedome, power, iuſtice, &c. which being eſſentiall in him, are for our capacitie, expreſſed vnder
the names of ſuch qualities in vs: or
Memorials, as his workes ofPſal. 104. creation, and prouidence, but eſpeciallyPſal. 19.14 redemption: or hisPſa. 138.2. & 19.7. &c word (and worſhip) which is the booke of grace, and the box of ointment, out of which the ſweetCant. 1.2 ſauour of his name, is moſt effectually powred.

2. By [hallowing] wee muſt vnderſtand, the ſeparating of the name of God, from all profane and vnholy abuſe: not by adding any holineſſe thereto, but byPſal. 96.8. acknowledging and honouring it for ſuch; whereby wee doe, as it were, ſet the crowne of holineſse & honour vpon the head of God.

Contrariwiſe, failing ſo to do, we are guilty of the profanation of Gods holy name: not that he can receiue any pollution from vs, but onely as the man, that lusteth after a chaſt woman, is ſaid, by ourMat 5.28. Sauiour, to bee guiltie of adultery with her, though ſhee
remaine, in her ſelfe, ſpotleſſe, and vndefiled.

p.hi: Q. What doe wee then aske of God in this Petition?

div.p: A. Two things, Viz.

list.item: 1. That he wold vouchſafe to plant, & encreaſe in vs, & others, ſuch graces wherby his name may be glorified, asPſal. 100.3 & 67. • . knowledge of God,Pſa. 115.1. humilitie, thankfulnes, patience: Pſ. 51.15 & 45.1. lips opened, and tongues tuned to ſpeak of him with reuerence: Finally aMat. 5.16 1. Pet. 2. • Tit. 2.10 life ſo ordered, that men may ſay, hee is an holy God, who, by his grace, maketh vs an holy people.

2. That he would remoue, & root out of our hearts, tongues, & liues, all ſuch vices, by and for which his name is diſhonoured, asPro 8.13 pride, profanenes, Hoſ. 8.12 ignorance, infidelity, Rom. 1.21 vnthankfulnes, impatience &c. thoſe tongue-wormes ofExod. 20.7 ſwearing, blaſphemie, & vnreuerent ſpeaking of him: FinallyRo 2.23, 24 euill and ſcandalous life, for which the name of God, and his religion, is euill ſpoken of in the world.

div.head: SECT. XLI. Of the ſecond Petition.

p.hi: Q. VVHat are the words of the ſecond Petition?
A.
Thy Kingdome come.
Q. What is the meaning of theſe words?

div.p: A. Firſt by the Kingdome of God we muſt vnderſtand, not thatEſ • . 6.5. Pſa. 95.3. &c. vniuerſall ſoueraignety which, as Creator, he exerciſeth ouer all creatures, diſpoſing them all vnto their proper ends for his glorie: but thePſal. 110.2 1. Cor. 15.25 ſpirituall regiment of the Church (and of all things for the good of the Church) wherein God hath appointedPſal. 2.6. Hoſ. 3.5. Chriſt to be the King, theR • uel. 15.3. ſaints his ſubiects, theJob 22.22. word his law, theHeb. 1.6. Angels, and all creatures his ſeruants, the2. Cor. 5.20 Miniſters his Heralds, and Embaſſadors: finally theMat. 12.26. diuels kingdome, that is, wicked Angels, and men (Luc. 19 27. enemies to the Kingdome of Chriſt) hisPſal. 110.1. footſtoole.

Secondly this Kingdome is ſaid to come,
1 In regard of meanes, where theMath 12.28, & 13 19. Mat. 1.15. word of the Kingdome is publiſhed.
2 In regard of efficacy, whereRom. 6.17. from the heart obedience is yeelded.
3 In regard of perfection it hath theſe degrees: Viz.
Math. 13.8.Encreaſe of grace in the time of this life:
TheLuc. 23.42 43. tranſlation of bleſſed ſoules into heauen, in the moment of death:
Finally theMat. 25.34 full redemption, and glorification of the Saints, in ſoule and body, in the life to come.

p.hi: Q. What things doe wee then craue of God, in this petition?

div.p: A. Six things, viz.

list.item:
1 That SatansAct. 26.18. Kingdome may be aboliſhed, the2. Tim. 2.26. Coloſſ. 1.13. bonds of ſpirituall captiuity looſed, theGal. 5.24. power of corruption, that maketh vs like well of our bondage, abated, the2. Theſſ. 2.8 inſtruments of Satans tyranny
(as the Turke, and Pope, and all ſuch outlawes from Chriſt) defeated.

2. That the word of the Kingdome, the rod and
〈◊〉 . 110.2. 〈…〉
• 2. Theſ • . 3.1 ſtandard of Chriſts power, may haue2. Theſſ. 3.1 free paſſage euery where, and bee gloriouſly lifted vp & aduanced.

3. That the eies of all men, eſpecially Princes, may be opened to ſee theReu. l. 17. • 1 • . filthines of the whore of Babilon, and the true
〈◊〉 . • 0.5 beauty of the pure religion, & ſpouſe of Chriſt.

4. That allEſa. 56.10. ••
loiterers, and tonguetied Miniſters remoued,M th 9.38. faithfull and able watchmen may be ſet ouer the flocke of Chriſt, with ſufficient encouragement of maintenance, countenance, protection &c.

5. That the Lord, by his word and ſpirit, wouldCol. 3.15, 1 • . rule in the hearts and liues of his Saints; making them alſo Kings, in part, by ouercomming the corruption,
which is in the world through luſt.

6. That he would finiſh the kingdome of grace, Gen. 9.27. calling his elect vncalled,2. Theſſ. 2.17. confirming ſuch as ſtand,Iam. 5.15, 16. raiſing the fallen,Eſa. 61.3. comforting the afflicted &c. and haſten the kingdome of glory, both byPhil. 1.23. taking vs in due time out of this conflicting life, into peace with Chriſt, and finally ſending his Sonne theReuel. 22.20. ſecond time for the full ſaluation of vs, and all his choſen, that hee hauing reigned in vs by grace, we may euerlaſtingly2. Tim. 2.12. reigne with him in glory.

div.head: SECT. XLII. Of the third Petition.

p.hi: Q. VVHat are the words of the third petition?
A.
Thy will be done on earth as it is in heauen.
Q. What is the meaning of theſe words?

div.p: A. Firſt, by this word [thy] wee exclude all wils oppoſed to, or diuers from, the will of God: whether the will of2. Tim. 2.26. Satan, or our1. Pet 4.2. owne, naturally corrupt, and enthralled to Satan; yea whatſoeuer2. Sam 7.2, &c. Iam. 4 15. lawfull intentions or deſires, repugnant to the will of God.

Secondly, by the [wil] of God we here vnderſtand, not ſo muchDeut. 29.29 that part, which he keepeth ſecret from vs, as his eternal counſell, thePro. 27.1. euents of outward things,Act. 1.7. times and ſeaſons &c. which it is vnlawfull to enquire into, impoſsible to know, or to withſtand, andAct. 4 28. no thanke for vs to accompliſh, vnto which we muſt onely with patience and contentmentAct. 21.14. ſubmit our ſelues: as that part thereof, which isDeut. 29.29 reueiled, and made knowne vnto vs in the word, both in the promiſes, which we are to beleeue, and in the precepts, which (as conditions of obedience, in way of thankſgiuing, annexed vnto the promiſes) we are to performe.

Thirdly, by [doing] wee vnderſtand, not a good intent only in the
heart, or aMat. 21.30 profeſsion of obedience in word and pretence: but an actuall and throughJam. 1.25. performance of what is required of vs.

Fourthly, where we ſay, [in earth as in heauen] we propound to our ſelues the patternes of thePſal. 103.20, & 22 Angels and bleſſed ſoules, who being freed from all mixture of corruption, doe, in their kind, perfectly obey God; whom therfore we deſire to imitate in the maner, though wee know we cannot equall them in meaſure, and degree of obedience.

p.hi: Q. What doe wee then aske of God in this Petition?

div.p: A. Three things. viz.

list.item: 1. That all wils of wickedZech. 3.2. Angels andPſal. 140.8. men, as contrary to the will of God, may bee diſappointed.

2. That in vs,Pſal. 119.18 ignorance of the reueiled will of God,1. Sam. 15.22, 23. rebellion, diſobedience, murmuring, &c. being remooued, all pretences and diſpenſations, or powers, preſuming to diſpence with
the wil of God, diſclaimed, and our hearts by gracePſal. 119.32. ſet at large, ſtrengthened, andVerſ. 36. directed, wee may both know, and obey the will of our heauenly Father and Lord.

3 That, for the manner of performance, we may, (after the heauenly patterne aforementioned)Pſal 110.3. willingly without conſtraint, or repugnancy,Pſal. 119 60. ſpeedilte without delay,Deut 5.28, 29. ſincerelie without hypocriſie,Pſal. 119.6. fully without reſeruation, &Verſ. 112. conſtantly without intermiſsion, beleeue the promiſes of mercie, and obey the precepts of holineſſe.

div.head: SECT. XLIII. Of the fourth Petition.

p.hi: Q. THus farre of the three firſt petitions for things concerning God: To come to the three latter concerning our ſelues; What are we generally to note in them?

div.p:
A. The order & dependance they haue
1. From the former three concerning God: for we are then allowed, andLuc. 17.7. &c. not til then, to ſeeke good things for our ſelues, when wee haue firſt minded & ſought thoſe things that concerne the glory of God; becauſe vnto1. Tim. 4.8. godlineſſe only the promiſes of this life, and that which is to come, are entailed.
2. Betweene themſelues; wherein is to be obſerued,
Firſt, that we haue but one petition for outward things, as leſſe to be eſteemed: but for ſpirituall things two, as aboutMat 6.33. which, our care is to bee doubled.
Secondly, that yet the firſt place is giuen to outward things; not as chiefeſt, but asGen. 28.20.21. helps to enable vs to ſpirituall duties, and as ſteppes Act. 17.27, 28. whereby our weak faith may the better aſcend to lay claime & hold on ſpirituall graces.
Thirdly, that, according to the
order obſerued in the Creed, (called the Apoſtles) we are taught to depend:
On the prouidence of God the Father, our Creator, for outward bleſſings:
On the mercy of Chriſt, our Sauiour, for the remiſſion of our ſinnes:
On the powerfull aſsiſtance of the holy Spirit, our ſanctifier, for the reſiſting and ſubduing of al temptations vnto euill.
Laſtly, that in all theſe petitions, vnder one thing expreſſed, other things are figuratiuely included, as ſhall appeare.

p.hi: Q. To proceed in order: What are the words of the fourth petition?
A.
Giue vs this day our dailie bread.
Q. What is the meaning of theſe words?

div.p:
A. Firſt, by [bread] we muſt vnderſtandPro. 27.27 & 31.14. all outward things, ſeruing for
our neceſsitie, and ſober delight, as foode, phyſicke, ſleepe, raiment, houſe, &c. together with the meanes thereof, as peace, ſeaſonable weather, and ſuch like.

Secondly, by [daily] bread, or bread [inſtātly neceſſary] or [ſuch as is to be added to our ſubſtance] we vnderſtand ſuch prouiſion, and ſuch a proportion thereof, as may beſtPro. 30.8 agree with our nature, charge, and calling.
Thirdly, by [our] bread, we vnderſtand2. Theſ. 3.12. ſuch, as commeth to vs by the bleſsing of God on our lawfull labours, ſo that neither God, nor man, can iuſtly implead vs for it.

Fourthly, when wee ſay, [giue] we profeſſe our ſeluesLuk. 17.10 Gen. 32.10. vnable, by any ſeruice or labour, to merit our bread (much leſſe our ſaluation) at the hands of God; but that, our right vnto the creatures beeing forfeited in Adam, wee haue nothing to plead, but onely Gods deed of gift, made vnto vs in Chriſt, the ſecond Adam, andHeb. 1.2. heire of all things;Rom. 8.32 in whom and with whom all things are conueyed to vs.

Fiftly, when we ſay giue [vs] wee profeſſe our ſelues petitioners for all men, eſpecially the houſhold of faith; that for the moſt part euery one may haue ſufficient, and, where want is,2. Cor. 8.14. others may bee enabled to ſupply it out of their abundance.

Laſtly, when we ſay [this day] or [for the day] we profeſſe theMath. 6.34 moderation of our care, and deſire of earthly things, with our purpoſe euery day by labour and prayer, to ſeeke theſe bleſſings at the hands of God.

p.hi: Q. What doe we then begge of God in this Petition?

div.p: A. Two things: Viz.

Firſt, bread: Iam. 4.3. Num. 11.4, 5, 6. not quailes, or delicates, not riches, and ſuperfluitie; but a proportion of maintenance, credit, libertie &c.Pro. 30 8 1. Tim 6.8 conuenient for vs: and that with condition, Jam. 4.15 2 Sam 7.27 if God ſhall ſee good, which is a caution proper to this Petition for outward things,

Secondly, faith and grace, as well inPhil. 4.12 want, as in abundance, to depend on the prouidence of God for outward things: to beeHeb. 13.5 contented with, and
thankefull for, the portion which it ſhall pleaſe the Lord toPſal. 16.6 meaſure out vnto vs, as his gift; not enuying ſuch, to whom hee giueth more: toEpheſ. 4.28 labour with our hands the thing that is goo • , that wee may eate our owne bread: to adde vnto our labor1. Tim. 4.4, 5 prayer, and thankſgiuing, as whereby, on our part, all Gods bleſſings are aſſured, and ſanctified vnto vs: Finally toPhil. 4.6 Pſal. 37.5 containe our ſelues within the care for the meanes, leauing euents vnto Gods only diſpoſition.

div.head: SECT. XLIIII. Of the fift Petition.

p.hi: Q. VVHat are the words of the fift Petition?

div.p: A. Mat. 6.12 Luk. 11.4 And forgiue vs our debts, as euen we forgiue our debtors: where, beſides the petition, is a reaſon added for confirmation thereof.

p.hi: Q. What is the meaning of the words?

div.p:
A. Firſt, by [debts] we muſt vnderſtand
ſinnes (as Saint Luke expoundeth the metaphor,) and that not in themſelues, as breaches of the Law of God (for who would ſay that wee owe and are to pay ſinne vnto God?) but with reſpect to the puniſhment, and ſatisfaction, due to Gods iuſtice for the offence of ſinnes. For our debt properly beingRom. 8.12. & 13.8. Gal. 5.3 obedience, whereto we were bound vnder penaltie of all the curſes of the Law, eſpecially eternall death; we all in Adam forfeited that bond, whereby theLuc. 13.4. Mat. 18.24 &c. Rom. 6.23 penaltie became our debt, and is daily encreaſed in vs all by ſinning.
