Let my reioicing be, not that I haue deluded the world with a fained ſhew of holineſſe and integritie, but that in ſimplicitie and godly pureneſſe I haue had my
conuerſation among men, as in thy ſight. Renew my youth, O LORD, as the Eagle, not to the ſeruice of ſinne, but of thy name. Let it bee my meate and drinke to doe thy will, and let my hunger after it bee ſo great, that it may breake through all the ſtone walles of impediments and diſcouragements thereto. Yea the more I am diſcouraged, and withdrawne from dutie, by the practiſes of Satan, and the weakeneſſe of my fleſh, the more let mee ſtriue thereto, and abound therein, that Satan finding himſelfe a looſer, may bee forced to giue ouer his aſſaults. Let mee bee ſo farre from wearineſſe in thy ſeruice in the time of proſperitie, as I would thou ſhouldeſt bee from neglecting mee in the houre of neceſsitie. Let thy loue toward mee, O Father, winne mee to the loue of thee, and let my loue to thee conſtraine mee, euen with deniall of my ſelfe, to ſerue thee. Teach mee to looke for all good things

from thee, by the meanes of IESVS CHRIST, and in him to offer vp my daily ſacrifices vnto thee. Diſperſe in mee the clouds of ſinne, that my heart as in a cleare day, may alwaies behold thee. Let all worldly ioyes bee ſwallowed vp in mee, with the ioy of thy holy Spirit: and before all peace, let mee preferre the peace of a good conſcience: Let mee reioyce in thee without lightneſſe, and mourne for mine owne, and others ſinnes, without diſcouragement. Powre vppon mee thy Spirit of grace and ſupplication, that I may call vpon thee with ſighes that cannot bee expreſſed, that cannot bee denied: that with this key I may open the treaſurie of thy goodneſſe, and enrich my ſelfe. Make mee a meete gueſt to ſit downe at the marriage feaſt of the Lambe, and graunt that I may bee carefull not to bee found without the wedding garment of faith working by loue. Let mee keepe a diligent account of what I receiue
from thee, and remembring that there ſhall bee a day of reckoning, graunt mee ſo to gouerne my ſelfe in the employing of thy talents, that both thou maiſt receiue of me thine owne with aduantage, and I, beeing found faithfull in little, may bee made ruler ouer much. Let mee account this terme of life, a ſeede time, and let mee not doubt to caſt my bread vpon the waters, ſeeing at the end of dayes I ſhall finde it againe. Let me not eſteeme my ſelfe the poorer for beſtowing vpon thy needie ſeruants, but let mee thinke that as the corne which is ſowen, remaineth not in the ground, but returneth with encreaſe to the ſower, ſo what I giue in thy name ſhall not remaine with the receiuer, but returne vnto mee with aduantage. Make mee willing to beſtow, and to bee beſtowed, for the good of thy Saints: and withall humble, to aſcribe both the gift, and the willingneſſe to giue, to thy grace onely. Graunt, good Lord,
that beeing a pilgrim vpon earth, I may haue my conuerſation in heauen: and profeſſing my ſelfe to bee a citizen of that Ieruſalem, which is from aboue, I may deſire not onely to enioy the priuiledges, but alſo to ſpeake the language, and to bee gouerned by the lawes of that Citie. Make mee wiſe, O Lord, to vnderſtand and conſider my latter end. Let my whole life bee a preparation to death, and the meditation of death, the rule of my life. O Lord, guide my heart to the loue of thy Maieſtie, and the waiting for of thy Sonne. Vnto mine old age, and gray head, O God forſake mee mee not: and let thy feare keepe mee from forſaking thee. Let mee bee among thoſe, that are planted in thine houſe, and flouriſh in thy Courts. Let mee bring forth more fruit in mine age. Let my later dayes bee my beſt daies, and my workes more at the laſt, then at the firſt. Finally, enable mee in this pilgrimage of my life, ſo to walke from
ſtrength to ſtrength, that at the length I may appeare before thee, with the Congregation of the firſt borne, in that kingdome of glorie, which thou haſt prepared for all that loue the appearance of thy Sonne our Lord Ieſus Chriſt. To whom, with thee, O Father, and thy Spirit, bee all honour and obedience, in the Church, hence forth, and for euer. Amen.
A BRIEFE DIRECTION TO TRVE HAPPINESSE.
ABRIDGED OVT OF the larger Treatiſe, for the more conuenient vſe of priuate Families, and inſtruction of the yonger ſort.
By SAM. CROOKE.

q.p: Traine vp [or Catechiſe] a Child in the way he ſhould goe: and when he is old, he will not depart from it.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by John Pindley, for Nathaniel Butler, and are to be ſold at his ſhop neere S. Auſtins gate, at the ſigne of the Pyed Bull. 1613.

div.head: A BRIEFE DIRECTION TO TRVE HAPPINESSE.
SECT. I. Of the Scripture.
div.p: Queſtion. HOw may a man attaine true bleſſedneſſe?
Anſ. Onely byJob. 22.21, 22. acquaintance, and fellowſhip with God, as hee offereth himſelfe to bee kn • wne of vs, in hisJoh. 6.68. word.

p.hi: Q. What meane you by the word of God?

div.p: A. The holy2. Tim. 3.25, 16. Scriptures of the old and new Teſtament, giuen by inſpiration of God.

div.head: SECT. II. Of God.

p.hi: Q. HOw doe the Scriptures propound God to be knowne of vs?

div.p: A. Partly in himſelfe, partly in his workes.

p.hi: Q. What doe the Scriptures teach vs touching God himſelfe?

div.p:
A. Foure things: and firſt thatHeb. 11. •
there is a God.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſecond thing?

div.p: A. That God is aIoh. 4.24 ſpirit, moſt ſimple, eternall, infinite, conſtant and abſolute.

p.hi: Q. What is the third thing?

div.p: A. That there is onely1. Cor. 8.6. me God, and no more.

p.hi: Q. What is the fourth thing?

div.p: A. That in this one Godhead areMat. 28.19. 1. Joh. 5.7. three diſtinct perſons, the Father, the Sonne, and the Holy Ghoſt.

div.head: SECT. III. Of Gods decree.

p.hi: Q. VVHat are the workes of God?

div.p:
A. They areEpheſ. 1.11
1. His decree, and
2. The execution thereof.

p.hi: Q. How may wee take a view of theſe workes of God?

div.p: A. Generally in all creatures; ſpecially in Angels, and men.

p.hi: Q. What did God decree concerning all creatures?

div.p: A. ThatRo. 11.3, 6. Pro. 16 4. all things ſhould ſerue vnto his glorie.

p.hi: Q. What did God decree touching Angels and men?

div.p: A. 1. Tim. 5. • 1 Mat 25.41. 1. Theſ 5.9. Ro. 9.22, 23 That they ſhould remaine for euer, ſome in honour, others in diſhonour, for his glorie.

div.head: SECT. IIII. Of Creation.

p.hi: Q. HOw doth God execute his decree?

div.p: A. By two Actions: to wit, Creation, and Prouidence.

p.hi: Q. What is Creation?

div.p: A. TheGen. 1. whol • . making of all things of nothing, very good, in the firſt ſixe dayes of the world.

p.hi: Q. How did God create Angels?

div.p: A. HeCol. 1.16 made them all, at the firſt, very good, and glorious ſpirits; yetJob 4.18 mutable.

p.hi: Q. How did God create man?

div.p: A. HeGen. 29 made him a liuing ſoule, framing his bodie of the dust of the earth, and breathing in his face the breath of life.

div.head: SECT. V. Of Prouidence.

p.hi: Q. VVHat is prouidence?

div.p:
A. The continuall
Pſ. 213.6 care, that God hath of all his creatures, for the ſuſtaining, and diſpoſing of them, as they may beſtPſal. 119.91 ſerue for his glorie.

p.hi: Q. How doth God ſuſtaine Angels?

div.p: A. They are all vpheld by the power of God, ſo that they ſhallLuk. 20.36 neuer llye, nor returne to nothing.

p.hi: Q. How doth God ſuſtaine men?

div.p: A. He preſerueth mankinde in generall, by the bleſsing ofGen. 1.28 procreation: and particular men and women, both for thePſal. 36.6. time of this life, and forMat. 25.46. euer in the world to come.

p.hi: Q. How doth God diſpoſe of Angels?

div.p:
A. Hee ſuffered2. Pet. 2.4 ſome to fall, by ſinne, into damnation without recouerie, called Diuels: the reſt heeMat. 28.20. conf • rmeth in their firſt bleſſed eſtate, called Angels of light: both which hee
• ob 1.6. employeth for the accompliſhing of his will.

div.head: SECT. VI. Of the ſtate of Innocencie.

p.hi: Q. HOw doth GOD diſpoſe of man?

div.p: A. As of that creature, inPſa. 8.3, &c whom, aboue the reſt, hee intendeth to ſet forth his glorie; wherefore the Scriptures doe plentifully declare the dealing of GOD with man, both in this world, and for euer hereafter.

p.hi: Q. How doe the Scriptures ſet forth the dealing of God with man in this world?

div.p: A. In a threefold eſtate, to wit, of Innocencie, of Corruption and miſery, and of Redemption; all which make way vnto that euerlaſting eſtate of honour or diſhonour, fore-appointed vnto all men.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſtate of Innocencie?

div.p:
A. The holy and happy condition of mankinde, created in theGen 1.27 image of God, and placed by him inGen. 2.8 Paradiſe,
with abilitie to attaine to bleſſedneſſe by the Couenant of workes.

p.hi: Q. What is the Couenant of workes?

div.p: A. TheGe. 2.16, 17 ſubſtance of the Law, written in the hearts of our firſt parents, promiſing bleſſedneſſe, if they ſhould obey, and threatning death, if they ſhould tranſgreſſe.

div.head: SECT. VII. Of the Fall.

p.hi: Q. VVHat is the ſtate of corruption and miſerie?

div.p: A. The fearefull condition of ſinne, and death, wherein to God ſuffered all mankinde, in Adam, toGe. 3.1, &c fall, through the temptation of Satan, by breaking the Couenant of workes.

div.head: SECT. VIII. Of Sinne.

p.hi: Q. VVHat is Sinne?

div.p:
A. 1. Ioh. 3.9 A ſweruing from the
Law of God, making the ſinnerGen. 4.7. g •••
tie of the curſe of the Law: and it 〈◊〉 either originall, or actuall.

p.hi: Q. Wherein doth originall ſinne conſiſt?

div.p: A. In vtterRom. 7.18 enmitie of our whole nature vnto all that is good, andRom. 7.14 proueneſſe vnto all euill.

p.hi: Q. What is Actuall ſinne?

div.p: A. EueryRom. 5.14 particular breach of the Law of God.

div.head: SECT. IX. Of Death.

p.hi: Q. VVHat is Death?

div.p:
A. It is the ſeparation Gen. 3.19 either of the ſoule from the body, 2. Theſ. 1. •
or of ſoule and body from God; with all euils that attend on the one, or the other.

p.hi: Q. How doth God employ men in this ſtate of Corruption?

div.p:
A. Two waies: and firſt by theJoh. 1.9. light of nature, andEſay 44.28 common graces,
reſtraining many from groſſe ſinnes, and guiding ſome vnto actions profitable for humane ſocietie, and for the outward ſeruice of God.

p.hi: Q. How ſecondly?

div.p: A. By ouer-ruling mens euill and ſinfull actions, ſo that thereby theyAct. 4.27, 28. bring to paſſe nothing, but what God hath determined for his owne glorie.

p.hi: Q. Doth God leaue all mankinde in this ſtate of ſinne and death?

div.p: A. No: but onely the reprobate, whom heeAct. 14.16. ſuffereth to runne on in ſinne, and ſo vnto damnation deſeruedly.

div.head: SECT. X. Of Redemption by the Couenant of grace.
div.p: Q. WHat is the ſtate of Redemption?
A. TheRo. 3.23.24 recouerie of the Elect out of the ſtate of ſinne and death, by the new Couenant of grace.
Q. What is the Couenant of grace?
A. GodsGal. 3.21, 22 ſecond contract with mankinde, after the fall, for the reſtoring of him vnto his fauour, and happineſſe, by the meanes of a Mediator.
Q. What are wee to conſider in the Couenant of Grace?
A. Two things: whereof the firſt is the foundation of it, to wit, the Mediator.

div.head: SECT. XI. Of Chriſt the Mediator.

p.hi: Q. VVHo is the Mediator betweene God and man?

div.p: A. Onely1. Tim. 1.5 Ieſus Chriſt, God, and man.
Q. How is he God?
A. In that hee is the1. Ioh. 5.20 ſecond perſon in Trinitie, to wit, the eternall Sonne of the Father.
Q. How is hee man?

A. ByIoh. 1.14 taking our fleſh into his perſon, beeing miraculouſlyLuk. 1.35 conceiued
by the holy Ghoſt, and borne of the bleſſed Virgin Mary.

p.hi: Q. How is he the mediator between God and man?

div.p: A. By becoming our Prophet, Prieſt, and King.

p.hi: Q. How is he our Prophet?

div.p: A. ByJoh. 17.26. reuealing vnto vs the will of God.

p.hi: Q. How is he our Prieſt?

div.p: A. ByEph. 2.1 • . 2. Cor. 5.28. appeaſing, and reconciling God vnto vs, through his death, and obedience.

p.hi: Q. How is he our King?

div.p: A. ByEſa. 9.7. gouerning all things, for the ſaluation of his Elect, andPſal. 45.5. deſtruction of his enemies.

div.head: SECT. XII. Of the myſticall vnion.

p.hi: Q. VVHat is the ſecond thing to be conſidered in the Couenant of Grace?

div.p:
A. The application thereof to the
elect, giuing themHeb. 3.24. part in Chriſt, and in all his benefits.

p.hi: Q. What part haue the elect in Chriſt?

div.p: A. They haue firſt vnion with Chriſt, and ſecondly thereby Communion.

p.hi: Q. How are the elect vnited vnto Chriſt?

div.p: A. They areEph. 5.30. knit vnto Chriſt the head, as members of his myſticall bodie, by the ſpirit of Chriſt, and by faith.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſpirit of Chriſt?

div.p: A. The power of the holy Ghoſt,Rom. 8.9. Gal. 5.25. abiding, and working in all thoſe that are Chriſts, as the ſoule of ſpirituall life.

p.hi: Q. What is faith?

div.p: A. The firſt effect of the ſpirit of Chriſt,Eph. • .16, 17. diſpoſing vs to cleaue to him, and the inſtrument, whereby all graces are begun, and increaſed in vs.

div.head: SECT. XIII. Of the Goſpell.

p.hi: Q. VVHat is our communion with Chriſt?

div.p: A. The participation of the benefits, flowing from his ſeueral offices.

p.hi: Q. What benefite receiue wee from the Propheticall office of Chriſt?

div.p: A. TheMath. 11.27 reuelation of the Couenant of grace, whereby we are made2. Tim. 3.15 wiſe vnto ſaluation.

p.hi: Q. What meanes doth God vſe for the reuealing of this couenant?

div.p: A. The meanes are of two ſorts. Viz. outward, and inward.

p.hi: Q. What are the outward meanes?

div.p: A. The word, and the Sacraments.

p.hi: Q. What meane you by the word?

div.p:
A. TheEph. 1.13. Goſpell preached, which
• ontaineth, and publiſheth, the promiſes of ſaluation by Chriſt.

div.head: SECT. XIIII. Of Sacraments.

p.hi: Q. VVHat are Sacraments?

div.p: A. Rom. 4.11. Seales, annexed by God to the word of his Grace,Gal. 3.27. aſſuring our part in Chriſt, andRom. 6.4. binding vs vnto him in obedience.

p.hi: Q. What Sacraments are there of the Couenant of Grace?

div.p: A. They be of two ſorts: Viz: ſome of the old Teſtament, before Chriſt, others of the new, vnder Chriſt.

p.hi: Q. What were thoſe Sacraments of the old Teſtament?

div.p: A. Two: Viz: Gen. 17.10. Circumciſion, for entrance into the Couenant; and theExod. 22.3, &c. Paſſeouer, for continuance, and confirmation therein.

p.hi: Q. How many Sacraments are there of the new Teſtament?

div.p:
A. Two likewiſe? Viz: Baptiſme, for entrance, and the Lords Supper, fo •
confirmation, in the ſame Couenant.

div.head: SECT. XV. Of Baptiſme.

p.hi: Q. VVHat is Baptiſme?

div.p: A. The ſeale of ourTit. 3.5. new birth, and entrance into the Couenant of Grace.

p.hi: Q. What are the parts of this Sacrament?

div.p:
A. They are two; namely, firſt theEph 5. • 6▪
element of water, with the action of dipping, or ſprinkling the partie baptiſed,Math. 28.19. In the Name of the Father, the Sonne, and the holy Ghoſt.

p.hi: Q. What is the other part?

div.p:
A. TheHeb. 9.14. blood, and1. Cor. 6.2 •
Spirit of Chriſt; waſhing away, both theAct. 2.38. guilt, andEzek. 36.25 Rom. • .2.3, &c. filthineſſe of our ſinnes.

p.hi: Q. Who are to be baptiſed?

div.p:
A. Whoſoeuer belong to the Couenant; whetherAct. 8.37. of riper yeares, con
• erted to the faith, or1. Cor. 7.14. children of Chriſtian parents.

div.head: SECT. XVI. Of the Lords Supper.

p.hi: Q. VVHat is the Lords ſupper?

div.p: A. The ſeale of ourEph. 4.26. ſpirituall nouriſhment, and grouth in the bodie of Chriſt.

p.hi: Q. What are the parts of this Sacrament?

div.p: A. Two, Viz: Firſt theMat. 26.26, 27. elements of bread, and wine, diſtributed, and receiued, according to Chriſts inſtitution.

p.hi: Q. What is the other part?

div.p: A. TheMat. 26.26, 27, 28. bodie and blood of Chriſt, giuen by God, and receiued of vs by faith, for theJoh. 6.54. nouriſhing of our ſoules in ſpirituall life.

p.hi: Q. Who are to receiue this Sacrament?

div.p: A. Such, as profeſsing the true faith of Chriſt, haue duely1. Cor. 1.28. prepared themſelues.

p.hi: Q. How ought wee to prepare o •• ſelues?

div.p:
A. By examining, and ſtirring vp
in our ſelues three notable graces.

p.hi: Q. What is the firſt?

div.p: A. Knowledge of the will of God; eſpecially touching the matter of the Sacrament,1. Cor. 11.29 that wee be able to diſcerne the Lords body.

p.hi: Q. Which is theſe ſecond?

div.p: A.2. Cor. 13.5. 1. Tim. 1.15 Faith, to apply the promiſes of ſaluation vnto our ſelues in particular.

p.hi: Q. Which is the third?

div.p: A.Zech. 12.10. Jam. 4. • . Repentance of our ſinnes paſt, with true1. Cor. 16.14. loue of God, and of our Brethren.

p.hi: Q. How ought wee to receiue this Sacrament?

div.p: A. In a reuerent, and thankefull 1. Cor. 11.24, 25, 26. remembrance of the loue of Chriſt, who gaue himſelfe for vs: with deſire to2. Pet. 3.18. grow in faith, and all holy graces.

div.head: SECT. XVII. Of the ſpirit and faith.

p.hi: Q. WHat are the inward means, whereby God reuealeth his Couenant of Grace?

div.p: A. They are 2. Viz: the ſpirit, & faith.
Q. What is here meant by the ſpirit?
A. A ſpeciall effect of the Spirit of Chriſt,Rom. 8.16. bearing witnes with our ſpirits, that we are, in Chriſt, the children of God.

p.hi: Q. What is here meant by faith?

div.p: A. That ſpeciall act of faith, whereby wee1. Joh. 5.10. Joh. 3.33. giue credit vnto the report of the word and ſpirit of Chriſt, touching our ſaluation in particular.

div.head: SECT. XVIII. Of Ʋocation.

p.hi: Q. VVHat is the māner of reuealing the Couenāt of Grace?

div.p: A. It is ourRom. 8.30. Vocation and Calling • when God, by the meanes aforeſaid, inuiteth men to come vnto him in Chriſt, for ſaluation.

p.hi: Q. Are there not different kinds of Calling?

div.p:
A. Yes: forMath. 22.14. many are called outwardly, who are not choſen: but the Elect arePſal. 65.4. effectually perſwaded to
• lea • e vnto Chriſt.

div.head: SECT. XIX. Of the Church.

p.hi: Q. To whom doth God reueale his Couenant of Grace?

div.p: A. Joh. 14.22. Not to the world; but to his Church, called out of the world.

p.hi: Q. What meane you by the Church?

div.p: A. TheEph. 5.32. 1. Cor. 1.9. whole number of Gods Elect, effectually called into fellowſhip with Chriſt.

p.hi: Q. Where is this Church of God?

div.p: A. Part alreadyReuel▪ 7.14. &c. triumphant in heauen; part as yetReuel. 12.11. militant on earth, in the ſeruice, and warfare of the Lord Ieſus.

p.hi: Q. Who are mēbers of the Church militāt?

div.p: A. As many as are liuing Eph. 1.22, 23. members of the myſticall bodie of Chriſt.

p.hi: Q. How may we know them?

div.p: A. Not by the inward graces (2. Tim. 2.19 onely knowne to God) whereby they are inuiſible to vs, but by the markes of viſible profeſsion.

p.hi: Q. What are the true markes of viſible profeſsion?

div.p: A. The outward meanes appointed by God for the calling and gathering of his Saints: viz. Mat. 28.19, 20. the word preached, and Sacraments duely adminiſtred.

p.hi: Q. Are we to ioyne with all Churches, that haue theſe markes?

div.p: A. Phil. 1.18 Cant. 1.5 Yea; neither muſt wee ſeparate from any, farther then they ſeparate from Chriſt.

p.hi: Q. What diſtinction is there of the particular members of a Church?

div.p: A. Though all be the ſheepe and familie of Chriſt; yet1 Cor. 12.2 • . Luk. 12.42 ſome are ſet-ouer the reſt to feede them with the foode of life, as the Miniſters: andPſ. 78.71, 72 others to rule and order them outwardly, as the Magiſtrates.

div.head: SECT. XX. Of Iuſtification.

p.hi: Q. VVHat benefite receiue we from the Prieſtly office of Chriſt?

div.p: A. OurRom. 8.30 Iuſtification before God, through his Phil. 3.9. righteouſnes, imputed vnto vs, and apprehended by vs.

p.hi: Q. What righteouſneſſe of Chriſt is imputed to vs?

div.p: A. Heb. 7.26 The abſolute integritie of our humane nature, in him our head, performing perfect obedience vnto the whole Law of God; both byMat. 3.15 doing whatſoeuer was required of vs, and by1. Pet. 2.24 ſuffering what wee deſerued by ſinning.

p.hi: Q. Who imputeth the righteouſneſſe of Chriſt vnto vs?

div.p: A. God, 2. Cor. 5.19. who in Chriſt reconcileth the world to himſelfe, not imputing their ſinnes vnto them.

p.hi: Q. How is this righteouſnes of Chriſt apprehended of vs?

div.p:
A. Onely by Rom. 5.1. & 10.10. faith, which as the hand
of the ſoule, taketh hold on Chriſt, The Ier. 23.6 Lord our righteouſneſſe.

p.hi: Q. What gaine wee, being thus iuſtified?

div.p: A. OurAct. 13.38, • 9. ſinnes are pardoned, theEphe. 1.6 fauour, and kingdome of God is purchaſed for vs, and wee admitted, as a1. Pet. 2.5. ſpirituall Prieſthood, to offer the ſacrifices of obedience, acceptable to God through Ieſus Chriſt.

div.head: SECT. XXI. Of Glorification begunne.

p.hi: Q. VVHat benefite receiue wee from the Kingly office of Chriſt?

div.p: A. OurRom. 8.30 Glorification; whereby our whole nature and eſtate is reſtored, according to theRom 8. • 9 image of Chriſt our King.

p.hi: Q. When is this benefite beſtowed on vs?

div.p: A. Col. 3.3.4 Partly in this preſent life, but fully and perfectly in the life to come.

p.hi: Q. How are wee glorified in this life?

div.p: A. Reu. 20.6. Partly in our condition, which is made bleſſed: and partly in our nature, which is made holy.

p.hi: Q. How are wee bleſſed in our condition?

div.p: A. Both in ſpirituall, and in outward things.

p.hi: Q. How in ſpirituall things?

div.p: A. In that, being in Chriſt, wee are not onely admitted into1. Joh. 1.3 fellowſhip with God; but alſo are made his Gal 4.5 children by Adoption, &Rom. 8.17. heyres of his glorious kingdome; which euen now, byRom. 5. • . faith, we doe in part fore-enioy, and reioyce in the hope thereof.

p.hi: Q. How are wee bleſſed in outward things?

div.p:
A. With all the1. Tim. 4 •
promiſes of God, and his liberall bleſsings, concerning this life; which are all giuen vnto the faithfull, withMar. 10.30 reſeruation of enduring the Croſſe; when God ſhall ſee it good for vs.

div.head: SECT. XXII. Of Sanctification.

p.hi: Q. HOw are we made holy in our nature?

div.p: A. By the grace of Sanctification; which is theT • . 3.5 renuing of our1. Theſ. 5.23 whole nature, according to theEph. 4.24 image of God, in righteouſneſſe and true holineſſe.

p.hi: Q. What are the parts of Sanctification?

div.p: A. They are two; according to the powerfull meanes, whereby they are wrought.

p.hi: Q. What is the firſt?

div.p: A. Rom. • .6, 7 Mortification of ſinne, wrought in vs by the power of the death of Chriſt.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſecond?

div.p: A. Rom. 6.4 Viuification, or quickning of vs, vnto newneſſe of life, by the power of Chriſt his reſurrection.

div.head: SECT. XXIII. Of the rule of Sanctification.

p.hi: Q. VVHat is the rule & ſquare of our Sanctification?

div.p: A. TheJoh. 17.17 whole word of God: that 〈◊〉 , both theJam. 2.8 Law, which requireth obedience; and the1. Tim. 1.10, 11. Goſpell, which directeth vs how to performe it.

p.hi: Q. How doth the Goſpell direct vs, 〈◊〉 the obedience of the Law?

div.p: A. Firſt, itIoh. 5.23 propoundeth God to be worſhipped of vs in Chriſt.
Secondly, it1 Theſ. 5.18 requireth obedience, • n way of thankefulneſſe for our redemption.
Thirdly, itRo. 10.6, 8. offereth, and conferreth to the regenerate, that which it requireth.

div.head: SECT. XXIIII. Of the Law.

p.hi: Q. VVHat is here meant by the Law?

div.p:
A. Onely the morall Law, compriſed byDeut. 4.13. God himſelfe in the Dec •
logue, or ten Commandements.
Q. Rehearſe the ten Commandements▪

p.hi: A.
God ſpake al theſe words, ſaying &c.
Q. What vſe is there of thoſe words I am the Lord thy God, that brought thee out of the land of Egypt, out of th • houſe of bondage?

div.p: A. They are a preface, enforcing the obedience of Gods Law; as proceeding from him, who is not onely the Lord ourPſal. 100.3. maker, but alſo our God 1. Tim. 4.10 and Sauiour.

div.head: SECT. XXV. Of the firſt Commandement.

p.hi: Q. WHich is the firſt Commandement?
A.
Thou ſhalt haue none other Gods before me.
Q. What is forbidden in this Commandement?

div.p:
A. Rom. • .7 Originall Corruption, as the fou •
taine
of impiety, with all the ſtreames of ignorance, errour, profaneneſſe, pride, fleſhly confidence, carnall feare, or loue &c.

p.hi: Q. What is required in this Commandement?

div.p: A. Eſay 8.13 That we ſanctifie the Lord God •• our hearts, yeelding vnto him in Chriſt, due faith, loue, feare, &c.

div.head: SECT. XXVI. Of the ſecond Commandement.

p.hi: Q. VVHich is the ſecond Commandement?

div.p: A. Exo. 20.4. &c. Thou ſhalt make thee no grauen Image &c.

p.hi: Q. What is forbidden in this Commandement?

div.p: A. Mat. 15.9 Euery forme of worſhip, not preſcribed by God himſelfe, in his word: and namely the worſhip ofHab. 2.18 images, or of God in images.

p.hi: Q. What is required in this Commandement?

div.p:
A. Eccl. 4.17 That wee diligently, and decently,
performe all parts of Gods worſhip preſcribed, as hearing the word praier, receiuing the Sacraments, &c.

div.head: SECT. XXVII. Of the third Commandement.

p.hi: Q. VVHich is the third Commandement?
A.
Thou ſhalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vaine &c.
Q. What is forbidden in this Commandement?

div.p: A. Mal. 1.6, 12. Euerie abuſe of the name of God, as byJam. 5.12. ſwearing: Gen. 16.5. vnreuerent mention of him, or his word, and workes Tit. 1.16. hypocriſie: Rom. 2.24. euill life, diſhonouring the profeſſion of religion: &c.

p.hi: Q. What is required in this Commandement?

div.p: A. That we honour God, and hi • religionMath. 5.16 Tit. 2.10. by our holy conuerſation: that we makePſal. 19.1, 2 honourable mention of him his word, and workes: that weJer. 4.2. ſwear by him truly, aduiſedly and rightly &c.

div.head: SECT. XXVIII. Of the fourth Commandement.

p.hi: Q. VVHich is the fourth Commandement?
A.
Remember the Sabbath Day, to keepe it holy, &c.
Q. What is required in this Commandement?

div.p: A. That wee beare the Sabbath in minde, toLuc. 23.54 fit our ſelues for it: that weExod. 34.21 reſt therein from our ordinary labours: finally that withEſa. 58.13. ioy, and deſire of profit, we performe the duties thereof.

p.hi: Q. What are the duties of the Sabbath?

div.p: A. They are partly duties of pietie; asAct. 13.14, 15. & 20.7. hearing, reading, prayer, holy conference, &c. partly of1. Cor. 16.2 mercie, as viſiting, and releeuing the ſicke, and needie; and ſuch like.

p.hi: Q. What is forbidden in this Commandement?

div.p:
A. The vnhallowing of the Sabbath;
byNeh • . 11.15 • &c. minding, or doing our ordinary affaires: byExod. 32. •
carnall reſt, or paſtime: byMar. 3.4 taking libertie to ſinne: finally byAmo •
• .5. M • l. 1.13. being wearie of holy duties.

div.head: SECT. XXIX. Of the fifth Commandement.

p.hi: Q. VVHich is the fifth Commandement?
A.
Honour thy father and thy mother &c.
Q. What is required in this Commandement?

div.p:
A. That
• phe. 6.1 • 5, &c. inferiors reuerence, and obey their ſuperiors: thatEph. 6.4, 9, &c. Tit. 2.7. ſuperiors ſo carrie themſelues, that they may be worthie of honour, and imitation: finally thatRom. 12.10. equals afford due reſpect each to other.

p.hi: Q. What is forbidden in this Commandement?

div.p:
A. Iude. • .9, 10. Neglect, and diſobedience, in inferiors: 1. • im. 2.2 •
indiſcreete carriage in ſuperiors: Math. 23. •
inciuilitie among equals.

div.head: SECT. XXX. Of the ſixt Commandement.

p.hi: Q. VVHich is the ſixt Commandement?
A.
Thou ſhalt not kill.
Q. What is forbidden in this Commandement?

div.p: A. Euerie hurt, done, threatned, or intended, to the ſoule, or bodie, either ofPro. 6.32. & • .35. 1. King 2.23 & 18.28. our ſelues, or of our Math. 23.15. & 15.14 Math. 5.21 22. &c. neighbours?

p.hi: Q. What is required in this Commandement?

div.p: A. That we loue and cheriſh, both the ſoule, and bodie, of our Heb. 3.1 • Iam. 1.27. Phil. 2.12. Eph. 5. • 9. neighbour, as we would, and ought to doe, our owne.

div.head: SECT. XXXI. Of the ſeuenth Commandement.

p.hi: Q. VVHich is the ſeuenth Commandement?
A.
Thou ſhalt not commit adulterie.
Q. What is forbidden in this Commandement?

div.p: A. All impuritie, and fleſhly pollution, inMath. 5.2 • . thought, Ephe. 4.2 • . word, orHeb. 13.4. action.

p.hi: Q. What is required in this Commandement?

div.p:
A. Chaſtitie, and puritie, inMath. 5.8. heart, Eph. 4.29. ſpeech, and
• . Theſ. 4.4. behauiour.

div.head: SECT. XXXII. Of the eight commandement.
div.p: Q. VVHich is the eight Commandement?
A.Exod. 10.15. Thou ſhalt not ſteale.
Q. What is forbidden in this Commandement?
A. The hindering, or abuſing, of Pro. 23.21. Luc. 15.13. our owne wealth, or of Pro. 1.11, &c. Amos 8.4. the wealth of our neighbour.
Q. What is required in this Commandement?
A. That wee preſerue, and further, both our owne wealth, and our neighbours, by all Eph. 4.28. lawfull courſes, and Tit. 2.10. honeſt dealing.

div.head: SECT. XXXIII. Of the ninth commandement.
div.p: Q. VVHich is the ninth Commandement?
A.Exo. 20.16. Thou ſhalt not beare falſe witneſſe againſt thy neighbour.
Q. What is forbidden in this Commandement?
A. All Col. 3 9. Eph 4.25. Apoc. 22.15 Pſal. 15.3, lying, diſſembling, equiuocating, falſe ſpeaking, or ſurmizing; finally what ſoeuer is contrarie to truth, or good report.
Q. What is required in this Commandement?
A. That by Pſal. 15.2. Jam. 3.17. true ſpeaking, and iudging, by 1. Cor. 12.22 ſeaſonable commendation, and reproofe; finally by all meanes, wee maintaine truth, and good name.

div.head: SECT. XXXIIII. Of the tenth Commandement.

p.hi: Q. VVHich is the tenth Commandement?
A.
Thou ſhalt not couet, &c.
Q. What is forbidden in this Commandement?

div.p: A. Originall corruption, orRom. 7.7. Jam. 1.14 Math. 15.19. concupiſcence, with all motions, proceeding there from, contrary to the rule of charitie, and the good of our neighbour.

p.hi: Q. What is required in this Commandement?

div.p: A. That wePro. 4 23. watch ouer our hearts, and outward ſenſes, keeping our thoughts, and affections, within the bounds of1. Tim. 6.8. contentment, & brotherly loue.

div.head: SECT. XXXV. Of Repentance.

p.hi: Q. THus farre of the rule of ſanctification: what is the effect or exerc • ſe thereof?

div.p: A. Repentance, which is a through change of ourRom. 12.1.2. purpoſe of heart, andEſa. 1.16.17. courſe of life, from euill, vnto good.

p.hi: Q. How is this change wrought in vs?

div.p: A. ByZech. 12.10 looking on our Sauiour, in the glaſſe of the Goſpell, with godlie ſorrow for the ſinnes, wherewith wee haue pierced him.

p.hi: Q. How may wee know that our repentance is true?

div.p:
A. By two notes: whereof the firſt is, if it extend vnto thePſal. 119.128. hatred of all ſinnes, andPſal. 119 •
practiſe of all duties, without reſeruation.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſecond note?

div.p: A. If we ſhew our hatred of ſinne, inHeb. 12.4. ſpirituall warfare againſt it, and our loue of righteouſneſſe, in the practiſe ofMath. 3.8. good workes.

div.head: SECT. XXXVI. Of the ſpirituall warfare.

p.hi: Q. WHat is the ſpirituall warfare?

div.p: A. TheEph. 6.10, 11, &c. withſtanding of all temptations vnto ſinne, from theEph. 4.27. Diuell, the1 Joh. 5.4. world, and our owneGal. 5.2 • , fleſh, by the power of the Grace of God.

div.head: SECT. XXXVII. Of good workes.

p.hi: Q. VVHat is a good worke?

div.p: A. Whatſoeuer is done of vs, by thePhil. 4.13. power of grace, according to theRom. 12.2. will of God, for1. Cor. 10.31 his glorie, and our owne, and others1. Cor. 10.21. good.

p.hi: Q. Who can doe good workes?

div.p: A. Onely the Regenerate, who areEph. 2.10. created anew for that purpoſe: and euen theyGal. 5.17. imperfectlie, becauſe of the remainders of ſinne.

p.hi: Q. Are not ſome good workes ſpecially commended to vs?

div.p: A. Yes; asMath. 6, 1, &c. Prayer, whereto ſometimes Faſting is to be ioined: and Almes.

div.head: SECT. XXXVIII. Of Prayer.

p.hi: Q. VVHat is Prayer?

div.p: A. It is thePhil. 4.6. requeſt of an humble heart vnto God, in theJoh. 14.14 name of Chriſt, withIam. 1.6. aſſurance to bee heard.

p.hi: Q. For whom muſt we pray?

div.p: A. For1. Tim. 2.1. all men, euenMat. 5.44. our enemies: but eſpecially for ſuch, as are ourEph. 6.18. brethren in Chriſt.

p.hi: Q. How, and for what, muſt we pray?

div.p: A. 1. Ioh. 5.14. According to the will of God, and the directions wee haue out of his word.

div.head: SECT. XXXIX. of the Lords Prayer.

p.hi: Q. VVHat directions haue we for prayer in the word of God?

div.p:
A. Manie precepts, and platformes of holie prayers: but eſpeciallie
Math. 6.9. &c. Luk. 11. • , &c. that moſt abſolute forme, and patterne, deliuered by our Sauiour himſelfe, called the Lords Prayer.

p.hi: Q. What are the words of the Lords Prayer?
A. Our Father, which art in heauen &c.

div.p: Q. Why are wee taught to call God [Father?]
A. That wee might come before him, as children, withMal. 1.6. reuerence, andPſal. • 03.13. confidence.
Q. Why are wee directed to call him [our] Father?
A. That we might be put in minde toMat. 5.23, &c. 1. Tim. 2.8. bee at peace one with another, and toIam. 5.16 pray one for another, as well as for our ſelues.
Q. VVherefore are wee directed to ſay, [which art in heauen?]
A. To encreaſe both ourEccleſ. 5.1. reuerence of him, who is ſo high aboue vs, and ourLuk. 11.13. confidence in him, who can and will doe all things for vs.

div.head: SECT. XL. Of the firſt Petition.

p.hi: Q. HOw many Petitions are there in the Lords Prayer?

div.p: A. Sixe: whereof the three firſt concerne God: and the three later our ſelues.

p.hi: Q. Why are thoſe Petitions firſt placed that concerne God?

div.p: A. To teach vs toJoh. 12.27, 28. preferre the glorie and ſeruice of God, before our owne good.

p.hi: Q. What are the words of the first Petition?
A. Hallowed be thy Name.
Q. What doe we aske of God in this Petition?

div.p: A. That God, who in himſelfe, his word, and workes, is moſt holy, and glorious, may beePſal. 96.8 1. Pet. 2.9 acknowledged, and honoured for ſuch, by vs.

div.head: SECT. XLI. Of the ſecond Petition.

p.hi: Q. VVHat are the words of the ſecond Petition?
A. Thy Kingdome come.
Q. What doe we craue of God in this Petition?

div.p: A. That theAct. • 6.18 Col 1.13 Kingdome of ſinne, and Satan, beeing more and more aboliſhed, Col 3.15, 16 Chriſt may now raigne in our hearts by grace, and2. Tim. 2.22 we with him for euer in glorie.

div.head: SECT. XLII. Of the third Petition.

p.hi: Q. VVHat are the words of the third Petition?
A. Thy will bee done in earth, as it is in heauen.
Q. What doe wee aske of God in this Petition?

div.p:
A. That2. Tim. 2.26 1. Pet. 4.2 renouncing the will of Satan, and our owne corrupt inclination,
wee mayPſa. 119.60 readily, andCol. 3.23 heartily obey the will of God; following, in our meaſure, the example of thePſa. 103.20 Angels and Saints, that are in heauen.

div.head: SECT. XLIII. Of the fourth Petition.

p.hi: Q. VVHat are the words of the fourth Petition?
A. Giue vs this day our dayly bread.
Q. What doe we begge of God in this Petition?

div.p: A. Pro. 30.8. Such a portion of outward bleſſings, as God ſhall ſee meete for vs: together withPhil. 4.11, 12. grace to be contented with our allowance.

div.head: SECT. XLIIII. Of the fift Petition.

p.hi: Q. VVHat are the words of the fift Petition?
A. And forgiue vs our Debts, as euen we forgiue our Debtors.
Q. What doe wee craue of God in this Petition?

div.p: A. That God wouldJob 35.24 Pſal. 35.3 Jer. 14.7 aſſure vs daily of the forgiueneſſe of our ſinnes; for Chriſt his ſake; working in vs aCol. 3 13 mercifull affection, to forgiue, for his ſake, ſuch as haue offended vs.

div.head: SECT. XLV. Of the ſixt Petition.

p.hi: Q. VVHat are the words of the ſixt Petition?
A. And lead vs not into temptation, but deliuer vs from euill.
Q. What doe wee aske of God in this Petition?

div.p: A. That ſinne may not onely be pardoned vnto vs, but dailyRo. 6.1, 2 mortified in vs: and wee eitherPro. 30.8 2. Cor. 12.8 kept by the prouidence of God from temptations, or1. Cor. 10, 13. 2 Cor. 12.9 preſerued by his Grace from being hurt thereby.

div.head: SECT. XLVI. Of the concluſion and circumſtances of Prayer.
div.p: Q. VVHy are wee taught to adde thoſe words, [For thine is the Kingdome, the power, and the glorie, for euer, and euer?]

A. That wee may firmely beleeue, that1. Tim. 1.17. God, the mightie, and euerlaſting King, Ephe. 3.20. can, andJer. 14 7. Ezek. 3 • 22. for his owne glorie will, grant the things we haue thus demanded.
Q. Why are wee taught to conclude with this word, [Amen?]
A. That thereby wee may ſignifie, not onely ourIam. 5.17. feruent deſire, that ſo it may be, but alſo ourIam. 1.6. Reu. 22, 20. faith, that ſo it ſhall be, as we haue prayed.

p.hi: Q. What other circumſtances are there required in Prayer?

div.p:
A. In priuate prayer,1. Cor. 14.2 1. Kin. 18.42. ſuch words, geſtures, &c. as may expreſſe our reuerence, and faith towards God: in publique prayer,1. Cor. 14 4, 17, 40. ſuch, as may alſo
witneſſe our Communion one with another, and deſire of mutuall edification.

div.head: SECT. XLVII. Of Faſting.

p.hi: Q. VVHen muſt Faſting be ioyned vnto Prayer?

div.p: A. When we deſire to1. Sam. 7.6 Eſther 4.16 auoid ſome great euill, or toNehe. 1.4. Act. 10.30. obtaine ſome great mercie at the hand of God.

p.hi: Q. What is Faſting?

div.p: A. TheJoel 2 16 chaſtiſing of our nature, and laying aſide of the delights of ſenſe, for a time; and that with reſpect to a ſpirituall buſineſſe.

p.hi: Q. What is that ſpirituall buſineſſe?

div.p: A. An extraordinarie endeauour ofEzra 8. • 1 humbling our ſelues, and of ſeeking the face, and fauour, of God.

div.head: SECT. XLVIII. Of Almes.

p.hi: Q. VVHat is Almes?

div.p: A. It is aDeut. 15.7 Heb. 13.16. dutie of Chriſtian loue, whereby1. Joh. 3 17 ſuch as haue this worlds good, doe2. Cor. 9.7 freely impart to ſuch as are in want.

p.hi: Q. Who muſt giue Almes?

div.p: A. Whoſoeuer hath1. Tim. 6.17 Luk. 21.3. ſuch a portion, out of which, by frugalitie, ſomething may be ſpared.

p.hi: Q. To whom muſt Almes be giuen?

div.p: A. ToDeu. 15.7, 11. thoſe on • ly, whom God by his prouidence, hath made poore; vnleſſeLuk 10.33 preſent extremitie diſpenſe with the conſideration of the perſon.

p.hi: Q. How much muſt we giue?

div.p: A. We muſt2. Cor. 9 6 ſow liberally, that we may reape alſo liberally: yet with reſpect to2. Cor. 8.13 our owne abilitie, and the2. Cor. 9.12. condition of the receiuer.

p.hi: Q. With what affection muſt Almes be giuen?

div.p:
A. WithMat 6.1. &c. humilitie before God,
Pſal. 112 4. compaſsion of our poore brother2. Cor. 9.7. cheerefulneſſe, andRom. 12.8. ſingleneſſe of heart.

div.head: SECT. XLIX. Of Death, and particular Iudgement.
div.p: Q. VVHat is the dealing of God with man after this life?
A. The bringing of all men vnto Iudgement.
Q. How are men brought to Iudgement?
A. Two waies: Viz.Heb. • .27 ſeuerally at the hower of euery ones death, and Act. 17.31 generally at the laſt day.
Q. How are men iudged in the houre of death?
A. God then pronounceth, and the conſcience apprehendeth the ſentence of abſolution, or condemnation: and the Luk. 16.22, 23. ſoule is accordingly conueyed into ioy, or miſerie.

div.head: SECT. L. Of the preparation to the laſt iudgement.

p.hi: Q. VVHat is the iudgement of the laſt day?

div.p: A. The great Aſsiſe of the whole world, wherein2. Cor. 5 10 Eccl. 12.14 all men ſhall appeare before the iudgement ſeate of Chriſt, to receiue according to that they haue done in this life.

p.hi: Q. When ſhall this day be?

div.p: A. Act 1.7 It is not for vs to know the times; onely wee know thatHeb. 10.37. 2. Pet. 3 9 hee that is to come, will come, and will not tarrie.

p.hi: Q. How ſhall Chriſt come to iudgement?

div.p:
A. Euen in hisAct. 1.11 humane body, butMat. 25.31. with vnſpeakeable glorie; attended with all the holy Angels of God, and with the1. Theſ. 4.1 •
ſhout of an Arch-Angell.

p.hi: Q. How ſhall all men be brought into the preſence of Chriſt the Iudge?

div.p: A. 1. Cor 15.52 The dead ſhall be raiſed with their owne bodies, and the liui •• changed, and that in a moment, at the ſound of the laſt trumpet.

p.hi: Q. Shall the reſurrection of the Elect, and the Reprobate be the ſame?

div.p: A. No. For1. Cor. 15.52, 53. the Elect ſhall riſe with glorious bodies: but the Reprobate with bodies full of vncomelineſſe.

p.hi: Q. How ſhall men appeare before Chriſt?

div.p: A. Luk. 21.28. 1. Theſ. 4.17. The Elect ſhall with ioy, be caught vp to meete the Lord: butReu. 1.7. & 6.15, 16. the Reprobate, with horror ſhall bee drawne into his preſence.

div.head: SECT. LI. Of Examination and ſentence.

p.hi: Q. HOw ſhall men bee tryed in this iudgement?

div.p:
A. Ro. 2.12, 15. According to the will of GOD, manifeſted vnto them by nature, or by Scripture: and the testimonie of their owne conſciences,
touching their obedience, or diſobedience thereto.

p.hi: Q. Shall the Elect vndergoe this tryall?

div.p: A. Yea, but with great fauour; forEzek. 18.22 Reu 14.13. not their ſinnes, but their good workes onely, ſhall bee remembred; and thoſe not ſtrictly cenſured, but onely produced, as proofes of that faith in Chriſt, whereby they haue2. Pet. 1.10, 11 entrance into the kingdome of God.

p.hi: Q. How ſhall ſentence bee pronounced?

div.p: A. Chriſt the Iudge ſhall award vntoMat. 25.34 the Elect the bleſſed kingdome promiſed: and toMat. 25.41. the Reprobate the curſe of euerlaſting fire, Rom. 6.23 which they haue deſerued.

div.head: SECT. LII. Of the Execution of the laſt Iudgement.

p.hi: Q. HOw ſhall this ſentence be executed?

div.p:
A. Mat. 25.46. Chriſt by his Almightie power, and miniſterie of Angels, ſhall ca ••
the Diuels, and wicked men into hell fire: and after carrie vp the righteous with himſelfe, into the bliſsefull, and euerlaſting kingdome of glorie.

q.p: Let vs heare the end of all: feare God and keepe his commandements: for this is the whole of man.
For God will bring euery worke vnto iudgement, with euery ſecret thing, whether it be good or euill.

div.head: A ſhort Prayer for the Morning.
div.p:
O Eternall and Almightie Lord God, who in vnſpeakeable wiſedome and goodneſſe haſt made all things for the good of man, and man with al, and aboue all things, for thine owne glorie; wee humbly acknowledge our ſelues to be vtterly vnworthy of the leaſt of all thy mercies, which wee either enioy, or deſire to enioy. For (O Lord) wee are not onely weake creatures, vnable to giue vnto thee firſt, that wee ſhould bee recompenced: but alſo ſinfull and vnthankefull wretches, not rendring vnto thy Maieſtie, according to thy kinde and gracious dealing with vs. Thou createdſt vs, O Lord, in thine owne image, endued with
wiſedome and true holineſſe, adorned with all bodily perfections, aduanced vnto dominion ouer all thy workes of wonder: but wee all in Adam, by breaking thy Couenant, forfeited our birth-right, de • aced thine holy image, and made our ſelues more vile then the beaſts that periſh. Thus were wee borne into the world an increaſe of ſinfull men; full of ignorance and vanitie of minde, of rebellion and obſtinacie of heart, ſecure in conſcience, peruerſe in affections, vnbridled in appetite, vtter enemies vnto thine holineſſe; careleſſe to know or ſeeke after thee, vnwilling either from thy bleſsings, or from thy iudgements, to take knowledge of thee. Yea, Lord, when thou cauſedſt the light of thy glorious Goſpell to ſhine vnto vs, our fooliſh hearts deſpiſed that light, and preferred darkneſſe before it, becauſe our deedes were euill; ſo that if thou hadſt not giuen vs, as well ſight as light, and a minde, as well as meanes, to know thee who art
true; euen to this day our eyes had beene ſtill blinded by Satan, the God and Prince of the darkneſſe of this world. But bleſſed for ouer be thy glorious Name, who for thine owne mercies ſake, not our merite, and by thine owne Almightie power, without any diſpoſition or concurrence on our part, haſt effectually called vs vnto the knowledge and obedience of thy Goſpell. But what can we plead for our ſelues, O Lord, that haue walked vnworthy of this thy great grace, and as much as in vs lieth, againe defaced thine image in vs, euen the new creature? For ſince the time that we gaue our names vnto Chriſt, and profeſſed our ſelues to bee of his partie, wee haue many waies, and many times, treacherouſly ioined with Satan, with the world, and our owne corruption, to ſinne againſt the honour of our Sauiour, and againſt the light of knowledge, which ſhineth into our conſciences; ſo that by our diſobedience and rebellion we haue weakened the
cauſe of thy Truth, and opened the mouth of the Aduerſarie to reproch the holy Goſpell of thy Sonne Ieſu • Chriſt, which we profeſſe. Finally, our whole courſe & conuerſation aboundeth with continuall breaches of all thy righteous lawes, and is ſhamefully barren of thoſe fruits of righteouſneſſe, which by Ieſus Chriſt ſhould redound vnto thy praiſe and glorie. Wherefore, O Lord, wee freely confeſſe againſt our ſelues our great wickedneſſe: wee iudge our ſelues worthy • o be deſtroyed for all our iniquities: we abhorne our ſelues and repent before thee in duſt and aſhes: we fly only to thy rich mercie & grace in Chriſt Ieſus; beſeeching thee for his ſake to haue mercie on vs, with his bloud to waſh & clenſe vs from all our ſinnes, in his face and countenance to behold vs, in his abſolute merite & mediation fauourably to accept vs. So ſhall there be no condemnation for vs, being in Chriſt Ieſus, who was made ſinne for vs, that wee might be made the righteouſnes of God in him.

Further, O Lord, that wee may ſoundlie aſſure our ſelues that wee are in Chriſt, and withall be enabled to walke more worthie of thy grace, wee beſeech thee make vs more and more partakers of the ſpirituall power, both of the death, and life of Chriſt. Let the power of his death mortifie in vs all carnall and ſinfull luſts: let it crucifie the world vnto vs, and vs vnto the world: let it dull and dead our hearts vnto the allurements of ſinne: let it make vs ſenceleſſe, or careleſſe, of the diſcouragements that are, or may be, offered in the way of welldoing. Let it arme vs with this mind, rather to ſuffer any trouble; and forbeare any pleaſure, then, by ſinning againſt thee, to hazard the peace of a good conſcience. On the other ſide, let the quickening power of the life of Chriſt reuiue our dead nature vnto new obedience: let it in flame our hearts with the loue of thy maieſtie: let it make thy word ſauourie vnto vs, and more deſirable then our appointed food: let it teach vs reſolutely
to ſhake of all impediments, carefullie to redeeme all occaſions, and gladlie to embrace all opportunities of doing good. Finally vnto all theſe good purpoſes, worke in vs, by thy holie word, & ſpirit, a dailie encreaſe of liuing and ſauing faith. O Lord, it is thine onely vnſpeakeable gift; without whom it is no more poſſible to beleeue that which thou promiſeſt, then to performe whatſoeuer thy law requireth. Thou therefore, O Father, for Chriſt Ieſus ſake, by the powerfull operation of thy Spirit, worke and encreaſe in vs this mother grace. Teach vs ſo to lay hold on Chriſt, and lodge him in our hearts, that we may not onely applie, and aſſure vnto our ſelues, all the promiſes of life and mercie, but alſo cleanſe our ſelues from all filthineſſe of the fleſh and ſpirit, and grow vp vnto full holineſſe in the feare of thy Maieſtie.

And now, Lord, for outward things wee ſubmit our ſelues to thy wiſe and fatherlie prouidence; onely beſeeching thee, to giue vs this day,
what thou knoweſt needefull and behoofefull vnto vs for the day. Lord feede vs with food conuenient for vs: giue vs ſuch a portion of health, maintenance, credit, and all outward comforts, as may make vs thankefull and ſeruiceable vnto thee. And aboue all, giue vs grace to employ and improue all thy bleſſings, as thy talents, to the furtherance of the worke thou haſt giuen vs to doe. Lord giue vs euerie day (but eſpecially on thy Sabbath dayes) more then a naturall and common vſe of thy good creatures. Let vs in all things taſt and ſee, how ſweet and gracious a God thou art, Let thy good bleſſings be, not as a wall, to ſtop our ſight, that we may not looke beyond them; but as a glaſſe, through which wee may the better diſcerne thy loue and faithfulneſſe towards vs concerning heauenly things. Let vs ſerue thee with an vpright heart, in the duties and buſineſſes of this day; bringing the generall profeſſion of religion into particular practiſe, according to
our ſeuerall callings. Lord let vs neuer bee a burden vnto humane ſocietie, nor a blemiſh vnto the profeſſion of Chriſtianitie, by idleneſſe, or inordinate liuing. Make our labours and endeauours fruitfull and beneficiall, not onely vnto our ſelues, that wee may eat thereof, and reioice before thee, but alſo vnto all others whom they concerne, that they may praiſe thee with vs, and for vs.

Bleſſe thy whole Church, O Lord, and build it vp more and more in perfect beautie. Take pittie on thoſe thine elect, that walke yet in darkeneſſe, and cauſe the light of thy Goſpell of grace to ſhine vnto them. Confirme thy gracious worke in thoſe, who haue receiued the firſt fruits of thy ſpirit. Comfort ſuch as mourne for ſinne. Fulfill the deſires of all that trulie long and ſigh after thee. Support, and cure the infirmities of all that are humbled vnder thine hand, and that haue ſeene affliction in the rod of thy viſitation. Preſerue the good land wherein woe
liue: make vs more thankefull for all thy rich bleſsings, and our manifold mightie deliuerances. Saue thine Annointed ſeruant, our Soueraigne Lord King Iames; with our gracious Queene Anne, and the Royall progenie. Aſsiſt with thy ſpirit and grace, all that are in authoritie; ſanctifie all thoſe whom thou emploieſt in the worke of the miniſterie. Remember in ſpeciall mercie, thoſe, whom thou haſt knit vnto vs in the bands of conſanguinitie, affinitie, neighbourhood, or Chriſtian amitie. Finallie, vnto all thine, and ours, vouchſafe Peace and mercy, through Ieſus Chriſt, thy deere Sonne, our alone Redeemer and Sauiour. To whom with thee, O Father, and thy holie Spirit, one God, and King euerlaſting, be rendred all honor, ſeruice, and thankeſgiuing, for euermore. Amen.

div.head: A ſhort Prayer for the Euening.
div.p:
O Almightie God, King of Glory Father of Eternitie, who dwelling on high abaſeſt thy ſelfe to behold things in heauen & in earth, & being the firſt & the laſt, giueſt beginning & ending to all times & affaires, wherein thy creatures are employed; we acknowledg with humble & thākfull hearts, the riches of thy bountie afforded vs, thine vnworthie ſeruants, as well this day now paſt, as in the whole courſe of our liues. Thou O Lord, haſt made vs, and that fearfully and wonderfully: thou haſt been our hope from our mothers breſts. Thou haſt lengthened the daies of our life vnto this houre, & therein haſt ſhewed vs many mercies. Thou haſt freed our bodies from diſeaſes & dangers, our names from reproch, our ſubſtance from ſpoile, our liberty from violent and vniuſt reſtraint. Thou haſt ſtrengthened vs vnto labour, ſatiſfied vs with thy good creatures,
cheared our hearts with the fellowſhip and loue of thy people, our fellow ſeruants: and bleſſed our endeauors with ſucceſſe through thy good prouidence. Thou haſt heard our prayers, accompliſhed our deſires, turned away our feares, mitigated our troubles, and put an end from time to time to all our afflictions. Thus haſt thou ſhewed thy ſelfe to be the God, that delighteſt in the proſperitie of thy ſeruants. But, O Lord, how can we worthilie magnifie thy mercy towards vs in Ieſus Chriſt? In whom thou haſt, from all eternitie, appointed an heauenly Kingdome vnto vs: By whoſe word thou haſt called vs: by whoſe blood thou haſt redeemed vs: by whoſe Spirit thou haſt ſanctified, and ſealed vs vnto the day of redemption: In whom we haue this liberty, to call thee Abba, Father: In whom, and with whom, all earthly bleſſings are giuen vnto vs, not onely for our bodily comfort, but alſo as pledges of our heauenly inheritance. Oh, how deare therefore are thy
thoughts of mercie vnto vs, O Lord how great is the ſumme of them Bleſſed Father, enlarge our hearts to comprehend thy loue, and encline them to loue thee, who haſt ſo loued vs.

But let vs mourne and be aſhamed that wee haue returned nothing vnto thy maieſtie, but hatred for thy good will. Let it ſtrike our hearts, that wee haue abuſed thy bodily bleſsings vnto couetouſneſſe, or intemperance: thy patience vnto preſumption: the grace of thy Goſpell vnto licenciouſneſſe in ſinning. Let vs abhorre our ſelues, that wee haue prophaned thy ſabbaths, deſpiſed thy word, quenched thy ſpirit, vnhallowed thy name, & many waies defiled the holy profeſſion we haue taken vpon vs. Let vs repent in duſt and aſhes, for our wilfull blindneſſe of minde, hardneſſe of heart, remorſeleſſeneſſe of conſcience; whereby wee haue reſiſted the worke of thy grace in vs. Thou O Lord wouldeſt haue purged vs, and we would not be purged; thou wouldeſt
haue cured vs, but wee would not be cured. Th • ſe, and all other our ſinnes, O Lord, let vs recount before thee, with true ſorrow and aſtoniſhment of heart. But doe not thou, O Father, ſtraightly marke iniquities; nor deale with vs as we haue deſerued. Truth Lord, vnto vs belongeth nothing, but confuſion and condemnation: but vnto thee compaſsio • and forgiueneſſe, though wee haue grieuouſly rebelled againſt thee. Thou haſt in thy word proclaimed thy ſelfe vnto vs, to be The Lord, mercifull & gracious, ſlow to anger, forgiuing iniquitie, tranſgreſsion, and ſinne. Thou haſt made many faithfull promiſes, that thou wilt bee found of them that ſeeke and ſue for mercie vnto thee. Thou haſt ſatiſfied thy Iuſtice in the accurſed death of thy Sonne, our ſurety and Sauiour, Ieſus Chriſt, for the ſinnes of the whole word of thine elect. Thou haſt giuen vs of thy Spirit, wherby euen we, ſinfull wretches, are taught, and enclined, to forgiue for thy ſake ſuch as
haue offended vs: how much more wilt thou ſhew thy ſelfe a faithfull and mercifull God to pardon all our ſinnes, and to clenſe vs from all vnrighteouſneſſe? Wherefore O Lord heare, O Lord forgiue, O Lord conſider, n • giue a gracious anſwere vnto our ſupplication, for the Lords ſake.

Yea Lord, teach vs to riſe vp with thy Maieſtie, againſt our ſins, that our warre with them may aſſure vs that we haue peace with thee. Let vs not be ſuch traitors to thy Maieſtie, as to harbour thine enemies. Breake of in • uerie one of vs the wicked cuſtomes of ſinning: aboliſh the power and dominion thereof: crucifie the loue and affection thereto. Let vs, in the bloudy paſsion of our deare Sauiour, ſee the ougly face, heare the dreadfull cry, and feele the intolerable burden of our tranſgreſsions. And let vs not, as if the loade were yet too light, let vs not (bleſſed God) adde more vnto the waight and meaſure of our ſinnes: but rather let vs, in our proportion, beare part in the ſufferings
of our Sauiour; ceaſing from ſinne for his ſake, who for our ſakes refuſed not to offer vp his innocent ſoule a ſacrifice for ſinne.

Lord teach vs to doe thy will. Knit our hearts vnto thee, that wee may feare thy name. Let thy good Spirit leade vs in all the pathes of righteouſneſſe, and make our barren nature fruitfull in good workes. Quicken vs, O Lord, for thy names ſake, with the life of grace: and ſtabliſh our hearts with thy free Spirit. Teach vs freely to ſubmit our ſelues to the eaſie yoake, and light burden of our Lord Ieſus Chriſt. Let thy grace ſo frame vs vnto heartie obedience, that thy commandement may not be grieuous vnto vs. Let thy loue in Chriſt Ieſus be ſo ſhed abroad in our hearts by the holy Ghoſt, that no difficulties may diſcourage vs in the way of well doing. Let the meditation of the glorious kingdome prepared for vs, ſo poſſeſſe and affect vs, that the loue of this preſent world may ſeeme baſe, and vnworthy of vs. Let the expectation
of the ſuddaine comming of our Lord Ieſus Chriſt ſo awaken vs, that the momentanie pleaſures of ſinne, or cares of this life, may not lull vs a ſleepe, and enſnare vs.

Watch ouer vs this night by thy gracious prouidence, preſerue vs from the dangers of the darkneſſe: refreſh vs with the moderate vſe of thine ordinance of reſt and ſleepe: raiſe vs vp with health of bodie, and cheare of heart, to the duties of the next day. Let thy kindneſſe and mercie follow vs all the dayes of our life. Bring vs in peace, with good report, eſpecially with a good conſcience, vnto the bed of the graue; that after the ſleepe of death, wee may awake vnto bleſſed immortalitie.

Preſerue thy whole Church, and adde thereto, from day to day, ſuch as ſhall be ſaued. Be mercifull to this Land: forgiue the common and crying ſinnes, of profaneneſſe, worldlineſſe, crueltie, and abuſe of thy long patience, and liberall bleſſings; eſpecially of thy Goſpell. Giue grace vnto
all eſtates, truely to returne vnto thee, and to ſeek thy face and fauour. Eſpecially poure downe a liberall ſhower of all bodily and ſpirituall bleſſings on the Kings Maieſtie, with the Queene, and Royall family; ſanctifie, and aſſiſt the Magiſtrates, and Miniſters. Continue theſe bleſſings of peace, and of thy Goſpell, vnto the poſteritie after vs. Bleſſe all that loue vs, and are by any band linked, or allied vnto vs. Yea take pittie of thoſe that cauſeleſſely hate vs. Shew vs all, O Lord, thy mercie in this life, and in the life to come, grant vs thy ſaluation; through Ieſus Chriſt, thine onely Sonne, and our alone Sauiour. To whom with thee, O Father, and thy bleſſed Spirit, be all praiſe, power, dominion, and obedience, henceforth and for euer. Amen.
